1.content:
My name is Cassandra Pennant. Call me Cassie, everybody does.

I was 16 when it happened, a junior in high school. I lived with my mom, my stepdad, and my 14-year-old stepbrother, Pat. We all got along well.

There wasn't a whole lot that was special about me back then. I was a plain-looking girl, not a lot of curves. I didn't have a lot of interests in school, keeping to myself, except for a small circle of friends. Needless to say, the boys weren't exactly tripping over each other to get to me.

As for my experience with the opposite sex, what I knew about the male anatomy was akin to what I knew about the Eiffel Tower: I knew it existed, I'd seen some pictures, but I couldn't tell you the first thing about what it was like.

You may think it's strange that I'm talking so much about my absence of experience when it comes to sex. But I need for you to know these things about me. I need you to believe them. I need you to believe me.

Because, if you don't believe me, you won't have any idea why I reacted to two words my doctor said as if she'd said them in a language I'd never heard before.
1.title: About Me

11.content:
Breakfast was good on the plate, but nowhere near as appetizing coming back up and into the toilet. I couldn't understand it. I had no food allergies, and Pop was a decent cook. So why couldn't I keep it down?

"Cassie?" Mom called.

I texted her: Sick. Throwing up.

She texted back: Stay home. I'll call the Dr.

When my stomach was finally empty, I brushed my teeth and gargled three times, just so my breath wouldn't announce that I'd spent the morning ralphing.

With that done, I went downstairs. "Do you think you could handle a cup of tea and some saltines?" Mom asked.

My stomach didn't instantly rebel at the thought, so I said, "I'll try."

As I sipped the tea, Mom asked, "Any idea where this is from?"

I shook my head. "I was fine last night. I thought I was okay when I woke up. I just don't get it."

"Well, I got you in for a 10:20 appointment. Dr. Foster will figure it out."

I hoped so. I didn't think I could take many more mornings like this.
11.title: The Day It Began

111.content:
"So, Cassie," Dr. Foster asked, "what seems to be the problem?"

"This morning," I replied, "I was sick as a dog. It just came out of nowhere. Now, I feel okay again."

"Interesting," she said. She checked my chart. "Your temperature is a little elevated. Have you noticed any other symptoms?"

"I've been going to the bathroom more often. But that isn't anything."

"When was your last period?"

"Two weeks ago. It was lighter than usual, but it was about the right time."

"Are you sexually active?"

"No, Doctor."

"Doctor," Mom said, "it sounds like you think Cassie's pregnant."

"I'm just getting some information, Mrs. Pennant," she replied. "I'm going to order some blood and urine tests, see what we can rule out."

So I went to the lab, where they drew my blood, then handed me a paper cup and directed me to the restroom. As I had said, I was going more frequently, so I didn't even need to turn on a faucet to get things done. Then, I went back to the exam room and waited.

It was getting on lunchtime when Dr. Foster came back in. "We've got our answer, Cassie," she said. "You're pregnant."
111.title: Dr. Foster

1111.content:
"Pregnant?" I couldn't have heard her right. "I told you, I'm a virgin!"

"It doesn't look that way from here," she said.

"I can't be pregnant! Your tests must have come out wrong."

She showed me the test results. "Blood and urine tests both show your body is producing a hormone called hCG. People who are pregnant produce hCG. People who aren't pregnant don't. You're producing hCG, so you're pregnant."

"But I'm a virgin! You can examine me yourself."

She rolled her eyes. "The hymen is not some kind of factory seal. Many things can break it, and it can heal."

"Come along, Cassie," Mom said, "let's go home."

I got up and followed Mom, still trying to wrap my head around this. Pregnant? How could I possibly be pregnant?
1111.title: Pregnant?

choices: Very strange things happen in this town.
we have a very interesting family history.
11111.content:
Upon returning home, Mom took me to her bedroom and closed the door, before having me sit on her bed and sitting next to me. "You've got to believe me, Mom." In tears, I said. "I never had sex with anyone! I'm a virgin!"

"You know I love you honey." Serious, Mom said. "So please understand that I have to ask you these questions..." She took a breath. "Have you ever accepted a strange drink from a boy at a party in the last few months?"

"No."

"Have you ever fallen asleep in study hall or in the library?"

"No."

"Ever kept your bedroom window open at night."

I sighed. "Mom, no." Firmly, I said. "I simply can't be pregnant..."

"I'm afraid the tests are quite accurate, sweetie." Softly, mom said. "Unless..."

"Unless what?" Worried, I asked.

Mom shook her head. "Never mind..." Quickly, she said. "Forget I said anything."

"The doctor said I'm pregnant!" Crying, I wailed. "If you know something, anything... tell me!"

Mom sighed. "Okay..."
11111.title: At Home

choices: The crazy cat lady in the old house.
111111.content:
To say I was taken aback by that was an understatement. "What do you mean strange things happen in this town?" Surprised, I demanded. "I never noticed anything."

"Well, for example, you know that your younger brother, Pat, was adopted, right?"

I nodded. "Yeah, but he has the same eye and hair color as me." Curious, I said. "Everyone just assumes that he's your biological son."

"Well, actually, he was my husband." to my shock, Mom said. She walked over to her nightstand and pulled out a small box before opening it and showing me the series of photos that were inside. "Pat regressed in age from forty to two in less than a week."

Looking at the photographs, I was stunned. "What- What caused this?!"

Mom sighed. "No one knows, so it was swept under the rug." Softly, she explained. "Pat was declared dead, and I adopted a two-year-old orphan boy who ironically had the same name."

"What else happened in this town?" shaken, I asked.

"Do you remember Dr. Foster who examined you?" Looking at me, Mom asked. I nodded and Mom added, "She was my doctor when I was your age."

"How is that possible...?" Stunned, i asked.

Mom shrugged. "How is it possible for you to be pregnant out of the blue?" Quietly, she countered. "Dr. Foster has not aged a single day in over fifty years, but no one talks about the strangeness here, especially not to outsiders."

"Why is this happening to me now?" Quivering, I asked. "Mom, I need answers..."

Mom again sighed. "I might know someone who could find those answers, but she is a difficult woman to talk to." Serious, she said. "She is, you might say, eccentric."

"Who is she?" Anxious, I asked.

Mom frowned. "She is..."
111111.title: Very strange things happen in this town.

choices: Explaining Things to Pop and Pat
111112.content:
"There is this story," Mom said, "that my grandmother told me."

"What is it?"

"It happened when she was 17 years old. She found herself... 'in trouble' was what they called it then."

"Pregnant?"

"Her parents were scandalized. Good girls just didn't do that sort of thing back then. They sent her to a home for unwed mothers. When she had the baby, she gave it up for adoption. When she went back home, her parents treated her like damaged goods, rushing her into marriage to the first young man who expressed interest in her."

"That's cold. But what does it have to do with me?"

"Grandma always insisted to me that... that she had no idea how she'd become pregnant."

"Holy... And now it's happened to me, too?"

Mom shrugged. "All I know is what she told me: that she got pregnant without sex, and gave birth to a boy. And now, here you are."

There I was. Every test said I was pregnant, even though I'd never done the one thing everyone knows leads to pregnancy. "Sounds like I'm following in Great-Grandma's footsteps."
111112.title: we have a very interesting family history.

1111121.content:
My stepfather came home that afternoon, along with my stepbrother, Pat. "Heard you weren't feeling too sharp this morning, Cassie," Pop said, kissing me on the forehead. "You know what it is?"

Either a boy or a girl, I thought, but didn't say. Jokes weren't going to help Pop believe what I had to tell him. "We went to the doctor's office."

"And?"

I took a deep breath. "I'm pregnant."

"I see. When were you going to introduce him to us?"

"I had a very good reason for not bringing him to say hello, Pop."

"And what might that reason be?"

"He doesn't exist."

"You've lost me."

"Mom said it happened to Great-Grandma way back when, too."

"That's... that's not possible. It's just not possible."

"I can't explain it, Pop. There's no reason for me to be pregnant, but I am. There's plenty reason for me to be scared, though, and I'm terrified. Great-Grandma was shipped off to have her baby, and I don't know what to expect. No pun intended."

"Sis," Pat said, "virgins... virgins just don't get pregnant. It doesn't happen that way."

"Well , it didn't happen to me any other way. I've been through every common explanation. Now, I need to look at the uncommon explanations."

Pop was silent for a long while. Then, he asked, "What did you say happened to your great-grandmother?"

"Her parents shipped her off to some place where the neighbors wouldn't gossip. She had a boy, and he was given up for adoption. Then they married her off to the first boy who didn't turn his nose up at her."

"Well, I don't know the truth about where this baby came from, but you're welcome here, Cassie."

"And the baby?"

"And the baby."

Alright. History wouldn't go that far to repeat itself.

Now, I just had to figure out how this baby got begotten.
1111121.title: Explaining Things to Pop and Pat

11111211.content:
Next was my best friend, Trish Regan. Although there was no telling how long that was going to last, given what I was about to tell her. She came up to my room. "I brought your homework," she said. "Need help going over it?"

"Probably," I said. "Trish, there's something I need to tell you."

"Lay it on me, girlfriend."

"I'm pregnant."

She swatted me on the shoulder. "And when were you going to tell your best friend?"

"I just did. You were sitting here."

"You just told me you were pregnant. But when were you going to tell me you had a boyfriend?"

"I'll tell you about any boyfriend I have when I get one."

"You don't have a boyfriend."

I shook my head.

"But you're pregnant... Were you raped?"

I shook my head again. This is it, I thought. "I'm a virgin."

For a full minute, she stared at me, saying nothing. Then: "You're pregnant... and a virgin?"

I nodded. "Please, believe me."

She began making the sign of the cross.

I stopped her. "Trish, I'm serious."

"You're a pregnant virgin. Doesn't that mean... ?"

"Not in this case. If an angel had appeared to me and told me I was supposed to have the most important child in the world, I would have told you then."

She spent another minute in silence. Then: "How did this happen?"

"I don't know. Apparently, my Great-Grandma had a baby without a boyfriend. But she never figured out how." I lay back on my bed. "What am I going to do?"

"I don't know," Trish said. "But I know one thing."

"What?"

She lay back next to me. "You don't have to do it alone."
11111211.title: Trish Pays a Visit

111112111.content:
The next day saw me going back to school, only with a difference: I was returning with the knowledge that a baby was growing inside me.

"You'll need to start thinking about how you want to explain this," Mom said. "A pregnancy is not something you can keep secret forever."

For now, though, the fact that I was pregnant would be a secret, just like the fact that this baby didn't get here through the usual method.

******************************


I tried to pay attention in class, but my thoughts kept leaving the classroom and the lesson plan, to revolve around the fetus inside me: What did it look like? How big was it? Was it aware of things outside the womb? Questions like these were more interesting to me than calculus or European history.

At lunch, Trish and I sat down with Susan Porter, my other best friend, and told her. "How did it happen? What do you do now?" I'll give her this, her questions were just as good as the ones I'd been pondering. The only difference was, somebody knew the answers to the questions I had pondered in class.

"Nobody knows where the baby came from," I told her. "Or, if they do, they won't tell me. It's enough to make me wonder if it really is a miracle."

"Maybe it is," Susan said. She showed me her tablet. She had been looking something up, presumably about mystery pregnancies, and a quote caught her eye:

"A miracle is not contrary to nature, only contrary to what we know about nature."

I shrugged. "It's the closest we've come to an answer so far."
111112111.title: At School

1111121111.content:
We went back to Dr. Foster for another checkup. "Good to see you again, Cassie," she said. "Have you remembered anything since last time?"

"There's nothing to remember," I replied. "No male of the species has touched me in the manner normally associated with getting pregnant. I can tell you, though, that it isn't unprecedented."

"There have been no sightings of mysterious stars or itinerant nobility, if that's what you mean."

"I mean my great-grandmother had a baby when she was 17, and she always insisted that she had been a virgin at the time."

"Oh." Clearly, she hadn't expected to hear that, any more than I'd expected to hear I was expecting.

"I've been doing my own research," I said, "along with a couple friends of mine. As much as I'd love to say something sounds familiar, I have to admit I've come up short. So, for now, there's nothing to do but make sure this baby's healthy. Which brings me to you."

"I see. Well, I can't say I'm convinced on the issue of virgin birth, but I can keep you, and your baby, in good condition."

"Alright. So, we have our own ideas about how I came to be sitting here. Since I don't need for you to believe I'm a virgin, we should be able to get through this together."

She smiled. "I think I can agree to that." And we shook hands on it.

******************************


One physical examination later, Dr. Foster said, "I think we can safely say that you're two months along. I take it you've decided to have the baby?"

I nodded. "And I'm keeping it."

"Alright. I'll print out some dietary recommendations, and we'll see you next month. Happy Thanksgiving."
1111121111.title: Two Weeks Later

11111211111.content:
I had mixed feelings about Thanksgiving this year. On the one hand, I always enjoyed spending the day with my relatives. On the other hand, I was picking this day to tell them I was pregnant, and there was no telling how many would believe me when I answered the inevitable follow-up question.

After napping during the car ride (Mom said it was normal for pregnant women to be tired, but all I could think of was how glad I'd be when I could actually get enough sleep again), I split my time between helping in the kitchen and cheering on Pop and Pat in the Turkey Bowl, our family's traditional touch football game.

Finally, the time came when it felt right to speak up. "Nana," I said, "I'm pregnant."

That shut up everyone else at the table.

"Oh, my," Nana said, "you're a little young for that, aren't you? So, tell us, who's the father?"

"That's the thing, Nana: There isn't one."

And that got them talking again, mostly asking each other who I was trying to kid.

But Nana shut them up again when she said, "That happened to my mother, once. I hope you're doing better than she did."
11111211111.title: Telling My Extended Family

111112111111.content:
"Of all the days to make you need new clothes," Mom said, "your hormones picked Black Friday."

That pretty much summed it up. On Thanksgiving, my pre-pregnancy bras fit just fine. This morning, they were too small.

Oh, well. Nothing to do for it but go to the mall, Black Friday or no Black Friday.

******************************


The upside to our necessary shopping trip was that Trish and Susan were at the mall, too. "Hey, Cassie," Susan said. "Bringing your mom to hang out?"

"No, I need new bras."

They shrugged. "Something to do," Trish said.

I picked out enough bras for two weeks. Then, Mom brought me to get some clothes. "Not just for your new figure," she said, "but because, in a few weeks, you'll be needing clothes with a little more room at the waist."

"I'm going to need maternity clothes that soon?"

"No, those will be a ways off just yet. But you'll need some in-between clothes. At first, you'll look like you're putting on a few pounds. It won't be until your fourth month that you'll really start to look pregnant."

After that, we went to the bookstore and picked out a book on pregnancy. Trish and Susan each picked up a copy, too, so they could learn along with me and follow what I was talking about. After all, I was sure to be talking about my pregnancy a lot, even if I hadn't been a virgin.
111112111111.title: Bra Shopping

1111121111111.content:
It was right before school let out for winter break when it happened.

I was in my second home (i.e., the girls' restroom), when three girls walked in. I could hear them talking as they gathered by the sink.

"Anybody seen Pennant?"

"She's probably in the bathroom someplace, again."

"She has to go a lot, doesn't she?"

"She doesn't just go. A few times, I've heard her throwing up."

"Uh-oh."

"What'd you lose?"

"Not me, Pennant. My sister used to throw up and use the bathroom a lot when she was preggers."

"Cassie Pennant pregnant? Lord, now I've heard it all."

No, you haven't, I thought.

"Guess she's on her way out."

"Not to mention trouble at home. Her folks will kick her out when she tells them."

"You think so?"

"Happens all the time. My cousin works at the women's clinic, and every girl our age tells her their folks are going to kill them."

It got quiet out there when I flushed, and their heads turned when I walked out of the stall. They parted like the Red Sea when I walked up to the sink.

Just before I walked out, I turned to them and said, "My folks are happy for me, thanks for asking."

I breathed a sigh of relief. They were talking about me, but it was about Mom and Pop right now.
1111121111111.title: The School Starts to Talk

11111211111111.content:
Christmas had always meant a lot to me, but it seemed to take on more meaning for me this year. No prizes for guessing why.

Don't misunderstand me. What I said when I told Trish I was pregnant was true. I did not - do not - believe that the three-month-old fetus inside me was put there by a higher power. I didn't, and don't, believe that I was chosen. I didn't understand how this baby had come to be, but that was no reason to believe that it had an important destiny to fulfill. The more I thought about it - and anybody you ask will only be half-joking when they ask if I thought about anything else - the more I came to the conclusion that what was happening to me and inside me was perfectly natural, if totally unusual.

Still, you can't really blame me for feeling a good deal of sympathy for that other teenage girl who found herself pregnant without sex, can you? I read about how her fiance was being nice to her when he planned to break up with her (sparing her the punishment she would have suffered if he'd publicly accused her), and I couldn't help thinking of Great-Grandma, shipped off to some place nobody cared about to have her baby. How is it, I pondered, that there has been more progress in the time between Great-Grandma and me than between Mary and Great-Grandma?

As far as gifts went, I got some Blu-Rays, some clothes that might fit me next Christmas but were too small for me now,... and a book of baby names from Nana. And people wonder why I spent so much time thinking and talking about it.
11111211111111.title: Christmas

111112111111111.content:
When school opened up again, I was wearing my in-between clothes. I needed them, and Mom was already planning a trip to the mall for maternity wear. My hormonally-enhanced breasts convinced her to stay ahead of my wardrobe needs.

But these were my in-between things, like I said, so the whispers I heard when I walked by were split into two groups: fat and pregnant. To be fair, both arguments had reasonable evidence behind them. It just so happened that evidence for one was also evidence for the other. I was eating more, thanks to both my morning sickness subsiding and my appetite increasing. My belly was undeniably bigger, thanks to the baby taking up more room.

Of course, anybody who cared to eavesdrop on the lunchtime conversations I had with Trish and Susan could have settled the debate, since I spent so much time talking about the baby. Now, though, I was also talking about my mind, since I had started having bizarre dreams and wanted someone to hear about them.

And I'm not exaggerating when I call them bizarre: One dream had me with a transparent belly, so people could see the baby before it was even born. Another had me as the mother of a boy whose dingaling was where his nose should be, and I was trying to stop him from showing it to everyone. "My brother would totally do that!" Susan said of that dream.

Now, with all this talking about the baby that we were doing, you'd think I'd have an answer when Susan asked me, "So, what do you want to say when people start asking whose it is?"

But I didn't, so I turned to Trish. "Yeah, Cassie," she said. "We want to put up a united front, but we have to take our cues from you."

"I, uh, I haven't decided yet," I was forced to concede.

"Well, you'd better," Trish said. "It's going to get more obvious that you aren't just packing on the pounds, and, since you aren't dating anyone, they're going to ask how it happened."

I knew she was right.

But how do you explain how you got pregnant, when even medical science says "Damned if we know"?
111112111111111.title: Back to School

1111121111111111.content:
The day finally came, aptly enough, at the maternity shop, aptly named Great Expectations. The shop had a belly pad for trying out clothes you weren't quite big enough for yet, and I was using it to get a better idea of how I would look in the months ahead.

I was coming out of the dressing room to show some clothes to Mom, when I bumped into Rosemary Johnson coming in. We said hi, and I got feedback from Mom on how the clothes looked on me. The whole time, I was thinking about how it was bound to get out now that I was pregnant. After all, why else would I be trying on maternity clothes?

I had picked out the clothes I would be wearing for a while, and I went back to the dressing room to put my in-between clothes back on, when Rosemary asked, "Whose is it?"

"Huh?" Smooth move, Ex-Lax.

"Don't tell me we were both seeing the same guy? I'm mad enough at him for knocking me up, I'll kill him if he's been stepping out."

I shook my head. "It's not him."

"So who's the lucky guy?"

Maybe it was because I didn't want Rosemary going after some innocent guy. Maybe I just wanted to get out of the conversation. Or maybe part of me wanted the whole story to get out, now that half of it was blown already.

Whatever the reason, I looked Rosemary in the eye and said, "I'm a virgin."
1111121111111111.title: The Question Gets Asked

11111211111111111.content:
When we got home, I called Trish and Susan. "The secret's out," I said. "I ran into Rosemary Johnson at the maternity shop, and wound up blabbing everything."

"Smooth move, Ex-Lax," Susan said.

"Well, it's out there now," Trish said. "Nothing we can do about it, except be on your side."

Susan nodded. "Like sticks. They could break us individually, but, when we're together, they can't do it."

******************************


I did my best to remember that Monday morning, when we were back in school.

It started with the whispers. Everywhere I went, people were looking at me and whispering. Mostly, they shut up when I got too close.

Finally, though, somebody said something. Specifically, it was Veronica Decker, the head cheerleader and most popular girl in school, who looked me square in the face and asked, "Do you really expect people to believe that you're the mother of the Second Coming?"

"No," I replied, hoping I sounded braver than I felt. "I don't know if there's a God, and I don't know how it happened. All I know is, I've never had sex, and I'm pregnant, anyway." I tried to walk away.

"This isn't over, Pennant," Veronica said.

"I'm well aware of that," I replied. "After all, I'm the one who's having this baby."
11111211111111111.title: Fallout

111112111111111111.content:
After Veronica, others found their voices. And they were a lot less circumspect about what they said. I lost count of how many times the word slut was spoken as I walked past.

Others, mostly boys, were more brazen. They would walk right up to me and invite me to show them my breasts, or kneel down with my mouth open, or things I don't even want to think about. If that's what boys are like, I thought, when I find out how I got pregnant, I'm telling the world and making men obsolete.

Now, sure, the school has a no-bullying policy, but, somehow, the teachers never seemed to hear what people were saying about me.

When I got home from school, I went straight to my room. I gave serious thought to staying there, in my room, until the baby was in college.

When I heard a knock on my door, I expected it to be Mom, so it was a bit of a surprise when I heard Pat's voice. "Are you okay, Cassie?"

"I haven't been okay for three and a half months," I replied.

"Can I come in?"

"I guess."

He came in and sat on the edge of my bed. "I got suspended," he said. "Some guys were talking smack about you, and, long story short, I'm in trouble for fighting."

I looked up. "What did Pop say?"

"He said I had a good reason. He can't do anything about the teacher being upset, but he and I are cool."

"You... you guys believe me, right?"

"I'm not sure what Pop thinks, but I figure, if you wanted to make up a story to explain how you got pregnant, you wouldn't have picked this one."
111112111111111111.title: Bullying

1111121111111111111.content:
Trish and Susan came in, and came straight to my room. "Heard what happened today," Trish said. "Figured you could use a little company."

"I've got a little company," I said, putting a hand on my belly. "That's kind of how this whole thing started. But I could definitely use some friends."

Trish and Susan came in and, once Pat got up, sat on either side of me. "Remember the sticks," Susan said. "We're together, so they'll have to try awfully hard if they want to break us."

Trish asked, "Everybody knows we're friends, right?"

"I hope so," I replied, "we eat together every day, unless I have a doctor's appointment."

"Right. So you know that's why when we tell you that... somebody from the school paper wants to talk to you. And they're reaching out to us to get to you."

"Somebody?"

"Okay, okay," Trish admitted, "it's my sister, Clarice. But it's true, she knows we're friends, and she came to me about maybe interviewing you."

There was a knock on the door frame, and a girl who could only have been Clarice poked her head around. "I followed you guys," she said. Then, to me, she said, "I know you're going through a lot right now with the baby, but I really think an interview could help you. I mean, by talking to me, you could get the story to everyone in the school at once. Once the editor is through with it, it'll be in everybody's inbox. What do you say?"

I looked at Trish, then Susan, then asked, "Can you give us a minute to talk about it?"

"Sure," Clarice said. "I'll be down the hall."

I gave Clarice five seconds to get out of earshot, then asked, "What do you guys think?"

"It's definitely easier than telling everyone individually," Susan said.

"And you'd have more control over the narrative," Trish added.

"But it's your decision," Susan said. "What do you want to do?"

I thought about it, then said, "Send her in."
1111121111111111111.title: Trish, Susan,... and Someone Else

11111211111111111111.content:
Clarice turned on her recorder. "Thanks for sitting down with me."

"You're welcome."

"Let's start with the facts," she said. "You are pregnant?"

"Three and a half months."

"And you've never had sex?"

"Never even came close."

"How do you account for your condition, then?"

"I don't," I replied. "I can't. I have no idea how this baby got here, but it's in here now."

"So, as for the rumors that you claim - "

"I don't claim anything," I said. "I was not visited by any heavenly messenger, and I was not asked if I would agree to bear a child. I woke up sick to my stomach, and the doctor said it was morning sickness. That was how I found out I was pregnant."

"If I may ask,... why didn't you, uh,... ?"

"Because it honestly never crossed my mind. Maybe part of it was thinking that whatever got me pregnant might just do it again. But another part was... curiosity. A baby under these circumstances, you kinda want to see how it turns out, you know?"

"Do you consider this baby to be a miracle?"

"I've never heard a mother call her baby anything else. So, in that sense, yes, it's a miracle."

"How would you like to see this baby treated?"

I giggled.

"Did I say something funny?"

"No, not like that. I just remembered a joke Pat told me two years ago:

"You see, one day, the Pope was visited by aliens. And they're having a very nice discussion, when the Pope asks them, 'Have you ever heard of a man named Jesus Christ?'

"And the alien leader says, 'Of course, He visits our planet twice a year.'

"'Twice a year? It's been over 2000 years, and we're still waiting for His Second Coming.'

"'Didn't He like your chocolate?'

"'Chocolate?'

"'Whenever He comes, we have always given Him the very best chocolates we make. Why, what did you do when He came?'"

Clarice and I both laughed.

"Thanks again," Clarice said. "This may not make the next edition, but I'm sure you'll read it soon."

"Goodbye," I said.

"Goodbye. I hope everything goes well, for you, and the baby."
11111211111111111111.title: The Interview

111112111111111111111.content:
"And how are we doing today?" Dr. Foster asked me, as Mom watched.

"Actually," I said, "I feel like I'm doing okay. My belly has caught up to my boobs, which is where I should be. And my friends say I have such a glow about me, they're seriously thinking that there's a higher power involved."

"A higher power, you say? And what do you call this higher power?"

"Well, frankly, I call it a deadbeat dad, because I've been left high and dry dealing with this baby. Seriously, if there is something... divine about this situation, the one responsible doesn't seem interested in being worshipped. Maybe this baby won't be so much about 'Look what I can do,' and more about 'Look what we can do.'"

"I see. Well, enough speculating, let's see how you're both actually doing." With that, the examination began.

When Dr. Foster was done, she said, "So far, everything seems to be checking out. You're right where you ought to be, which is unusual for a teen mother-to-be. Sometimes, at this point, I would order an amniocentesis, which is a test of the amniotic fluid. There is a slight risk of miscarriage, so I'll run it by you before I do anything."

At the mention of miscarriage, I wrapped my arm around my belly, as if to protect and reassure the baby. "Is it medically necessary?" Mom asked.

"Strictly speaking, it's not specifically called for. But it's something that would give us a handle on any possible birth defects. I'm confident in how you're doing, Cassie, but, since the identity of the father is up in the air, I'd like to touch all the bases. As I said, the risk is slight, and I don't believe you'll have any ill effects."

I certainly wanted to know if the baby was healthy. I nodded, and Mom said, "Alright. You can do the amnio."

Dr. Foster stuck a needle in my belly, and drew out some fluid. "The risk of miscarriage is chiefly if I accidentally hit the fetus with the needle, but it doesn't look like that's happened here. There may be some discomfort, so take it easy for the rest of the day. Now, the amnio will also tell us if you're having a boy or a girl, but some want to be surprised on the big day. Do you want to be surprised, or was finding out that you're pregnant surprise enough?"

"I don't mind waiting to see what it is."

"Alright then. We'll send you the test results later, and you're free to go."
111112111111111111111.title: Fourth Month Checkup

1111121111111111111111.content:
"There may be some discomfort," Dr. Foster said. To whoever's reading this, let me tell you: If your doctor says there may be some discomfort, interpret it like the captain of the Titanic saying they're stopping for ice. My belly was sore for the rest of the day. I was glad I was staying home: I could just imagine wedging my sore belly into a desk.

My interview finally made the school paper. Apparently, it took this long for the editor to decide enough people were talking about me and my baby to make it news. Trish and Susan called, and said they liked the joke at the end. They said it showed I wasn't taking it too seriously. Maybe more people would treat me like plain old Cassie Pennant again, just with a plus one until school was out.

I did the homework that was assigned that day, and decided to relax with a book. Before I realized what I was doing, I started reading the book aloud. I realized I was reading to the baby. I put the YA novel aside, and picked up my copy of Green Eggs and Ham. It was a bit more baby-friendly than the occasional F-bomb from my other books.

A few days later, Dr. Foster called to assure me that there was no sign of any birth defects in my baby. I was so glad to hear it, I hugged everybody I came in contact with, even Veronica Decker.
1111121111111111111111.title: A Day at Home

11111211111111111111112.content:
Later that day, I decided to take a walk, and found myself at a table in front of a coffee shop, where I ordered a caramel cappuccino and a bagel. I was enjoying my order when a shadow fell upon me. "Good afternoon, Cassie." softly, a male voice said. "Do you mind if I join you?"

I looked up to find a handsome man near my age I had never seen before. Sensing no danger, I silently nodded, and he sat down across from me. "Please tell me you are not going to try to open a conversation with a cheesy pick-up line." Calmly, I demanded. "I'm having enough trouble with another person in my life." I pushed back, patting my abdomen.

The man smiled, and I swore I could see a tear forming in his eye. I thought I had let him down easy, and guessed some men were just sensitive to rejection. Only the man surprised me by saying, "What I have to say is a bit stranger than a cheesy pick-up line." Calmly, he said. "You see, I'm from the future,... specifically, your future."

I've attracted a weirdo... Rolling my eyes, I thought.

I was about to stand up to walk away, but paused when the man said, "Who else would know you are working on a fantasy novel called Gaia?"

I slowly sat back down, surprised. "How did you learn about that...?" Whispering, I demanded. "Not even my parents know I'm working on that."

"My name is Brian Courtly." Softly, the man said. "I am a world-renowned inventor and quantum physicist... As I told you, I am from your future." he paused then added, "If you want more proof, there will be an accident across the street in five... four... three... two... one..."

I jumped as I heard a loud crash, and looked out to see that a car had run a red light and struck another car. Darkly curious, I turned back to Brian and asked, "What do you want with me...?"

Brian sighed. "Ten years from now, we will meet." Whispering, he said. "We will fall in love and... start a family." He motioned to my abdomen. "I am, or rather, will be the father of your unborn child."
11111211111111111111112.title: Reader's choice

choices: Videos of him and me together.
111112111111111111111122.content:
"I think you are insane." Frowning, I said. "I'm leaving now."

I was about to get up to leave when Brian held up a necklace. "Your biological father had this custom built for his little girl, to keep her safe." Serious, he said. "There is nothing else like it in the world."

I sighed, then turned, only to feel my heart skip a beat. Brian was holding the necklace my father had left me! It was a fantasy world necklace, showing a world very much different from Earth. It was what inspired my story, Gaia. "Where did you get that?!" Angry and surprised, I demanded.

I reached under my blouse and felt my heart skip a beat again. The necklace was there, the exact same necklace. Brian slowly nodded as I turned to him in shock. "As I said, I am from your future." Softly, he explained. "The baby you are carrying was sent back in time to have a chance to live, which is why there is no father in this time."

"This is unbelievable..." Tearing up, I whispered. "You are expecting me to believe a lot."

Brian nodded. "I know." Calmly, he said. "However, I brought one other piece of proof."

With that said, he produced....
111112111111111111111122.title: An insane truth.

1111121111111111111111221.content:
He pulled out an iPhone, but one unlike anything I had ever seen. It was bigger than the latest version Pop had bought for me just last month, and it opened up to reveal a keypad, as well as an extended screen. I watched curiously as he typed something onto the keyboard, then turned it so I could see the screen.

It was a video of me with him and the family, at the dinning room table during some Thanksgiving dinner. "I have an announcement to make..." I heard myself say on the screen. "Brian and I are getting married."

Cheers, hugs and kind words came immediately after, as I saw myself, or a version of myself, proudly showing off a large engagement ring. "When was this...? I asked.

"Twelve years from now, a year before you will discover you are pregnant." Serious, Brian replied. "If this does not convince you, I don't know what will."

I sighed, not knowing what to believe, then I remembered Pop telling me that he had a talent for knowing when people were being truthful or not and pulled out my cellphone.

Pop answered on the second ring. "Cassie...?"

"Pop,... I- I need you!" Tearfully, I said. "I found some- someone who thinks he- he knows why I'm pregnant..."

Pop was silent for only a moment before he replied. "Where are you?"
1111121111111111111111221.title: Videos of him and me together.

choices: The other side of the mirror.
111112111111111112.content:
It was a long day at school for me. The rumors and speculation were endless, from rape to a one night stand with a stranger to falling in love with one of the teachers. I denied them all, but it did not stop endless questions and accusations from students and staff alike. I went straight upstairs to my room in tears upon coming home, and splashed water in my face at the sink in my on suite.

With the door open, Pat cautiously walked up behind me and placed a comforting hand onto my arm. "Are you going to be okay, sis...?" Worried, he asked.

"I-I don't know, Pat." Tearfully, I replied. "I swear I have not had sex with anyone, it just doesn't make any sense..."

Pat sighed, not knowing what to say, and turned to the mirror before he gripped my arm tightly, breathing in a way that suggested fear. "C-Cassie..." Fearful, he said.

I turned to him, concerned, and became more worried as Pat was literally beginning to hyperventilate. "What? what is it?"

"Why does my reflection have long hair...?" Backing away, Pat demanded.

I did not know whether to scold Pat for trying to be funny or be worried for his mental state, but I turned to the mirror and nearly screamed. Pat's reflection not only had long hair, but two small orbs on his chest! "What the hell...?!"

Then, Pat's reflection gave a shy wave, and, in an echoing voice, said, "Hi, sis..."

Both Pat and I screamed at the top of our lungs.
111112111111111112.title: Mirror, Mirror

1111121111111111122.content:
Almost instantly, Mom came running, and nearly screamed herself, seeing Pat with long hair in his reflection. "What the..." was all that would come out.

"We do not have a lot of time, so I ask that you please listen." Serious, my reflection said. "You and I have the same problem, Cassie..."

"You mean we are both pregnant but never had sex?" Wincing, I asked.

My reflection shook her head. "I know how, and I am pregnant, but a device on my end is causing you to experience my pregnancy."

"What do you mean?" Taken aback, I demanded.

"You are not pregnant." Serious, my reflection said. "However, you might become pregnant if it turns out I'm having twins."

"I am so lost right now." Tearing up, I said.

"It's simple, actually." Stepping up to the mirror, Mom's reflection said. "We are in a parallel universe, where everything except for a few things are identical." she motioned to Pat's reflection. "Patricia, for example."

"How is that making her experience your pregnancy?" Worried, Mom demanded.

"There is a device that keeps worlds from spilling into each other." Serious, Mom's reflection replied. "The one on our side was damaged, and a breach opened."

"Fortunately, it is isolated." Sighing, my reflection said. "Unfortunately..."

"...It's focused on us." Wincing, I finished.

"Have your doctor run a false positive test." Calmly, Mom's reflection said. "It will show that your daughter is not pregnant, though her body thinks she is."

"Is that even possible?" Worried, Mom asked.

"It's rare but, yes, possible." Serious, Mom's reflection replied.

"We are trying to repair the device, so you will not be affected by this." Serious, my reflection said. "However, if we can't get it fixed before we get too far along..." She winced. "You may be in this for the full ride."

"We will try to contact you later with an update, but right now, we are out of time." Calmly, Mom's reflection said. "Until then..."

The mirror then changed, showing only our true reflections. For a moment, we all stared at the mirror in shock, just before I fainted.
1111121111111111122.title: Mom came running.

choices: Girl Pat standing next to me!
11111211111111111222.content:
I came around moments later to see Pop looking over me. "A bit of a shock, isn't it... seeing another you on the other side of the mirror?" Calmly, he asked. "Why do you think I call this the gate house?"

"You- You knew...?" Surprised, I demanded.

"I knew of the other universe, and that this house is the gate between the two worlds." Serious, Pop replied. "I didn't know that there was a breach, until my counterpart called me with the key piece to your mystery."

Pop helped me up to my feet and led us all to the basement, where he picked up the receiver to an old fashioned telephone. It was hooked up to what looked like a half dismantled television, that was hooked up to a number of odd pieces of equipment. "What is all of this...?" Taken aback, I asked.

I jumped as an image of Pop appeared on the screen. He looked exactly like Pop , only he had pierced ears. "This is a gate-phone." Calmly, Alt-Pop said. He chuckled, noticing where I was staring. "When a man lives in a house full of girls, he is going to get the girl treatment to some extent."

A giggle escaped my lips, the ice had been broken. "Can you tell me why your Cassie and I am going through this?"

"My Cassie fell in love with Kevin Stewart." Calmly, alt pop explained. "In the heat of passion, they made love about three and a half months ago..."

I gasped at that. "Kevin Stewart asked me out about then..." I sighed. "Only I was too shy at the time..."

"That's the key." Serious, Alt-Pop said. "Both of you had Kevin Stewart on the mind, thinking of possibly growing up together and raising a family." He sighed. "Tell me, on that day, did you place your hand onto the mirror?"

"I- I did..." Almost whispering, I said. "The- The mirror cracked..."

"The same happened on this end." Frowning, Alt-Pop said. "You and my daughter are linked between worlds."

"Any ideas of how we fix this?" Serious, Pop asked.

"We need to replace the mirror on both sides." Calmly, Alt-Pop replied. "However, it brings the same risk you and I took when wiring the device to the house."

"The entire house is the device?" Startled, I asked.

Pop nodded. "The device wasn't built in the age of high tech, Cassie." Serious, he explained. "My counterpart and I built our house around it in our worlds, on what was the edge of town."

"What are the risks?" Worried, Pat asked.

"Until the gate stabilizes, anything could happen." Serious, Alt-Pop said. "From one of our daughters ending up in the other world, to them or Pat swapping places, or our worlds becoming more alike."

"What do you mean more alike?' Wincing, I asked.

Alt-Popop gave a rueful smile. "Well, Pat in my world is a girl..."

Pat winced. "Ew..."

"We have no choice." Sighing, Pop said. "I will fetch a new mirror from the attic, and we will replace them straightaway."

Alt-Pop nodded. "I will meet you at the mirror."

Minutes later, I stood behind Pop in my bedroom en suite, as he carefully removed the mirror and put up a new one in the exact same place. Looking in the mirror as it was being installed, I saw Alt-Pop carefully matching all of Pop's moves. Within moments, the mirror was up.

When Pop turned around, though, I screamed, as I found...
11111211111111111222.title: Pop's reaction.

111112111111111112223.content:
When Pop turned around, though, I screamed, as I found girl Pat standing next to me, wearing a simple white dress and flats. Pat screamed seeing his, or rather, her reflection in the mirror! That was when I realized my brother had become my sister. "Why am I a girl?!"

Pop could only shake his head. "I was afraid of this." Softly, he said. "I should have just replaced the mirror straightaway. Now we have changes in our reality."

"This- This will fix itself... right?" Hopeful, I asked. "Pat and i will be back to normal once the gate stabilizes..."

Pop sighed. "I'm afraid that the link between you and Alt-Cassie will remain intact until her baby is born." softly, he said. "However, I agree that a false positive test will prove you are not pregnant... in theory."

"What do you mean?" Worried, I asked.

"Well, if Alt-Cassie is having twins, one of them will likely be born through you." Serious, Pop explained. "If she is not, then you will have a false pregnancy, which is simply your uterus only being filled with fluids."

"What about me..." Tearfully, Pat demanded. "I- I don't want to be a girl..."

"I'm sorry, Pat... I simply do not know if this will fix itself or not." Sadly, he replied. "We won't know until the baby is born."

"How do you know even that?" Worried, I asked.

"Because I was a boy when this happened the first time." To our shock, Mom said. "Any changes that last beyond six months are permanent."

This was too much for Pat to bear...
111112111111111112223.title: Pat becomes Patricia.

1111121111111111122232.content:
I sighed seeing Pat crumble to the floor, unconscious. "Poor kid..." Wincing, I muttered.

"Everyone but the four of us will see her as always being Patricia." Softly, Mom warned. "They will think she's crazy if she insists otherwise... I went through it."

I did not know what to think as Pop took Pat into his arms and carried her to her bedroom across from my own. It was no longer the bedroom I remembered. The walls were a pastel pink with a light blue carpet. She had a canopy bed with princess sheets, a white dresser, and a vanity. Like me, she had an en suite. On the walls were posters of ballet dancers and unicorns. "It looks like, in this reality, Pat is rather feminine."

"Don't push anything until she gets more comfortable in her new role." Firmly, Pop said. "It's going to be hard enough to deal with being a girl, let alone face her friends back at school."

"At least it's the weekend." Sighing, Mom said. "We have some time to help Pat adjust a little, before she goes out into the world."

"I'm more worried about inspecting the machine." Serious, Pop said. "There may be other problems."

"Are you saying that there might be more breaches?" Worried, I asked.

Pop nodded. "I was just a kid when this happened, a prodigy, but still a kid." Serious, he explained. "My brotherhood and I built the machine, then built the house around it."

"Are there any members left?" Curious, I asked.

"Your mother was a member before she became a girl." Ruefully, Pop replied. "Max Dietrich was a member as well." He sighed. "I may have to call them together and see if there were any other changes to our small city..."
1111121111111111122232.title: She fainted.

choices: Pat is not the only one who changed.
11111211111111111222321.content:
One telephone call later, the sitting room was filled with men from all walks of life, from all over the city. Mom made a pot of tea and coffee before ordering pizza. After everyone was seated, a tall, slender man began the conversation. "It's been twenty years since the gates of hell had been closed, Pop." In an accusing tone, he said. "What did you do to anger the..."

"Don't even start with me, Toby White." His eyes narrowing, Pop warned. "None of you were willing to accept the heavy responsibility of maintaining the device, it fell squarely upon my wife and me... your part of the contract is seriously overdue..."

A tall and muscular man in an expensive-looking business suit sighed. "That's just his way of dealing with stress, Pop." Calmly, he said. "Since the year of Hell, The Lord's will is all he really knows." He turned to me. "I am Max Dietrich, the owner and operator of the local bank... we were all very different twenty years ago."

A short, well-built man nodded. "Indeed... I am Jason Darling, owner of Darling Cosmetics. Max and I had the wealth to purchase all we needed for the device which Pop and Tom designed."

A tall, slender man in designer clothes sighed. "I'm Tom Stewart." Calmly, he said. He motioned to a man who looked identical to himself. "My twin brother, Christopher, and I helped Pop design the device, but he was the one who built it."

"I'm Tim Stone, chief of police." Calmly, a tall, muscular man said. "There has not been any obvious signs that the gates had reopened, so the question at hand is, how bad is it?"

Pop sighed. "My daughter's counterpart got pregnant through her boyfriend, and now she and my daughter are linked."

A short, slender man shook his head. "A breach..." Softly, he said. He turned to me. "I am Dr. John Rafferty, the head physician of the hospital. I'll order a false positive test for you first thing in the morning."

"I appreciate that." Managing a smile, I said.

Then Mom walked in and the last two stood up and called out, "Hey, Slugger!"

Mom blushed slightly. "My nickname when I was a boy." Softly, she explained. "This is Tim Stone and Scott West. They are the owners of the local gym."

Both men were tall and muscular in average clothes who nodded and smiled politely. "We were all inseparable when we were kids." kindly, Tim said. "We still are, in a way."

"Yes but we need to move fast." Turning serious, Scott said. "There have been minor changes all over town, and we need to find all the breaches before it gets worse."

"Were there any other changes here?" Worried, Toby asked.

Pop sighed as Pat walked into the room.
11111211111111111222321.title: Pop calls in the brotherhood.

11111211111111112.content:
Rosemary looked at me for a moment, then laughed. "Good one, Cassie." wiping a tear away, she said. "Only I doubt you are the 'Virgin Mary' of the modern world."

I gave a nervous laugh, hoping Rosemary would leave it at that, but no such luck as she repeated her question, "Who's the lucky guy?"

"A Galahad." Smiling, Mom calmly interjected. "Quite the story behind it, I must say."

I blushed profusely at mom's words. "What are you doing...?" Whispering, I demanded.

Rosemary's eyes widened, a curious smile touching the corners of her mouth. I just knew she was mentally drooling to learn more of Mom's story. "Do tell..."

Mom's smile grew as she shook a single finger. "Tut, tut..." Teasing, she said. "You know better than that, Miss Johnson. The most juicy stories only come out in bits and pieces, and that was the only bit you are getting today."

Rosemary pouted. "You're horrible, Mrs. Pennant." Whining, she complained.

Mom turned serious. "If you want the whole story, do not be spreading rumors, like you did with the last girl." Firmly, she warned. "It backfired on you, almost to the point of losing all hopes of getting into the college of your choice."

Rosemary sighed. "I am painfully aware of that..." softly, she said. With that, she walked off.

After she was gone, I turned to Mom, more than a little annoyed. "Care to tell me who this faceless Galahad is, mom?"

Mom smiled. "The same one who got your great-grandmother pregnant." Calmly, she said. "A faceless, nameless hero you only saw once, and never learned his name." She touched my cheek. "Being rescued can lead a person from one thing to another and, before you know it, something happens."

"Only what was I rescued from?" Nervous, I asked.

Mom again turned serious. "Cassie, you still have two days you can't account for, when you went out camping on your own four weeks ago, off of Old Town Road." Softly, she said. "The same isolated campground your great-grandmother went to..."
11111211111111112.title: A nameless Galahad.

11112.content:
We weren't home for long before Mom turned to me and asked, "What's his name?"

"Mom, I swear to God, I've never done anything like that."

"How long do you intend to stick to that story?"

"It's the truth! Look, I always come straight home from school, don't I? And I don't date or go to parties, do I? You've met my friends, how many of them are guys? So where and when would I have the opportunity to get knocked up?"

Mom said nothing.

"Out of all the possible lies I could tell to explain this," I asked, "why would I ever pick that one?"

"Cassie," Mom finally said, "you're scaring me."

"You think you're scared? Try it from this end."

Tears in her eyes, Mom hugged me. I hugged back, doing some crying of my own. "How in the world could this have happened?" she asked.

"I wish I knew."

"What do we tell your stepfather? What will we tell everyone?"

My stomach grumbled. "What's for lunch?"

Mom laughed. "Let's see what we've got."
11112.title: Mom Doubts Me

choices: I take a pregnancy test on my own.
111121.content:
While eating lunch, which was simply a few sandwiches and milk, my stepdad walked in, looking tired but happy from work. He was a first shift factory worker, so he was always home around lunch time. To be clear, he did not like me calling him Dad, as he felt it would be disrespectful to my biological father, who passed some time ago. He insisted I call him 'Pop'. "Anything exciting happen today?" Calmly, he asked.

"You could say that." wincing, Mom said.

I gulped. "Pop... Dr. Foster said I'm pregnant."

Pop paused, a look of surprise on his face, before his slight smile fell. I feared he was going to go through the roof with me, but, instead, he scoffed. "What possessed you to go to her?" Ice in his voice, he demanded. "That woman is a certified quack."

"She came highly recommended." Serious, Mom said.

"She also told me I had a sprain when I had really broken my ankle." Also serious, Pop countered.

"So I'm likely not pregnant?" Hopefully, I asked.

"I didn't say that." To my disappointment, Pop said. "I just said Dr. Foster is a quack and you need to get a second opinion." He placed a gentle hand onto my shoulder. "It will not be you I will be angry with if you do turn out to be pregnant."

I teared up. "Pop..."

"All I am saying is you need to get a second opinion." Serious, Pop said. "It's too early for any of us to jump to conclusions."

With that said, he quietly walked to the counter and began to make a sandwich of his own.
111121.title: Step dad doubts for another reason.

1111211.content:
We went to the hospital to see a Dr. Hughes. Dr. Hughes was a woman doctor, which Mom and I always preferred, and she wasn't Dr. Foster, which made Pop happy. This time, Pop went with us.

Dr. Hughes came into the exam room. "What brings you here today?"

"I went to a different doctor," I explained, "who said I was pregnant. I came for a second opinion."

"Well, let's do some tests, and see what we can see."

You guessed it: more blood work, and another urine sample. Mom went along with me, just in case I felt woozy.

When I got back to the exam room, Dr. Hughes said, "Cassie, why don't you lie down on the table, and we'll check you out?"

I did, and Dr. Hughes began feeling my lower belly.

When she was done with that, a nurse brought in my test results. "You're pregnant, Cassie. About 6-8 weeks along, I'd say." She looked at Dr. Foster's notes. "Everything seems to be in order. I'm not sure why you wanted a second opinion."

"Dr . Hughes," I said, "I know how crazy this sounds, but I shouldn't be pregnant. You see, I've never been with a boy."

Pop's jaw dropped. It was the first time he'd heard that little detail.

"It doesn't sound quite as crazy as you think, Cassie."

"What are you saying, Doctor?" Mom asked.

"I can't give you too much information," Dr. Hughes said. "Doctor-patient confidentiality, you understand." She took a deep breath. "There's something my father used to say: 'Once is happenstance, twice is coincidence, but the third time makes a pattern.'" She looked me straight in the eye. "Cassie, you're the third patient to come in with an unexplained pregnancy."
1111211.title: getting a second opinion.

11112111.content:
I didn't think anything could shake me up more than hearing I was pregnant. But then, who could possibly imagine hearing there were others in the same boat? It was enough to make me question everything I'd learned in school.

On the way home, Mom asked Pop to stop at a store. She came out with a box of ginger snaps. "I want you to have two or three in the morning when you get up," she said. "Let's see if they help your morning sickness."

It was all becoming so real. Now I had to treat morning sickness. Soon, I'd be dealing with bigger clothes. Kicking. Breathing classes. Labor pains.

These were the things I thought about as we sat together on the couch.

Finally, Pat came home from school, accompanied by my best friend, Trish Regan. "Hi, Cassie," she said. "I got your homework for you."

"Thanks, Trish," I said, not really comprehending what homework could possibly be.

"So," Pat asked, "what did the doctor say? Feeling better?"

"I'm going to have a baby." It just popped out.

Trish fell on her knees and put a hand on my knee, almost as shaken as I was.

"A baby?" Pat asked. "Who's the lucky guy?"

"There isn't one."

"Huh?"

"There's no guy. I shouldn't be pregnant, but I am. And I'm not the only one. Try to believe me."

Trish was still wrapping her head around my bombshells, but Pat said, "Jimmy."

"What?" Mom asked.

"My best friend, Jimmy Tucker. His sister is pregnant, and she said almost the same thing."

So now I had independent confirmation of what Dr. Hughes had said. Jimmy Tucker's sister was a pregnant virgin, too.
11112111.title: Back at Home

111121111.content:
"Pat," I asked, "do you have Jimmy's number?"

"Yeah, why?"

"I want to talk to his sister."

Pat placed the call himself. "Hey, Jimmy. Can you put Lauren on? My sister wants to talk to her."

He handed me the phone, and I heard what must have been Jimmy calling her to the phone.

The voice on the other end was definitely not happy. "Listen, you little shit," she said, "I don't know who you are, but I want you to go find a better - "

"My name's Cassie Pennant. It's happening to me, too."

That got her attention. "What did you say?"

"I'm a pregnant virgin, too. And there's at least one more in this city, but I don't know where she is."

"How... how did you find out?"

"Dr. Hughes told me I was the third to come in saying I couldn't possibly be pregnant, only to be told I was. Then, Pat mentioned you when I told him."

"I'm sorry I yelled at you. Jimmy's been spreading it all over school, and you're the first one who didn't make a prank call."

"Can't say I blame you."

"What do you think I should do? About this... thing."

"Well, we still don't know why or how it happened, so there's no guarantee any attempt to end this would even work."

"I hadn't thought of that. God, this is all so scary."

"Tell me about it. Wanna come over to my place and hang out?"

"How about this weekend?"

So that was how our solidarity began.
111121111.title: Making a Call

choices: Pat remembers seeing a ball of light.
I remember a storm that night.
1111211111.content:
The last two days before the weekend were rough. While Pat was kind enough not to tell anyone about my issue, Jimmy was not as restrained. I got questions and comments from several people, including teachers, who voiced their concerns. Fortunately, the teachers had heard of the two other cases, but they were worried if anyone, the female teachers included, could be next to find themselves pregnant. It was certainly a startling thought, but I took some comfort in knowing that the third girl was a student somewhere in my school.

"There has to be a connection." Walking home that Friday, I muttered. "Something the three of us have in common that separates us from the others."

"That makes sense." softly, Pat said, walking with me. "Only what could it be?"

Upon returning home, I found Lauren Tucker waiting for me in the sitting room, where Mom had set up a tray of hot tea and some snacks. "Hurry and change clothes." Serious, Mom said. "We have a lot to talk about, dear."

I nodded and made quick work to change into a pair of sweats and a clean blouse before coming down, where Mom began the conversation. "There has to be something that links all three cases together." Calmly, she said. "As we have not found the third girl yet, we need to discuss everything we had done, and where we had gone, in the past few months."

"Well, I was in a hotel for one night while going on vacation with my family." After a thought, Lauren said. "It was about four months ago, and we only stayed one night."

My eyes widened at that, as my family had stopped for the night at a hotel during a vacation about four months back. "What was the name of the hotel?" Almost whispering, I asked.

"It was Star something...." Wincing, Lauren said. "I really don't remember."

"Stardust hotel." Surprising us, Mom said. "I remember it only because I had to deal with that blasted neon light flashing into our bedroom window all night."

"I better make a call to confirm it." Shaken, Lauren said.

She called her mother on the phone while I waited anxiously. I did not have to wait long, as her face turned pale before she ended the call. "It was the Stardust hotel, just on the state border off of Highway 55." Softly, she said.

Mom nodded. "That's the place." Calmly, she said. "Now, is there anything any of you can remember about that night, that we may use to further connect the dots?"
1111211111.title: A clue is found.

11112111111.content:
"I saw... "

The three of us turned. Pat had come into the room.

"I saw this weird ball of light. Like ball lightning, but smaller."

"What did it do?" Mom asked.

"It flew around above us for a bit, then it went through the wall."

"I thought it was just a dream." We were all startled when I spoke, even me.

"Tell us, Cassie," Mom said.

"I must have been half awake, half asleep. I saw that light. And I felt this... tingly feeling, all over my body."

"Mom," Pat asked, "do you think that light had something to do with this?"

"How could it?" Lauren asked. "That was four months ago, and we haven't been pregnant for half that long."

"Maybe it was a scout," Mom replied. "It wasn't there to impregnate, just to examine us, see who was right."

"And then," I added, "when they were ready... "

Mom nodded.

We all pondered this.

"Aliens?" Lauren asked. "But... why this?"

"Maybe they're curious," Pat said. "I mean, why subject us to probes and abductions, when they can learn so much more about us... by becoming us?"

I got up and hugged Pat. "Thank you."

"For what?"

"You gave us the missing piece to the puzzle. We would have gotten nowhere if you hadn't spoken up. And, even if it's not... even if it's something else entirely, we're closer to understanding this than we were when we all sat down together."
11112111111.title: Pat remembers seeing a ball of light.

111121111111.content:
"I'm calling the hotel." After a thought, Mom said. "Perhaps the workers there noticed something amiss that day as well. I think i still have their business card in my memoir."

"Good thought." Surprised, Lauren said. "I'll call Jimmy, and see if he noticed anything strange while staying there, too."

I waited anxiously as Lauren called her little brother, and Mom soon after called the Stardust hotel, in a quest to find answers. I did not have long to wait, as Lauren turned to me, her face pale. "Jimmy remembers seeing the same bright ball of light that night." Whispering, she said. "He told me it vanished through the wall... to where I was sleeping."

As Dr. Hughes had said, Once is happenstance, twice is coincidence, but the third time makes a pattern. We had all seen the same bright ball of light, it was a pattern. Only was it really aliens that caused this? If so, why teenagers? My thoughts were interrupted by Mom letting out a breathless sigh. "Can you please bring her to the phone?" Pleading, she said. "She is not the only one going through this... Yes, I'll hold."

She turned to us. "The manager of the hotel said there is a 'crazy' teenage girl there, who thinks she was impregnated at the hotel while she slept."

Lauren and I exchanged startled looks before Mom spoke again into the phone. "Hello, miss... Sarah... Yes, this is Beth Pennant calling. You are not crazy. My daughter and her friend are also having a virgin pregnancy."

Mom pressed a button placing the call on speaker phone, and we heard a young girl crying on the other end. "Dr. Hughes said there was another case like mine when I went to her." Relief in her voice, she said. "I took the bus to the Stardust hotel, because its the only place I remember sleeping alone."

"You took the bus there alone?" Concerned, Mom asked.

Sarah cried harder. "I-I've been kicked out of my house because of this nightmare!" distraught, she explained. "Please... help me!"

"The hotel is about a forty five minute drive from here." Serious, Mom said. "Can you find a safe place to sit tight until I get there?"

"I- I think so." Crying, Sarah said.

Mom nodded. "Good, I'm on my way to pick you up now."

"Please hurry." Still crying, Sarah said. "I'm really scared."

Upon ending the call, Mom turned to Lauren. "Call your parents and ask them if you can stay the night here." Serious, she said. "I'm going to pick up that girl and bring her here."

Lauren nodded and turned to her phone once more, while I spotted Pop entering the room. "Well, did you learn anything?" Curious, he asked.

"We are piecing it together, honey." Quickly, Mom said. "We located the third girl who was effected by this, and I am off to pick her up." she paused. "Her parents kicked her out of the house, she's homeless."

Pop frowned. "Not exactly proper parenting, is it, now?"

"No, it's not." Softly, Mom said. "I'll be back as quick as I can."

With that, Mom was off as Lauren got off the phone. "My mom said I can stay over, and to keep her informed of what we manage to piece together."

Pop nodded. "In the meantime, I suggest you two keep talking." Serious, he said. "Where you find one clue, others will follow."
111121111111.title: Finding the Third Girl

1111211111111.content:
About an hour and a half after she left, Mom returned with a girl our age, whose red, puffy eyes indicated she'd been crying for days. "Sarah," Mom said, "this is my daughter, Cassie, and this is Lauren Tucker. Girls, this is Sarah White."

We both got up to shake her hand. "Welcome to the Sisterhood," Lauren said.

"'Sisterhood'?" I asked.

"When we found out I wasn't the only one, my mom jokingly called us the Sisterhood of the Maternity Pants. It kinda stuck."

Mom made a fresh pot of tea and gave Sarah a cup. "We've put together one or two things in this mystery," she said. "Why don't you tell us what all you know, Sarah?"

Sarah took a sip. "Our tour group was coming back from Ark Encounter, and decided to spend the night at the Stardust. It was the first time I had ever had a hotel room to myself. I don't remember anything unusual about that night, but it's the only thing that was different. I thought maybe they knew something, but they just thought I was crazy."

She had a cookie. "When I told my parents I was pregnant, they insisted I tell them who the boy was. The more I told them I hadn't done anything like that, the more they threatened me for adding blasphemy to my sins. Finally, they packed my suitcases and told me to get out and stay out until I was prepared to admit the truth."

As we heard this, Mom put her arm around me. I knew she was thinking of how she had doubted me at first.

"Something did happen at the Stardust that night," Mom said. "We've got reports of a strange ball of light that was there that night." Turning to me and Lauren, she said, "You've been talking it over while I was out, girls. What else have you figured out?"

"We didn't have any 'Eureka' moment," I replied, "but we did find more commonalities than the Stardust. We're both shy, we don't have a lot of friends, and we aren't sexually active."

"That goes for me, too," Sarah said. "What is this?"

"We aren't completely sure," Mom answered. "But I think we can agree that you girls were targeted. This was deliberate."
1111211111111.title: Mom returns with Sarah.

11112111111111.content:
"That actually speaks volumes, girls." Entering the room, Pop said. He turned to Sarah, who seemed startled. "My name is Don Pennant, Beth's husband, but I prefer to be called Pop."

"Why do you think our similarities speak volumes?" Curious, I asked.

"A shy girl with very few friends is less likely to spread word of anything unusual, especially an unusual pregnancy, to too many people." Serious, Pop said. "Also, if word were to get out, very few would investigate, as the girl is already a social outcast."

"Thanks, Pop..." Uncomfortable, I said.

"Hear me out." firmly, Pop said. "Whoever is responsible for this did not want it to get out to a lot of people, hence, you three were targeted." His face then turned dark. "This leads to another disturbing conclusion."

Mom gasped, realizing what Pop was saying. "You three had been watched for a while."

Pop nodded. "To have all those similarities is not a coincidence, its a pattern." Serious, he said. "To prove this a valuable clue, I say we find out what brought us to the Stardust hotel on that same night four months ago."

Lauren, Sarah, and I all blurted out in unison... "A flat tire."

It was like a sequence in a dream. We all turned to each other, the color draining from our faces, as yet another similarity was discovered. Mom and Pop turned to each other with worried expressions on their faces. "Our tire was hit by something, but we could not figure out what." Softly, pop said. "I never saw anything like it, the tire looked as if it had been hit with something extremely hot."

Again, faces turned pale as Sarah nodded. "Same here."

Lauren nodded as well. "Likewise..."

"We were taking the freeway home when it happened." shaken, Mom said. "We limped our car off the freeway and found the hotel next door to a gas station."

"We were taking the back roads when it happened." Softly, Sarah said. "We spotted the hotel across the street from us when the tire blew."

"We had just got off the freeway to find a gas station when it happened." Pale, Lauren added. "We found the hotel right next door to one."

"That strengthens the theory." Serious, Pop said. "Someone wanted us at that hotel that night and made certain we would stay the night there."

"The only question is who?" Wincing, Pat said.

Pop frowned. "It's time we all had a word with that hotel manager."
11112111111111.title: We were targeted.

111121111111112.content:
"Do you really think they'll admit being part of this, Mr. Pennant?" Sarah asked.

"Not if I ask like that," Pop replied. "If I go in cold with a crazy-sounding story like that, they'll just treat me like a lunatic, and that would be as far as we'd ever get. And I told you, call me Pop." He began to dial. "I'm going to start with cold, hard facts, and paint him into a corner."

He began to address the manager. "How are you, sir? I have to tell you, I'm a little surprised that you're still in business, considering what happened four months ago. What do I mean? Tell you what, I'll tell you what I know, and, when I'm done, you can tell me what you know. Deal?

"Okay, we'll start with my family. Four people walk in, desperate for a place to stay while their car needs repair. And what do you do? You offer them a deal they wouldn't turn down if their car was in working order: You put their kids each in rooms of their own, at no extra charge.

"But we're not done. That same night, another family comes in. They, too, need a place to stay until the car gets fixed. And you cut them the exact same deal, don't you? Their kids get their own rooms, no extra charge.

"And we're still not done. A tour bus - a whole tour bus, for Pete's sake - comes in, and they all need a place to stay until the bus can be fixed. And, once again, all those kids get their own rooms, free of charge.

"So you can see why I thought you must have closed down, right? All those free rooms. You had to go belly-up. Unless... Unless somebody else covered all those rooms. Somebody who wanted certain kids to be isolated.

"Okay, now it's your turn." Pop listened, nodding here and there, until he finally said, "Thank you, sir, I appreciate your time."

As he hung up, he said to us, "One more piece of the puzzle."
111121111111112.title: Pop calls the hotel.

1111211111111121.content:
"What did you learn?" Anxious, Mom asked. "Anything useful?"

Pop nodded. "The Stardust Hotel was still under construction four months ago." To our surprise, he explained. "The manager and owner were shocked to find a number of guests checked in before it had officially opened, and ran an investigation."

"What did they find?" Wincing, I asked.

"Someone had opened the hotel before it was ready and ran it for two nights." Darkly, Pop said. "I'm guessing whoever did this did not intend for those books to be found, but they were."

"So the hotel was a trap?" Gulping, Lauren asked.

Pop gave a solemn nod. "No trace of anyone ever being at the hotel was found, except for the log book records which we all signed." Serious, he said. "In a way, my phone call helped them solve a mystery that had been plaguing them as well."

"You mean the log books?" Curious, Sarah asked.

"Not only that." Frowning, Pop said. "But also a large sum of money in a safe that was supposed to still be empty until the grand opening."

"Then the hotel was paid for the use of the rooms, even though there was no trace left that we were ever there." Worried, I said. "That raises more questions."

"Indeed it does." Firmly, Pop said. "Only the hotel manager said one other thing, that really has me bothered..."

"What?" Worried, Pat asked.

Pop sighed. "He said that when the construction workers returned, they found that the hotel was finished, ready to open, but that's not the weirdest part. Sarah, Lauren and Cassie's names were circled, with a note that stated..."
1111211111111121.title: What Pop Learned

11112111111111211.content:
"... Compatible Subject."

"Compatible?" Sarah gulped. "With what?"

"I'd say with whatever did this to us," I answered.

Pat began whistling the theme from The X Files, until glares from half the room persuaded him to stop.

"I think we've done enough investigating for one night," Mom said. "I'll order pizza." Turning to us, she asked, "Will two large Cheese Lovers' be enough for you?"

It was.

*************************************************


We dug out Pat's and my sleeping bags from our last camping trip, and laid them on the floor of my room. I loaned Lauren a sleep shirt, while Sarah had a nightgown that was apparently designed by someone who was terrified of ever seeing more of a woman than her head and hands.

We decided to talk about ourselves, since none of us knew each other before today. "Yeah, Mom's been encouraging me to make more friends for years," I said.

"Mine, too," Lauren said.

"My mom was more about converting people," Sarah said. "She didn't care how many friends I had, just as long as they were the right friends." She looked around. "This is the longest I've talked to anybody outside my family without asking if they'd accepted Jesus."

"You don't seem bothered by that."

"I've been asking questions, even before this happened. I think... I think God wants us to be good to each other. Memorizing a book is fine, but God is in each of us, so the way we treat each other is the way we're treating God. And how much do I really need to tell God about God?"

We talked for several hours, until Mom came and said to us, "You know, young ladies in your condition need their sleep."
11112111111111211.title: compatible subject.

111121111111112111.content:
I was the first to wake up, feeling nauseous. I stumbled to the bathroom and proceeded to throw up into the toilet. After I had washed myself off, it was Lauren's turn to run for the toilet, followed by Sarah, who threw up in the toilet while Lauren was cleaning herself up. It was fortunate that my bed room had an en suite; otherwise, we would have been competing for the bathroom with Pat.

"At least we're not going through this alone." Softly, I said.

Lauren and Sarah nodded in agreement before a soft knock came to the door and Mom peered in. "Good morning, girls." Calmly, she said. "Please get dressed, breakfast is ready." she paused then added, "Also, try to be a little patient with Pat."

"Why, what happened?" Curious, I asked.

Mom smiled. "Pop and I believe he's going through the early stages of Couvade syndrome." Bemused, she replied. "It started late last night."

"Couvade syndrome?" Worried, Sarah asked. "Is that bad?"

Lauren giggled. "It's also called a sympathetic pregnancy." Smiling, she explained. "A condition in which a partner or close relative - in this case, Pat - experiences some of the same symptoms and behavior as an expectant mother."

Mom nodded. "The poor boy was throwing up half the morning, and his belly is a bit swollen." Calmly, she said. "I always knew you and he were very close, but I didn't expect this."

Lauren shook her head. "I wish my brother Jimmy could experience it." Softly, she muttered. "He could use to be knocked down a peg or two."

After getting dressed, we all came down to the dinning room to find Pat nibbling on dry cold cereal and ginger snaps with a look of misery on his face. I was tempted to say something, only Mom whispered to us, "Pat never once teased any of you for your condition, so don't get any ideas of teasing him."
