We all nodded and took a seat at the table, where I placed a gentle hand onto Pat's shoulder. "Mom told us you're not feeling well." Softly, I said. "Are you okay?"

"I'm not sure..." Tearfully, Pat replied. "I just feel weird."

"I'll get you something from the pharmacy to help you feel better." Calmly, Mom said. "In the meantime, you are going back to bed after breakfast. Be thankful its Saturday."

By the time we began to eat, Pat said he was done, and Mom walked him back to his bedroom. "Poor kid." Wincing, Lauren said. "At least he's not really pregnant."

"I'd be worried if he were." Serious, I countered. "This is all weird enough as it is." I sighed. "Maybe I should give Trish and Susan a call."

"Who?" Curious, Lauren asked.

"Trish Regan and Susan Porter, my two best friends from school." Softly, I said. "The only two friends I have, besides you two."

Lauren's eyes widened in surprise. "They're friends with Emily Masters and Amy Smith, my two best friends from school." Softly, she said. "What a coincidence."

"Two is a coincidence but three is a pattern." Shaken, Sarah said. "Emily and Amy are friends with Bree West and Fae Frost, my two closest friends..."

I turned pale, realizing that we had discovered another connection. "Do you think they were watched and considered too?" Worried, I asked.

Sarah shuddered. "I probably should have said this before but..." She winced. "Trish, Susan, Emily, Amy, Bree and Fae were on that tour bus with me that night at the Stardust hotel." She walked over to her purse and produced a photo. "This is all of us, posing for a picture in front of the hotel, the only clue I had to go on when..."

"We get the idea." Softly, Lauren said.

I looked at the photo over Sarah's shoulder and gasped. "Wait a minute!" Suddenly, I yelped. "What's that in the background?"

Lauren looked over Sarah's other shoulder and we all stared at the photograph our faces slowly turning pale. In the background of the photo, in the evening sky, was a bright blue ball of light...
111121111111112111.title: Couvade syndrome.

1111211111111121112.content:
I showed the picture to Mom and Pop. "I'll show this to Pat," Mom said, "see what he thinks."

"You do that," Pop said. "I'm going to the Stardust, see how much more I can find out."

With the folks busy, I took out my phone and called Trish. "Hey, Cass," she said, "what up?"

"Hey, Trish. Remember you went to Ark Encounter last summer?"

"Ugh. I didn't really want to go. But Bree and Fae had extra tickets, so Susan and I agreed to go. Too religious for my blood. Give me science fiction any day."

You're about to get your wish, I thought. "And remember how you got a flat tire, and had to spend the night at the Stardust Hotel?"

"Nothing happened, but still better than... Wait a minute. How'd you hear about that?"

"Lauren, Sarah, and I are trying to solve this mystery, Trish. And you've got a part to play."

"Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. I know I said I'd do anything for you, Cassie, but I meant something more like helping you hide a dead body, not getting pregnant."

"Not that big a part. Get Susan and come here. We've got tons to talk about."

I called Susan to give her a head's up, then I went into the kitchen and filled the teakettle.

Mom came down as I put the kettle on. "Pat says it's bigger than the one he saw, but looks identical otherwise. Why the teakettle?"

"We're having friends over."

Mom kissed me on the forehead and said, "I only wanted you to make friends. Getting pregnant wasn't really necessary."
1111211111111121112.title: We call our friends

choices: Later, pop returns from the hotel.
11112111111111211121.content:
Trish arrived first, with Susan, who seemed just as rattled and confused. Trish was about my height, with gentle blue eyes and long dust blond hair. Susan was a few inches shorter, with shoulder-length red hair and green eyes. "What's this all about, Cassie?" Worried, Trish asked. "Also, what does it have to do with our little trip to Ark Encounter?"

"I'm not the only one who found herself with a mysterious pregnancy." To my friends' surprise, I explained. "There are two others, in our circle of friends. We'll tell you all about it once everyone gets here."

Emily and Amy were next to arrive, both looking concerned. Emily was short and petite, with long blond hair and blue eyes. Amy was my height, fit, with short black hair and green eyes. "Lauren told us that she needed help solving a mystery." Serious, Amy said.

"We do." Nodding, I said. "Thanks for coming."

Bree and Fae were right behind them, also looking rattled and concerned. Bree was Pat's height, with shoulder-length auburn hair and blue eyes. Fae was Lauren's height, tall and slender, with long blond hair and green eyes. "Sarah said that you guys had found something frightening in your investigation of what had happened to you." Worried, Bree said. "We're here to help out any way we can."

"I appreciate that." Grateful, I said. "Please come inside. I have a pot of tea and some snacks, we have a lot to go over."

Over the next hour or so, we all told our friends what we had discovered in our investigation, and showed them the picture taken from the Ark Encounter tour. Our friends were all shaken, to say the least, by what we had managed to piece together. Though they seemed bemused by Pat's sympathetic pregnancy symptoms. "At least you know he loves you enough to go through what you're dealing with." smiling, Bree said.

"I still kind of feel sorry for him." Wincing, I said.

"We're getting off subject." Serious, Trish said. "We still need to find evidence that we were watched for a while, something that links everything together."

"There was one strange thing at school." After a pause, Susan said. "Sophomore year, we got a lot of substitute teachers in all of our classes."

"What makes that a clue?" Shrugging, Emily asked.

"The questions they asked..." softly, Sarah said. "More than one asked me why I had so few friends, since I seemed so nice."

"I remember that." Frowning, Amy said. "Several of those substitute teachers had asked me why I was so shy most of the time."

"They all seemed to be full of odd questions... personal questions." shuddering, I said. "Could they have been the ones who were watching us, observing us all?"

"Their behavior certainly makes them legitimate suspects." Serious, Fae said. "The question is, are they still at the school?"

I frowned at that. "Good question."

"We can't call the school with what we have." Thoughtful, Trish said. "They will think we're all desperate to find a 'smoking gun,' and it will give the substitute teachers the heads up that we might be on to them, if they are a part of all this."

"So what do we do?" Wincing, Sarah asked.

Mom, who had been silent up to this point, replied, "We give these substitute teachers a surprise visit, and ask them some questions of our own."

We were interrupted by Pat clearing his throat. I turned to find him looking worse than before, clutching his slightly swollen stomach. "The- the mail came." Weakly, he said. "There are letters addressed here for Lauren, Sarah, and you, sis."

"For us?" Surprised, Lauren asked. "That can't be right."

Mom took the three letters and opened the one addressed to me. Her face turned pale before she opened the other two, one at a time, her face turning from pale to white. "What do the letters say, Mom?" Wincing, I asked. "Is it bad?"

Mom gulped. "All three letters have the same six words." Shaken, she said. She gave us each the letter.

They all read: We chose you for a reason.
11112111111111211121.title: The Friendship Circle

choices: Dad searches Pat to be safe.
111121111111112111212.content:
Hours later, Pop returned from his visit to the Stardust Hotel, looking furious but oddly satisfied. "Once I explained that it had been medically proven that three minors had been violated and impregnated very close to the time they spent at their hotel, they became very cooperative." Serious, Pop said. "The gave me a copy of their security videos of the night in question."

"Have you seen it?" worried, Mom asked.

Pop nodded. "It proves that these girls were intentionally targeted." Angry, dad said. "You will need to see this to believe it."

Dad set up the DVD player and played the security disk. We watched in shock and horror as we saw the men working the hotel. "That- that's Mr Dorie, the substitute teacher I had for English class!" Shaking, I blurted out. "But I didn't see him when we checked in."

"That's because he checked in Lauren and her family." Serious, Pop said.

As the video continued to play, I saw Sarah and the Ark Encounter tour enter, with a different man at the desk. "That's Mr Thatch, the substitute teacher I had for Mathematics!" stunned, Lauren yelled.

Pop nodded. "I saw all of these substitute teachers walk out as you all left school." Darkly, Pop said. "I knew something was amiss at the hotel. They all looked familiar, but I didn't make the connection until now."

I then saw Pop, Mom, Pat, and I enter the hotel, to which Mom said, "That's Mr Barns, the substitute guidance counselor, who took over for Ms Taylor, who was out with the flu."

"That's what Mr. Dorie said about Miss Daisy, my regular English teacher." Stunned, I said. Turning to the others, I asked "Was it the same with your substitute teachers?"

All of my friends nodded, the color draining from their faces. "We were all being watched." Whispering, Trish said. "It could have easily been any one of us who had been impregnated."

"It could have been all of you." Gravely, Pop said. "This video also shows footage of all of you girls in your rooms."

Mom turned red with anger. "Those sick, twisted..."

"I have already called our attorney." Serious, Pop said. "First thing Monday morning, I am going to give those substitute teachers a visit they are not going to like."

"Assuming they are still there." Angry, Mom said.

"The school will still have records of who they are and where they came from." Serious, Pop said. "We now have more than enough evidence to spark a criminal investigation."

"Including these letters, addressed here for all three girls." Serious, Mom said. "This can only mean that they are still watching us."

Pop read the letters, then immediately turned to the girls and I. "I want all of you to step into the bathroom one at a time!" Firmly, he said. "My wife is going to search each any every one of you and the belongings you brought with you!"

"What?!" Startled, I asked.

"They knew exactly where to find you girls." Serious, Pop said. "That means some, if not all of you must be carrying a tracking device of some sort."

Frightened and uncertain, I walked into the bathroom first with Mom following me. "You know Pop is right, honey." Softly, she said. "How else would someone know where you all were?"

"It's just all very frightening, Mom." Wincing, I said.

Mom nodded. "I know, but at least we now have some suspects as to who violated you."
111121111111112111212.title: Fearful confirmation.

1111211111111121112121.content:
Mom began her search by having me empty my pockets and my purse. When that came up empty, she began examining my clothes, one at a time, as I took them off. She studied them closely enough that she could have told if the manufacturers had lied about the materials used, but still couldn't find a bug.

That left her with only one option: examining me.

She began with my hair. Taking my comb, she went through my hair almost strand by strand. First combing down, then up. It was when she started pulling my hair up that she said, "What's this?"

I felt something being ripped off from the base of my skull, then Mom brought her hand around. "Take a look."

It was shiny and metallic on one side, camouflaged to look like a mole on the other. "That... that was on me?"

"Yep. Any idea how it got there?"

"Mr. Dorie." I remembered him patting me on the neck, telling me what a good job I'd done. It seemed so innocent...

I rushed to the toilet and threw up. "I'm sorry, dear," Mom said.

When I was through, Mom said, "Why don't you clean yourself up and get dressed, then send the next girl in?"

********************************************************


One by one, all nine of us went into the bathroom. All nine of us walked back out, touching our necks as if we'd found cancer there.

Mom walked out and handed the fruits of her search to Pop. "What's our next move?"

"Now," he said, "we let them know that the game is over." He brought the tracking devices out to the grill, soaked them in lighter fluid, and ignited them.
1111211111111121112121.title: We are all searched.

11112111111111211121212.content:
"I want Pat searched, just in case." Serious, Pop said. "I don't want a single stone left unturned." He turned to the girls. "If any of you have brothers or sisters, have their parents check the base of their skulls just in case."

Mom hurried to Pat's room, while Lauren and Sarah turned to their phones, but the others did not, admitting they were an only child. Soon after, Mom came in with Pat, looking better but very weak. "I searched him and found a chip at the base of his skull, as well." Worried, she said. "He started looking better and stronger the second I ripped it off him."

She handed the chip to Pop, who destroyed it by adding it to the fire on the grill. He returned a moment later to find Sarah staring at her cellphone. "What is it, my dear?" Worried, he asked.

"I have a twin brother named Stanley." Shaken, Sarah said. "We all call him Stan." She winced. "Only I doubt my mom and dad will believe me..."

"Call your house then hand the phone to me." Serious, Pop said. "I have put the fear of God in more than my share of people."

Uncertain, Sarah dialed the number and handed the phone to Pop, who waited for someone to answer on the other end. "Good morning, Mr White." Forcefully, he said. "I am Don Pennant, your only salvation from burning in hell for abandoning your daughter!"

My eyes widened in surprise and turned to Sarah, who had raised a hand to her mouth in disbelief. Only Mom was smiling. "Trust me, girls, Pop is just getting warmed up." Whispering, she said. "He fears no man."

I was startled, but also somewhat impressed, as Pop continued talking. "We have irrefutable proof that your daughter was deliberately violated and impregnated, while she slept, by substitute teachers from her school!" Angrily, Pop said. "We have discovered two others who were violated in the same way, in the same place and time, including my own stepdaughter!" He took a breath as if to calm himself then added, "Then you have the ignorance of the grace of God to throw her out at the whispers of the devil...!"

When Pop eventually finished talking on the phone, he returned it to Sarah with a kind smile. "You are free to return home when you are ready, and you will be welcomed." Calmly, he said. "Your father will be praying hard for yours and the good Lord's forgiveness."

Sarah began to cry happy tears. "Thank you!" Sobbing, she said. "How did you ever convince Dad to take me back?"

Mom smiled. "Pop was a street pastor, fighting for the homeless on his days off for years." With a hint of pride, she explained. "It's actually how we met."

"You- You were homeless?" Startled, I asked.

Mom shook her head. "No, I was volunteering at a local homeless shelter at the time." Softly, she said. "I was crying when he met me, because your biological father had died in a car crash, trying to get to the hospital to see Pat born."

"I thought she was homeless, so I did what I could to support her." Smiling, pop said.

Mom kissed pop on the cheek. "The rest is history..."

"Did Dad find a chip on Stan's neck?" nervous, Sarah asked.

Pop nodded. "That was what convinced him." Serious, he replied. "That, and he's experiencing the same sympathetic pregnancy as Pat. Your father promised me that he threw the 'devil's toy' into the fireplace."

I smiled at that, then turned to Lauren as she sighed, ending her call. "What is it?"

"Once is a happenstance, two is a coincidence, but three is a pattern." Shaken, Lauren said. "My mom just told me that Jimmy is starting to show symptoms of a sympathetic pregnancy." She gulped. "She found a chip on the base of his skull and destroyed it with a hammer."

"That settles it." Shaking his head, Pop said. "We are bringing all the families together so we can take this all to the authorities."

"That will not be necessary, Mr. 'Pop' Pennant." A deep voice said.

Startled, we all turned to find three bright glowing blue lights in the living room with us, before they changed form to become the three substitute teachers...
11112111111111211121212.title: They Come to Us

111121111111112111212121.content:
Mom had just said that Pop didn't fear any man. But these were no men.

Nonetheless, if Pop was afraid of them, he was doing a masterful job of hiding it. "Whoever or whatever you are, you've got a hell of a lot of explaining to do."

"Your determination is impressive, sir," said "Mr. Dorie." "It is surpassed only by your empathy."

"Spare me the empty flattery," Pop said, "or you'll find out where my rage fits on that scale."

"Why did you hurt our children?" Mom asked. "Why did you hurt all these children?"

"Our homeworld is dead," the being said, "and we are dying. We needed to give our offspring a chance to live on after us."

"Your offspring?" I asked. "Y-you mean... " I put my hands over my womb.

The being nodded. "Our offspring will be born into the human race, through you."

"Why them?" Pop demanded. "Why didn't you seek out grown women to do this?"

"Years have a way of hardening your people. Adolescents do not have this disadvantage."

"But why us in particular?" Lauren asked. "I... I'm nobody."

"Humans speak of their capacity for love in terms of the size of their hearts. In this regard, you three have very large hearts, indeed. We could want nothing more for our offspring, than to know that they were with such loving people."

"But that doesn't explain why you sought out shy girls."

"That was a practical matter. Sexually active girls could become pregnant before we could implant our offspring. We had no wish to destroy, or to do lasting harm."

"The educators we substituted for were ill for a short time," said the one who appeared female, "but they recovered fully when we were finished."

"What about our brothers?" Lauren asked. "Your little bugs made them sick."

"We apologize. We did not know the emotional bonds between you would be so strong. However, it does indicate that we chose well."

Maybe it was all the talk of love and family, but I had to turn and look at Pat. When I saw him, my eyes went wide. "Pat!"

Everybody looked at Pat, whose belly now looked like he was four months pregnant.
111121111111112111212121.title: Mom and Pop confront the 'teachers'.

1111211111111121112121211.content:
"What have you done to my son?" Pop yelled. "Answer me, or I'll - "

"It appears," said the alien, "one of our offspring has implanted in the young one, perhaps believing him to be female, perhaps not knowing that males cannot bear children."

"He's in agony!" I cried. "Do something!"

"The only way to save both of their lives," the alien said, "would be to modify the young one's physical and chromosomal structure, making him a female. It will cost us much. Do you want this?"

Mom and Pop looked at each other, unsure of their decision.

"Help... " Pat cried weakly. "Help us... "

Apparently, that was the answer they were waiting for. Reverting to their light ball forms, the three aliens converged on Pat, enveloping him. For I couldn't tell you how long, we watched this big ball of blue light, unsure of what could possibly be happening inside.

Finally, the blue light faded - it didn't fly away, it faded - leaving a figure in Pat's place, curled up in a fetal position.

"Whoa," Trish said.

The figure stirred and arose, looking a little like the Pat we all knew and loved. "Pat?" Pop asked.

"Not quite," she said.

As the aliens had said, Pat was now a girl. Her flat belly indicated that she was about as far along as Lauren, Sarah, and I were.

"Where are the aliens?" Mom asked.

"They died," the former Pat said. "It took everything they had, to save me and the baby."

I put my arm around her. "How do you feel?"

She looked up at me. "I always wanted to be more like you, Cassie. I guess I just never thought I'd be this much like you."
1111211111111121112121211.title: What's Happening to Pat?

choices: The other girls received a gift as well.
11112111111111211121212111.content:
I sighed before pulling Pat into a hug. "Welcome to the Sisterhood." Kindly, I said. "Maybe some of my old clothes will fit you, we'll see what we can find."

"Thanks, sis." Sighing, Pat said. "Is it alright if I change now?"

"I'll take you to Cassie's room." Taking Pat's hand, Mom said. "We'll find you something."

Mom began to lead Pat away, but he abruptly stopped and turned to Pop. "The aliens told me to tell you that they left a monetary compensation in the basement."

Pop raised an eyebrow and walked down to the basement, with Trish and me following. Upon hitting the light switch, we were surprised by a bright light. When our eyes had adjusted, we found stacks of gold and silver bars, along with shelves of diamonds and emeralds. "Whoa!" wide eyed, Trish said. "You're rich, Pop!"

Pop bowed his head. "Their world is dead." Softly, he said. "It's very sad to think it took that to make them realize just how little value such material objects hold in the bigger picture."

I had not thought of it that way before, and it brought a tear to my eye. We were slowly destroying our own planet with pollution... all for the sake of riches. "The realization came too late, no children will be born, we sealed our own fate." Softly, I muttered.

"What was that?" Curious, Pop asked.

I blinked before realizing what I had said. "I'm not sure." Honestly, I said. "I guess I just remembered a poem from somewhere."

Pop sighed. "Where a door is closed, somewhere, a window is open." Softly, he said. "I have a strong feeling those aliens gave you more than just one of their offspring."

I shuddered at that as the full poem entered my mind.

The realization came too late, no children will be born, we sealed our own fate.
To a primitive world dubbed a place to hide, it is our last hope to survive.
Young women with great hearts we must find, grant them the gift of what we leave behind.

Overwhelmed by the sad meaning of the poem, I began to cry uncontrollably, trembling to the point of falling to my knees. An entire civilization, billions of people, slowly dying off, with no one able to carry a child to start the next generation. Lauren, Sarah, Pat, and I were their only hope to save what little was left of them. I began to see images of beautiful art in the form of statues, paintings, poems, and music...

"Cassie... Cassie...!"

Pop's words suddenly penetrated the swirling onslaught of images and sounds, bringing me back into reality, where I threw my arms around him, sobbing. "I- I can see everything, pop!" Crying, I said. "Their art, music, poems... it's all in my head!"

Pop looked at me for a long moment before pulling me into a hug, crying as well. "A heavy burden has been placed upon my stepdaughter." Weary, he thought. "Lord grant me the strength to help her and her friends through this test..."
11112111111111211121212111.title: Picking Up the Pieces

choices: The girs and I share what we see.
111121111111112111212121112.content:
Once Pop and Trish managed to calm me down, we all walked back into the sitting room, where we found Sarah, Lauren, and Pat in mournful tears. Their friends did their best to comfort them, with little success. "They just all seemed to lose it at once when Mrs Pennant came back with Pat from your room." Worried, Susan said. "We're trying to calm them down, but we don't know what sparked this."

I turned to Pat, to see she was wearing one of my old black pleated skirts and a white blouse with knee high socks and my old house slippers. She was crying like a baby, desperately trying to draw something on a piece of paper. Drawing was Pat's way to deal with stress. She would draw how she felt and show it to Mom and Pop. Only Pat's hands were shaking too much to draw anything, which was frustrating her.

"What do you see?" Looking into her eyes, I demanded. "Tell me!"

"I- I see clear rivers, blue oceans, beautiful mountains... as if I am flying over them in my head." Crying, Pat replied. "It's so beautiful..." She then cried harder. "Then I see black rivers, dead oceans... destroyed mountains..."

Pat could not speak any longer. She buried her face into her hands, bawling. I grabbed her wrists and pulled them from her face to look her into the eye. It was the only way to get her attention when she was distraught. "Pat, focus!" Firmly, I snapped. "You are seeing the alien world before and after it died! Focus on the good only!"

"I- I'll try..." Still weeping, Pat said.

"The aliens have given each of you a piece of their home world so you can tell their legacy to their... your children." Firmly, Pop said. "Only it is an overwhelming amount of information, their minds can't deal with it all at once."

"So... it's hurting them?" Worried, Mom asked.

Pop sighed. "It's causing them a great deal of stress, which is not healthy." Serious, he said. "We need to get them all to focus."

One by one, my friends and I, with Mom and Pop's help, calmed Lauren, Sarah, and Pat down to the point they were able to compose themselves. "I'll make another pot of tea." Shaken, Mom said. "It will help to calm all of our nerves."

"It seems that Cassie has gained knowledge of the alien's art." Softly, Pop said. "Pat seemed to have gained knowledge of their planet itself before and after it had died." He turned to Lauren and Sarah who jumped slightly but knew what he was about to ask.

"I keep seeing blueprints of medical devices, force fields, teleportation pads..." Quietly, she said. "It's like an all too real science fiction movie."

Sarah winced. "I'm seeing..." She gulped, her face pale. "I'm seeing people praying to the sun during the day and then to the stars at night." Timidly, she said. "It's nothing like Christianity, but yet somehow similar." She sighed, frustrated. "It's hard to explain... these aliens, they give thanks to the farmer who raised the pig, and thanks to the pig who sacrificed its life so they would have a meal."

"It sounds like an 'Earth' based religion." Pop said. "Perhaps it is similar to Wicca."

"I'm not sure..." Wincing, Sarah said. "I never studied any religion other than Christianity, my father would not have it." She sighed. "I'm more interested in maps and charts."

"We have all been given a heavy burden." Weary, I said. "Art is not really my cup of tea. I'm more of a tinkerer, I like to build things with Pop."

"I'm not what one would call a grease monkey." Wincing, Lauren said. "I'm more of an artist."

Pat sighed, blushing slightly. "I like Pop's religious books." Softly, he said. "It's amazing how so many different deities have come and gone through the years." He smiled. "Did you know the religion of the Pharaohs lasted over three thousand years? It's about how old Christianity is today, which raises so many questions..."

Pop, who had been listening, suddenly snapped his fingers. "Of course!" Frowning, he declared. "It should have been obvious!"

"What do you mean, Pop?" Wincing, I asked.

"The aliens gave you four knowledge that is way outside of your comfort zones." Serious, Pop explained. "however, it is well within the comfort zones of your friends."

"To keep us together." Turning pale, Lauren said.

Pop nodded. "Also to give reason for you all to gain all that they had left behind." Softly, he said. "They must have known that giving you each everything would have been too much for your minds to handle at once."

"So they gave us each a little, in a way we would have to stay together, in order to see the entire picture, once the puzzle was complete." Shaken, Sarah said. "How will I explain this to father?"

After a moment of thought, Pop looked at his home security system he had put in place last year, before turning to his phone. "You leave that to me."
111121111111112111212121112.title: The other girls received a gift as well.

1111211111111121112121211121.content:
After he finished making calls, Pop went into the kitchen and started making coffee. "For those who don't like tea," he said.

Within an hour, Lauren's folks arrived, accompanied by Jimmy. "Good to see you again, sis," he said, embracing her. Then, looking around, he asked, "Where's Pat?"

"Right here," she replied.

He looked her up and down. "Pat?"

She nodded. "It's short for Patricia now."

"Y-you're a girl? How? Why?"

"It had to be done," she explained. "It was the only way to keep me and my baby alive."

"Baby?"

Pat nodded, patting her lower abdomen. "The Sisterhood of the Maternity Pants stands at four members."

Sarah's family was next to arrive. They had kicked her out days ago, but the first thing they did when they saw each other was hug the stuffing out of each other.

Pop spoke up. "Ever since this began, one question has run through our minds: Why did this happen to our daughters? Well, today, we have the answer."

He pressed a button, and we all saw security camera footage of our last encounter with the aliens. When it got to the part where they explained why we were selected, parents' arms wrapped around daughters' bodies. By the time the video ended, you didn't need a system full of pregnancy hormones to be brought to tears.

After a minute or two, Mr. White asked, "What can we do?"

"Our daughters have a tremendous responsibility," Pop replied, "but they can't do it alone. They'll need the support of all of us. Whatever our initial reaction to the news was, these girls need to know that we're with them now."
1111211111111121112121211121.title: The families meet.

choices: At the Doctor's Office, a Familiar Face
11112111111111211121212111212.content:
After that amazing weekend, it was time for us to return to school. Once my stomach had settled, I went downstairs for a light breakfast.

"Alright," Pop said, "this cover story should answer any questions: After an investigation, it was learned that you had all been violated in your sleep by your former substitute teachers. When the heat closed in, they committed suicide."

"And me?" Pat asked. "How am I supposed to have gone from boy to pregnant girl?"

"You had a rare genetic condition," Mom answered. "After so many years, your Y chromosome broke down, and you reverted to female. Frightened by what was happening to your body, you concealed it for as long as you could. However, the substitutes managed to figure it out, and they violated you, too. When you realized that you were pregnant, you gave up the pretense and 'came out,' so to speak."

"That sounds plausible."

"Just remember, you have a doctor's appointment this afternoon. If I'm going to get you two to see an obstetrician, you need referrals."

*******************************************************


When we arrived at school, all our friends were there, so I filled them in. "Everyone got that?"

"Simple enough," Sarah said.

"You guys have had it rough," Trish said , "and it'll only get rougher in the months ahead. I'm sure glad I didn't get pregnant."

"Your time will come," Pat said.

"Huh?"

"The aliens didn't implant their offspring into you," she explained, "but they did implant their seeds. When you're ready, or if anything should happen to us or our children,... "

"How... how could you know that?"

"I was in physical contact with them when they died. I learned everything they had done to us. To all of us."

Our Friendship Circle looked at each other as they processed this information.
11112111111111211121212111212.title: Back to School

111121111111112111212121112121.content:
That afternoon, we went to the office of a Dr. Foster, an obstetrician who Dr. Hughes highly recommended over the phone. Upon arriving, Mom filled out the necessary paperwork, then led Pat and me back, where we were surprised to meet the same Dr. Foster who Pop had called a quack. She was tall and slender, with shoulder length blond hair and blue eyes. "Before you say or ask me anything, you need to understand that I must be the doctor to see you through this." Firmly, she said.

Mom was about to stand up to lead us out, but stopped as Dr Foster glowed, changing form into a bright blue ball of light! "You- You are one of them?!" Startled, I demanded.

Dr Foster returned to her human form, a sad look on her face. "There are only a mere few dozen of us left, out of billions." Softly, she said. "I, too, am slowly dying, so... I beg you to allow me to ensure our offspring have a very good start on this world."

Mom turned to Pat and me, looking for us to decide.

She and I turned to each other before nodding, we had the same thought in mind. "We will allow it." Softly, Pat said. "Just one condition, just be honest with us, trust is essential between a doctor and her patients."

"Will our children be human or like you?" Wincing, Pat asked.

"Please, call me Kyrl (Carol)." Softly, Dr Foster said. "Your children will be human in all ways that count, but carry above average attributes and intelligence."

"Will they suddenly change into blue lights?" Worried, I asked.

Kyrl shook her head. "No, those of us who accepted this desperate mission that involved you underwent dangerously experimental procedures to gain that ability." She shuddered at the memory of it. "It allowed us to complete our mission without detection but... it aged us in ways I hope you never understand."

"The realization came to late, no child will be born we sealed our own fate." Whispering, I said.

Kyrl nodded. "To a primitive world dubbed a place to hide, it is our last hope to survive."

Pat sniffed. "Young women with great hearts we must find, grant them the gift of what we leave behind." Tearfully, she said.

The three of us hugged each other, sobbing quietly for a moment. "You are very brave young ladies, thank you." With a small smile, she said. "Shall we begin the examination?"

I nodded, and Kyrl began to look Pat and me over. About twenty minutes later, she smiled, a look of relief on her face. "Your babies are perfectly healthy." Tearfully, she said. "My job is ensure they stay healthy, so our world... and yours will carry on."

"Um... do you know why I'm not really freaking out about being a girl and pregnant?" Wincing, Pat asked. "I know I should be..."

Kyrl smiled. "I can only guess that Mr. Dorie and his team instilled a certain calm within your mind, to allow you to adapt quickly."

I smiled at that. "You were blushing all day at school, Pat." Bemused, I said. "I don't know if it was the boys looking at you differently than before, or if it was the girls trying to give you tips on how to be a better girl."

Pat blushed at that, making her look cute, but I did not mention that. "Everything from fashion to hygiene to posture." Frowning, she grumbled. "Don't even get me started on the boys..."

Mom, Kyrl, and I giggled at that.

"Where do we go next?" After leaving the office, I asked.

Mom smiled, turning to us.
111121111111112111212121112121.title: At the Doctor's Office, a Familiar Face

choices: Lauren and I Share Our Gifts
1111211111111121112121211121211.content:
"I should think it was obvious," Mom told us. "We're going to get Pat some clothes of her own. If her new friends are giving her fashion advice, I can only assume that Cassie's old clothes haven't stood the test of time."

I felt uncomfortable hearing that. Sure, I'd never dressed to turn heads, but it was still wounding to find out for a fact that your clothes are definitely out.

So Pat began trying out new outfits. As we went, two things became clear: Pat had been given very good advice, and she was enjoying picking out new clothes. In fact, I'd say we'd have been there until closing if Mom would have let us.

Our shopping cart was full to overflowing when Mom called a halt. "Don't forget, you'll be needing new clothes in a few weeks. Both of you will need them."

She had a point. We had seen a woman pushing a stroller, and neither of us could resist cooing over that sweet little baby. A few weeks ago, I thought, I wouldn't have looked twice at it. Now, I had to restrain myself from pulling that little darling out of the stroller and showering her with kisses. Hell, even in my head, I still loved that baby.

**************************************************


When we got home, Pop asked, "How'd it go?"

"Just fine," Mom said. "The girls and their babies are the picture of health. Dr. Foster will be taking - "

"Wait a minute. Dr. Foster? You took them back to her? Why?"

"Dr. Hughes recommended her highly. My guess is, she misdiagnosed your ankle injury years ago because she wasn't too familiar with human anatomy yet."

"Well," Pop grumbled, "I guess she had to get better, since she couldn't... Wait a minute. Something you just said. The way you pronounced the word human." His eyes went wide. "You mean she - "

"That's right."
1111211111111121112121211121211.title: shopping for new clothes.

choices: Pat and Sarah share their gifts.
11112111111111211121212111212111.content:
Later on, Lauren met up with me at my house, and we sat down to talk about the gifts the aliens had given us. "Pat told me that they call themselves Gaians, and that their world is called Gaia." Calmly, I said. "She's still a bit shaken by visions of a dead planet."

"I would be, too." Wincing, Lauren said. "Still, she's adapting well, considering she was born a boy."

"Our obstetrician is a Gaian." Ruefully, I said. "Dr. Kyrl Foster. She told us that Mr Dorie had a knack for helping people mentally adapt, and Pat is no exception."

"You said that you loved to tinker." Changing the subject, Lauren said. "I love music and arts, so why don't we compare notes, so to speak?"

"Where should we start?" Wincing, I asked.

"How about something we both love, music." Pointing to a piano, Lauren said. "Can you think of any Gaian music we can play on a piano?"

"Not a piano, really..." shrugging, I said. "I keep hearing a beautiful song played on something that looks like an old sewing machine." I then smiled and added, "Pop and I built it last night, but neither of us are really musicians."

Lauren's eyes lit up. "Let's take a look at it."

I led Lauren to the other room, where we had set up and old electric sewing machine to which Pop and I had added a long spindle with rings of fine thread, making it look much like a tube of yarn for crocheting. Lauren smiled upon seeing it. "I saw blueprints for this in my dreams last night. You and Pop did an amazing job putting it together."

I blushed at that, then became curious as Lauren left the room, and returned soon after with a small cup of water. She wet her hands, then began to move her fingers over the fine threads, creating beautiful but haunting sounds, like a harp with an electric echo from a rock guitar. "What is it called?" Curious, I asked.

"This is called a Spindle Harp." Pausing, Lauren said. "Why don't you try singing one of the songs in your head, and I'll try to play it on this."

"I'm not that good of a singer." Wincing, i said.

"I'm not that good at building things." Shrugging, Lauren countered. "We both have to start somewhere, now, don't we?"

I giggled. "I guess so."

After taking a moment to allow Gaian music to flow through my mind, i picked a song and began to sing...

Over beautiful mountain sides
Our mighty clear rivers flow
Into oceans of majesties
Giving our world its glow

Gaia! Gaia!
Gods all smile upon thee
And grace us all with conflicts resolved
On all lands airs and sea...!

I paused, shedding tears. "It's so beautiful!"

Lauren nodded, shedding tears of her own. "The song seems to speak praise of their world, rather than individual nations." Smiling, she said. "Do you want to continue with the song?"

I nodded, and Lauren began to play the song again, singing along with me a sad, beautiful tribute to a dead world. A world of which we were now the only hope of bringing back from the brink of extinction.
11112111111111211121212111212111.title: Lauren and I Share Our Gifts

111121111111112111212121112121111.content:
"Okay, let's make sure we've got everything."

A lot had changed in our lives since that stay at the Stardust four months ago, but it was Thanksgiving, and two things never changed: we drove to Grandma and Grandpa's house for Thanksgiving dinner, and Mom and Pop fretted that they might leave something behind, and not remember until we were halfway there.

While they double-checked, I just had to close my eyes. Lately, it seemed like, no matter how much sleep I got, it was never enough. When I came home from school, I had to go straight to bed until supper. Pat was dealing with the same thing. Mom said that it was just part of being pregnant. A quick nap wouldn't hurt now, either...

I felt a hand on my knee. "Girls," Mom said. "Wake up."

I rubbed my eyes. The car wasn't moving. "Just a short nap," I said. "How soon before we go?"

She smiled. "We're here."

************************************************


I guess I had been a little nervous about how they would all react, what with Pat's sex change and both of our pregnancies. But, whatever they might have said out of my earshot, our aunts treated us like any other first-time mothers-to-be. Everybody had tips for handling morning sickness, treating constipation (ouch!), avoiding hemorrhoids (double ouch!), and a host of other ailments. Aunt Mary Jo even gave us each a bottle of flavored Tums, for when morning sickness segued into heartburn.

About the only really peculiar thing was how our cousin Bridget was walking around like they were talking about throwing the turkey away and stuffing and roasting her instead. But, so far at least, she was avoiding me.

The second most anticipated moment of our Thanksgiving gathering was when Grandma gave the order that anyone who was not involved in the actual preparation of the meal had to get out of the kitchen. This signaled the beginning of the Turkey Bowl, a friendly game of touch football. Pat had played in previous years, but had to spend this year's game on the sidelines. There were a few women who played, but pregnancy disqualified her. No matter. Pop was still playing, and his two favorite cheerleaders could still root for him.

"You the one who got knocked up?"

I turned. One of Grandma's neighbors was talking to me. "I suppose so."

"Take my advice, kid: go to the doctor, and get it flushed out by Christmas."

"No, thanks," I said, and found a different place to stand.

Apart from that, we were all having a good time. As usual, it was almost a disappointment when Mom came out and announced, "Dinner's ready."

As I headed inside, I noticed Bridget was close by. Seizing the opportunity, I pulled her aside. "What's wrong?"

She tried to dodge me again. "I don't know what you're talking about."

"You don't, huh? I guess that's someone else walking around with your face, making a deer caught in the headlights look like a model of composure? The last time I saw anybody looking like that, she had just found out she was... " It all fell into place. "You're pregnant?"

She nodded. "Not like you. I mean, I know the guy and everything. But Dad's gonna kill me when he finds out!"
111121111111112111212121112121111.title: Thanksgiving.

choices: Why did you not come to us right away?
Your's and Brad's entire life is going to change.
Break out the wine, we have some celebating to do.
1111211111111121112121211121211111.content:
"How did it happen?" Whispering, I asked.

Bridget winced. "We're in love." Softly, she explained. "I can't imagine a single day without him." She sighed. "A few months ago, we starting making out at his house while studying. One kiss led to another, then we began to fondle one another. Before we knew what was happening, we were both naked in the bed..."

"You made love?" surprised, I demanded.

"I never felt him enter me." Tearing up, Bridget said. "I was too lost in waves of pleasure from his gentle touch to even notice it." She began to cry. "I- I didn't know I was pregnant until the morning sickness started to hit."

I was silent for a moment before I asked, "Does he know you are pregnant?"

Bridget nodded. "He's just as scared as I am." Now trembling, she said. "We're both the same age, with old-fashioned parents..."

I sighed, wondering what to do. "When are you planning to tell your parents?" Worried, I asked. "It's going to become impossible to hide, eventually."

"Brad and I are planning to tell Mom and Dad after Thanksgiving." Sobbing, Bridget replied. "There's no sense in ruining their holiday..."

Our conversation was interrupted by a soft knock on the door. Uncle Hank, Bridget's father, answered, to find Brad at the door. He was of average height and average build, with short brown hair and gentle green eyes. "I am sorry to interrupt your Thanksgiving, sir." Nervous, he said. "However, I need to talk to you about something very serious." He gulped. "I have to admit, I'm really scared."

Everyone turned to Uncle Hank and the visitor at the door, surprised and concerned. Uncle Hank sighed. "We will talk outside."

Brad nodded, tears forming, and Uncle Hank walked out and closed the door. Seeing them, Bridget immediately began to quietly sob uncontrollably. I did what I could to comfort her without making a scene, and turned as Hank stepped back in, with a tearful Brad following close behind. They both marched right up to Bridget and me. Neither of their expressions gave any clue as to what they were thinking or feeling.

Bridget raised her hands up, trembling, as if she were expecting the pounding or lecture of her life, only Uncle Hank sighed. "Young lady..."
1111211111111121112121211121211111.title: Bridget's Pregnancy

11112111111111211121212111212111111.content:
"... why didn't you come to me with this sooner?"

"I... I was scared," Bridget replied. "I was sure you'd be angry with me. I know I should've been more careful, but it... "

Uncle Hank responded by wrapping his arms around her in a bear hug. "I thought, by being strict with you, I could protect you from the world," he said. "Now, I see you thought you'd need protection from me."

Aunt Meghan came up to us. "What's going on, Hank?"

Uncle Hank broke the hug and turned, keeping one arm around Bridget. "It looks like we're going to be grandparents." He turned to Bridget. "Unless you've changed your mind?"

Bridget shook her head, a hesitant smile forming through her tears.

"Brad's a good young man," Uncle Hank said. "He's promised to do what he can by Bridget and the baby."

The four of them hugged, which was more than enough to bring tears to the eyes of this hormone case.

Then, it was Bridget's turn to get advice from the aunts in the room.

"What's going on?" Pop asked me as I sat down next to him.

"Bridget's going to have a baby."

He sighed. "Where'd this one come from?"

"Young love."
11112111111111211121212111212111111.title: Why did you not come to us right away?

choices: Rumors of Pat running agaisnt Darla spread.
111121111111112111212121112121111112.content:
Upon returning to school the next day, I saw what I had been fearing since Pat became my little sister and pregnant. The 'popular girls,' as many of the students have dubbed them, surrounded Pat at her locker. "So you are the little boy turned girl everyone's been talking about." Grinning meanly, the first girl said. "I must say, you look good in a skirt and blouse, for being born a boy."

I recognized her as Darla Darling. She was fourteen years old, tall and skinny to a fault, with mid back sun blond hair and blue eyes. She and her posse, as she called her friends, were known for playing cruel pranks on new students, or those who had crossed her path one way or another. Many of them had led to injury, or students transferring out in fear. Fortunately, Jimmy had a locker right next to mine, and saw the girls surround Pat as well.

Those girls are nothing but trouble. Frowning, I thought. Pat's 'rare condition' must have put her in their cross-hairs.

I knew that Darla had already been warned twice by Principal Lila Switch. She was on thin ice, and one more reported stunt would get her expelled.

"Um... they had to order a uniform in my size." Softly, Pat replied.

"You don't need to explain anything to them." Firmly but kindly, I said. "Why don't you get your books and hurry to class." I then turned to Darla, my voice turning cold. "What do you want with my sister, Darling?"

"To meet your brother, or rather sister." Maintaining her smile, Darla said. "We've never had a true freak of nature in this school before..."

"Don't even think about it, Darling." Frowning, I warned. "You don't think I haven't heard the rumors around school myself?"

Darla scoffed. "As if he has any chance to be selected to become prom queen..." Frowning, she began.

I smiled, more bemused at the thought of my little sister being crowned prom queen over Darla Darling than anything else. Still, it caused Darla to take a step back.

Seeing her reaction, Jimmy smiled as well. "That would be interesting to see." Bemused, he said. "A cute boy, turned pretty girl running for prom queen."

At this point, Pat had finished gathering what she needed for her first class, and closed her locker before turning to us. Jimmy blushed, seeing her dressed in a simple baby blue skirt and blouse with a narrow belt and flats. With her keen fashion sense, she looked as if she were wearing a casual dress that showed off her youthful hourglass figure very well. She had turned the moment Darla blurted out, "You can't be serious!"

"What's going on?" Curious, Pat asked.

She blushed more, seeing Jimmy's jaw drop in surprise. "Pat! You look breathtaking!"

"I'm a little jealous." Smiling at Darla, I said. "To think you could look that good without any effort put into it..."

I turned to Jimmy, sharing a knowing smile before turning to Pat who winced, nervous. "Um..."

"The freak has no chance!" Suddenly angry, Darla fumed. "I am the queen of the prom!"

With that, she stormed off, leaving Pat confused. "What just happened?"

I giggled as I then closed my own locker. "Sorry, sis, but I think we've just inadvertently thrown you into the running for this year's prom queen." Bemused, I said. "You coming out looking that good didn't help anything."

"It was the most modest skirt and blouse I had." Wincing, Pat said.

"We'll worry about it later." Smiling, Jimmy said. "Let's get to class before we're late."
111121111111112111212121112121111112.title: Developments at School

1111211111111121112121211121211111122.content:
I was still getting used to having lunch with such a large group of friends. Our table rivaled some of the most popular cliques in size. On this day, I learned that others had noticed this as well.

We were talking about this and that (okay, we mostly talked about what we had read in various pregnancy books), when a voice asked, "Do you know what you three have in common with the senior class?"

"Get out of here, Brooklynne," I said.

Darla Darling ruled the freshman class with violence and intimidation, but Brooklynne Dietrich and her Queen Bees held dominion over the upper classes with gossip. Any threat to Brooklynne's status found every dirty little secret they had suddenly become public knowledge. Needless to say, the last thing any of us wanted was for her to take notice of us.

"I asked, do you know what you three have in common with the senior class?" she repeated. "Give up? Like them, you three won't be back next year."

"Literally nobody asked you," I said.

Unfortunately, Fae wound up making a liar out of me. "What do you mean?"

"I mean, your friends are going to drop out, in order to take care of their babies. It happens all the time." Turning back to us, she said, "Let's be real, what did you think you were going to do, attend classes with a wailing brat on one hip, and a bag full of dirty diapers on the other? No career. No future. That's what's in store for you."

I wanted to hit her. Actually, I wanted to do more than hit her, but hitting her would get me suspended, while what I really wanted to do would get me expelled, and probably some jail time.

"You should be more careful when you're talking to yourself, Brooklynne," said a boy's voice. "Somebody might overhear that, and come away mistakenly thinking you were talking to these three."

She turned to look at him, and I saw an opportunity to take her down a peg without a single blow. "Move your ass, Brooklynne, I can't see what I'm looking at."

That little display put the spotlight squarely on her. With a grumble, she stormed off.

It turned out my Galahad had a name, and it was Kevin Stewart. He was tall, with a lean yet muscular physique, ideal for a wrestler. He had short black hair and piercing blue eyes. Right behind him were the Rafferty twins, Mike and Bill. Their bodies were much like Kevin's, but with red hair and green eyes. They were all but impervious to bullies, and they used this for the benefit of anyone who got picked on. "You girls okay?" Kevin asked.

"We are now, thanks," said Trish.

"We figured you girls had been through enough," said Bill. "No need for her to pick on you, too."

As they went on their way, it occurred to me that I hadn't said a word. I was left pondering why, when it hit me: It had taken me more years than was usual, but I had just developed my first crush.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122.title: More trouble at school.

choices: Pat and I meet with Sarah and her family.
11112111111111211121212111212111111221.content:
Upon returning home from school, I felt oddly light on my feet, with a curious grin I did not really notice I was carrying. Pat, however, was dragging her feet, looking frightened and confused. Pop saw this right away, and folded his arms. "Okay, one at a time, what happened at school today?" Firmly, he demanded. "One of you looks like the cat that swallowed the canary, and the other looks like someone stole her last dime."

Pat moaned, tears forming, making Mom worry. "Darla Darling happened." Almost crying, she said. "She called me a freak of nature, but that's not the worst of it..."

Mom kneeled down to Pat's level, looking into her eyes. "Honey, what happened?"

Pat rubbed at her eyes. "Cassie and Jimmy came to my rescue." Sobbing, she said. "But- but it ended up starting a rumor that I'm running for freshman prom queen."

Mom sighed, shaking her head. She pulled Pat into a hug, slowly rocking her back and forth to help calm her down. "If she does anything to make you feel threatened, you let us know right away." Firmly but kindly, she said. "We do not tolerate bullies in this family."

Pat, although still crying, nodded. "Okay, Mom."

Mom then giggled slightly. "As for the rumor of you running for prom queen, that is up to you." Smiling, she said. "You can either deny it or go for it."

Pop turned to me. "What of you, young lady?" Serious, he demanded. "What happened to you at school today?"

"My friends and I were confronted by Brooklynne Dietrich and her Queen Bees." A frown appearing on my face, I said. "They told us we were all going to end up dropping out due to our babies, with no career and no future..."

Pop's face hardened, but he paused as the smile returned to my face. "Only I had a Galahad,... Kevin Stewart." sighing, I said. "He was so brave and bold..."

Pop's face softened, his lips curling up into a knowing smile which he shared with Mom.I

"It sounds like someone has her first crush on a boy." Smiling, Mom said. She then turned to Pat who was still holding her frightened and confused expression. "Something tells me that there's a little more to your story, honey."

Pat nodded, trying to compose herself. "Jimmy was there with me all day, defending me." Softly, she said. "It really made me feel weird..."

It was now Mom's turn to hold a knowing smile, which she shared with Pop. "It seems our little girls are growing up." Smiling, Pop said.

Mom nodded. "Our shy little flowers are finally blossoming."

Both Pat and I blushed, to which Mom and Pop chuckled...

Later on, Pat and I talked about our day. "I saw you and Sarah talking after school today." Softly, I said. "Care to share?"

Pat smiled slightly. "Sarah wants to meet with me to share our gifts." With an air of anticipation, she said. "She told her father that I want to talk about religion." She giggled. "She told me that his eyes lit up like a Christmas tree."

"From our meet and greet, he knows you are fascinated by all religions." Bemused, I said. "I'm betting he's hoping Sarah will show you the true path."

"They're all true paths to those who believe in them." Smiling, Pat said. "The point is, they believe in something that gives their lives purpose."

I put my hand over my womb. "I believe..."

Pat did the same. "So do I..."

I began to sing the beautiful "Song of Gaia," and Pat closed her eyes, singing along...
11112111111111211121212111212111111221.title: After School

111121111111112111212121112121111112211.content:
By either great coincidence or Mr. White deliberately seeking it out, Sarah's family's house looked a lot like a church. It didn't have a bell tower, but, if they ever decided to add one on, it wouldn't look out of place. "What a place," I said, as I pocketed the car keys. "Nice of them to remind me that they kicked out their own daughter."

We rang the doorbell, and a boy answered. "Peace be with you," he said. "My name is Stan. You must be Sarah's friends. Let me take your coats."

"Thank you," I said. "You look like you've recovered nicely."

"Thanks. When I heard what happened to your brother, I was scared that - "

"That what?" Pat asked, with a raised eyebrow.

"Uhhh,... nothing."

Stan led us to the living room, where the rest of the family sat in their own chairs, arranged to face a sofa. "Welcome to my home," Mr. White said. To Pat, he said, "If I recall correctly, you've been studying comparative religion in your spare time."

"Yes, Mr. White."

"Perhaps you can explain what my daughter did on Thanksgiving. We had family over, and I asked her to say grace. She proceeded to thank everyone except God." He shook his head. "She even thanked the turkey."

"The first thing that came to mind," Sarah explained, "was a Gaian prayer of thanksgiving. I just substituted turkey for grizzleback, whatever that was."

"It was something like a boar," Pat explained. Turning to Mr. White, she said, "It sounds like what we would call an Earth-based religion. To them, the gods don't sit on white thrones judging their creation, but they move among us and through us."

"Well," Mr. White said, "to my way of thinking, any religion that doesn't have a Messiah is lost."

"They called them the Prophets," Sarah replied. "The Gaians told of how they traveled the whole world, teaching them right from wrong."

"Prophets are all well and good," Mr. White said, "but I'm talking about the Hand of God, and the Virgin Birth."

"The Prophets were born of virgins."

"What?!"

"You heard me. And you can't even say it's that farfetched, what with evidence to the contrary literally staring you in the face."

Ever since the day I went to the doctor, I hadn't given much thought to the implications of being a virgin mother. Now, though, I learned that it had significance to the Gaians as well.
111121111111112111212121112121111112211.title: Pat and I meet with Sarah and her family.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The following morning, both Pat and I were still in awe over the courage Sarah had gained in such a short time. It was strengthened more by Pat's view of all religions being the right path to those who believed in them. We talked about it as we got ready for the day side by side in the bathroom. "The look on Mr. White's face was priceless." Smiling, I said.

"Especially when Mrs White took a stance between him and Sarah, when he hinted at raising a hand against her." Smiling back, Pat said. "She told him that their daughter had found religion, and that patience and love would lead her to the true path."

"Then, she per the three of us into the next room." Brushing my hair, I said. "There, she wanted to know all about the Gaian religion." I giggled at the irony of ir. "Turns out she is fascinated by all of the different religions of the world, too."

"Instead of three wise men coming to the birth of their savior, it was three virgin-born women going to a wise man to begin their journey to teach the world right from wrong." With a dreamy smile, Pat said. "As I said, it's like Christianity, but not... it's a mixed up version of it."

"I guess that's as good of a description as any." shrugging, I said. "They believed that their gods were in everything, so, by thanking everything, they were thanking their gods."

"Mrs. White made that connection as well." spraying a little perfume on herself, Pat said.

"Wait a minute!" Turning to my sister, I said. "Did you just spray yourself with some of Mom's expensive perfume?"

Pat looked at me, a bit lost, then blushed. "I guess I did." Softly, she said. "I just like it."

A knowing smile formed upon my face. "You mean you hope Jimmy will like it." Grinning, I said.

Pat blushed even further before countering, "I see you holding some perfume of your own, sis. Hoping Kevin will like it?"

"Okay, okay." Giggling, I said. "You got me there."

Pat and I shared a giggle before finishing to get ready for school, only Mom peeked in. "School has been cancelled for the day, girls." Calmly, she said. "There was a water main break, so workers had to cut off the supply to the school to fix it." She then sniffed the air. "Is one of you wearing my perfume?"

"Guilty..." Wincing, Pat said.

Mom smiled, holding back a giggle. "Well, what is done is done, but try to ask next time, okay? You put on way too much."

I giggled at that then turned to Pat. "So, what do you plan to do with your long weekend?"
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Long weekend.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"We've got the day," Pat said, "let's enjoy it. Main Street awaits."

"Sounds good to me," I said. "Let's check with Mom."

Mom, as it turned out, had work to do for clients, so us out of the house was just what she needed. She didn't throw the car keys at us, but neither did she hesitate to give them to me. She also gave me her credit card, warning, "I'd better not get a notice of excessive activity on it."

*******************************************


Our first stop was lunch at a local restaurant. "What would you like?" the waitress asked.

"I could go for a Reuben," Pat said

"And I'll have the chicken club," I said.

While we waited for our sandwiches, a man approached our table. "Hi, girls," he said. "Darren Lohan with the Gazette. I'd like to ask you a few questions, if I may, about the fathers of your babies, and about your miraculous transformation."

He scared me with his line of questioning, but I didn't want him to see that. "May I ask who your source is?"

"A Mrs. Arlene Nichols."

I didn't recognize the name, but then it struck me: Grandma's neighbor, the one who told me to get an abortion. It must have been her.

"Without confirming or denying anything," I said, "I must insist that all requests for interviews come through our parents."

As he left, I called Mom and gave her the information we had. Let her and Pop decide if he can talk to us, and let heaven help him if they don't like how he works.

******************************************


After lunch, we took a stroll down Main Street, checking out the shops, and keeping an eye out for more reporters. We stopped when we saw a maternity shop called Great Expectations. "Can we go in?" Pat asked.

"We're a few weeks away from needing maternity wear," I said, "but there's nothing wrong with taking an early look around." So we went inside.

I had no idea there was so much inside a maternity shop. We marveled at just about everything. "Think we could need a breast pump?" Pat asked.

"It's possible," I said. "We'll know for sure when the babies come."

"May I help you?" asked a salesperson.

"Just looking, for now," I said. "When we come back with Mom another time, we'll make some purchases." That seemed good enough for her.

Pat pointed. "Isn't that... ?"

I peeked. "Sure looks like her, doesn't it?"

"Why do you suppose she's doing here?"

"One way to find out," I said, moving toward her.

The closer we got, the more convinced I became that she indeed was who we thought. "Dr. Foster?"

She turned. "Oh, hello, girls," she said. "What brings you here?"

"We just wanted to look around. And you?"

She smiled. "The same thing. I'm pregnant."

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Kyrl began to cry happy tears, holding her hand gently against her lower abdomen. "I'm actually pregnant... the gods have decided to smile upon me."

Pat and I smiled, shedding tears of our own, and we shared a long warm hug. "Welcome to the Sisterhood, Dr Foster." Whispering, I said.

Kyrl looked at me, confused, and we explained what the Sisterhood was, which brought further happy tears to her eyes. "I'm honored." Softly, she said.

We then all began to sing the Song of Gaia...

Over beautiful mountain sides
Our mighty clear rivers flow
Into oceans of majesties
Giving our world its glow

Gaia! Gaia!
Gods all smile upon thee
And grace us all with conflicts resolved
On all lands airs and sea...!

Oh beautiful for fruitful plains
For plentiful fruit, grain and game
For open skies with sun and rains
The Gods blessing us in their name

Gaia! Gaia!
May we never return to old ways
Peace and love our sacred hub
Till the last of all our days

For beautiful heroes showed
Peace is a better path than waste and war
All losses both regretted and loathed
Equal view to young, old, rich and poor

Gaia! Gaia!
Gods forgive our wasteful past
To be given the pass for a second chance
Our promise will forever last!

"What was that song?" Curious, the saleslady asked. "It's sad but sweet..."

Pat, Kyrl, and I turned to each other then smiled. "Just a song we heard from somewhere." Calmly, I replied. "We sort of like it."

The sales lady smiled in return. "Well, when you are ready, I'll be happy to show you some of the products you will be needing during your pregnancy."

After the sales lady had walked off, I turned to Kyrl. "So... what's his name?" Teasing, I asked.

Kyrl giggled, blushing. "His name is Adam Eden." Softly, she explained. "We met a few months ago, just after Mr Dorie and his team made their move. It was in a park, some less friendly male tried to force me to give up my purse." she sighed, a dreamy look on her face. "Like the faceless knight of kingdoms of old, he came to my rescue and walked me home."

"Faceless knight?" Curious, Pat asked.

"A knight who never lifts his face shield." Calmly, I explained. "He only reveals his face while in armor to those he truly loves so enemies will not recognize him when off duty."

"That's sort of romantic in itself." Smiling, Pat said.

Kyrl nodded. "Well, as you humans say, one thing led to another, and, before we knew what was happening, we were making love." Smiling, she said. "I never in my entire lifetime dreamed that I would be blessed with a child here on Earth." She then began to cry again. "Only my lifespan is cut in half due to the pollution of Gaia. I'll be lucky to reach a hundred years."

Pat and I turned to each other, shocked, but I was quick to recover, and took Kyrl's hand into my own. "Humans rarely live beyond a hundred years." To her surprise, I explained. "No one will blink an eye at it, and that includes your child to be."

Kyrl thought about what I had said, then smiled, her tears becoming joyous once more. "I will make the most of the time I have with my child." Happy, she said. "We are the beginnings of a new generation."

We later returned home, happy and in a good mood, until we reached our house...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Dr. Foster's Baby

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The street was filled with news vans, and our front lawn was covered with reporters. "What's going on?" Pat asked.

"I don't know, sis," I replied as I parked, "but it looks like that Darren Lohan was just the tip of the iceberg."

As soon as I stepped out of the car, I had three cameras in my face. Reporters were shouting questions over each other, and I still couldn't tell who was asking what. I pulled Pat closer.

Mom and Pop came out to us, throwing coats over our heads. "Walk calmly," they said, "we'll guide you."

We didn't take the coats off of our heads until somebody shut the door. "What on Earth happened?" I asked.

"As near as I've been able to piece it together," Pop said, "it went like this: Grandma didn't tell Mrs. Nichols everything, of course, but she did mention that Cassie was pregnant and couldn't explain how she got that way, and that Pat had changed sex and was also pregnant."

"So Mrs. Nichols blabbed it all over the place?" Pat asked.

"Not intentionally," Pop replied. "She just mentioned the mystery to one of her friends, and this Darren Lohan character overheard her.

"From there, he went to the hospital. Dr. Hughes couldn't tell him any more than she told us, but, still, she confirmed that she'd had three patients who were pregnant and insisted that they couldn't be. So Lohan had a name and independent corroboration, enough to make it a story."

"Should we get the whole gang together, figure out what to do?" Pat asked.

"That would be exactly the wrong course of action," Pop said. "Right now, the media only know about us. They know there are two more, but they don't have any names or faces to identify them. If you go to them, or they come here, their anonymity goes out the window. You can call them or text them if you want, but tell them to stay where they are and don't come here."

I may not have been completely used to having eight or nine friends, but it still hurt me to have to tell them to stay away. "We'll keep you out of this for as long as we can" was all the hope I had to offer, and it didn't sound like remotely enough.

For a while, it looked like we might just be able to ride this out. Sooner or later, we figured, they would get bored with the story of what still looked like just two pregnant teenage girls. Then, the evening news found a new angle.

"Teresa Bridgewater, a floor representative at Great Expectations, a maternity store, told us that she had the two girls at the center of this story inside her shop."

And there she was, talking to a reporter as if she was just talking about the weather. "Yes. they came in to browse, but said they might come back to actually buy. Then, they started talking to a customer, they called her Doctor, and the three of them sang this beautiful song, 'Gaia, Gaia,' it went."

Pop shut off the TV. "Is that bad, Pop?" Pat asked.

"Nothing's hit the fan just yet," Pop said, "but there's definitely a new pitcher warming up. Dr. Foster is part of this story now. All she has to do is do her light-ball trick in front of a window, and... well, you've seen E.T."

Never have I wished harder to have someone's cell phone number.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: From Bad to Worse

Kevin Stewart comes for a visit.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
About an hour later, Pop frowned, seeing an update to the story, with the manager of the Stardust hotel showing reporters their footage of the substitute teachers taking over the hotel and catering to the families of six teenagers, Jimmy, Stan, and Pat included. Darren Lohan, who had talked to the saleslady at the maternity store, was covering the latest update. "...Three substitute teachers who had worked at River Oak Middle and High school had set a trap for these four girls." Anger in his voice, he said. "We cannot release the identities of these children, as they are minors, but the big question remains, why them? Why in a remote hotel not yet ready to open?"

Pop turned off the television, biting his lower lip in thought. Finally, he turned to his cellphone and dialed a number. "Dr Foster, I assume you have seen the news." His voice stressed, he said. "We do not have a second to lose, we need you over at the house right away. I'll explain when you get here, we have some damage control to do."

He then dialed another number. "Frank Dean, I need your legal expertise..."

By early the following morning, Pop opened the door to the mob of reporters, who all began to shout over each other, but fell silent as Pop raised a single hand. "I will allow only one of you to enter." Firmly, he said. "As for the rest of you, I have called for a restraining order, as your constant presence is causing my stepdaughter and my daughter unhealthy stress." He motioned to oncoming police cars. "Pack it in and get off my property."

Pop pulled in Darren Lohan and urged him to sit, while the cameraman with him recorded the brief interview. "As you likely already know from your investigative reporting, my children were raped while they slept at a hotel we, another family, and a bus tour assumed was open for business about four months ago." Serious, Pop said. "Also, my son had a rare genetic condition that left him with no Y Chromosomes. This caused him to become female, and she was raped as well."

"What of the song your stepchildren were singing at Great Expectations maternity store?" Curious, Darren pressed. "I have a feeling there is more to this story..."

Pop shrugged. "Not really." Calmly, he said. "My two girls are working on a musical they are hoping the school will accept and use this year."

"A musical?" Raising an eyebrow, Darren asked.

Pop nodded, then motioned to the Spindle Harp. "Cassie, Pat... would you mind singing the song he's so interested in?"

Although I did not know what Pop was planning, I played the Spindle Harp and began to sing the Song of Gaia with Pat and Kyrl soon joining. When we were done, Kyrl smiled at Darren. "I am their obstetrician." Calmly, she said. "I am also volunteering at the school to help them with entering their musical for consideration."

"So you see, big shot." Sarcastically, Pop said. "There's no award winning story here. Just four girls who were victimized by rapists who ended their lives when they got caught." he scoffed. "Go chase a real story, if you can find one."

With that, Pop escorted the reporter and the cameraman out. Once they were gone, I asked. "Is that the last we will see of them?"

Pop sighed. "I doubt it." Softly, he said. "However, we bought ourselves some time to strengthen our story and keep them off all of our backs."

Later that day...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: We Dodge a Bullet thanks to fast thinking.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Now that the reporters were gone, Pat and I put the call out to the rest of the Sisterhood, as well as our other friends. "Can you stick around, Kyrl?" I asked. "I want everyone to meet you."

"I'd be delighted," she replied. "But could you please explain something?"

"If I can."

"Why was everyone calling that man Darren Lohan?"

"It's his name. Why, what name did you know him by?"

"That was Adam Eden."

"He's also a novelist," Pop explained. "Adam Eden is his pen name." His face turned serious. "How do you know 'Adam Eden'?"

"He's the father of my child."

I had forgotten that piece of information, what with having reporters camped out on my lawn like there was a KOA sign on the roof. But, now that I was reminded, I was sure it would come up again at some point.

******************************************


Lauren and Sarah got there first, and they were thrilled when they heard of Kyrl's connection to our cases. Lauren already had an appointment scheduled with Kyrl, and Sarah was certain she could persuade her father to let her see Kyrl instead of the obstetrician from their church.

Once everyone was there, Pat and I handed out lyric sheets, Lauren played the spindle harp, and we all sang the Song of Gaia. After introductions were made, I got us down to business. "By now, you've seen the reports. Reporters have backed off for now, but Pop says we should be ready for when they come back."

"I agree," Trish said . "In fact, I'd suggest we all start by thinking of the whole truth coming out in terms of when, not if. It's bound to happen, sooner or later."

There was a bit of an uproar following this, with the other girls swearing up and down that it wouldn't happen if we were careful, until Pop said, "She's right." Then, you could have heard a pin drop.

"We can postpone the truth getting out by being careful, yes. But one mistake is all it takes, and we're only human. Even Kyrl. We'll need a plan in place for when people find out how you really got pregnant, and the nature of the children you carry. That plan will keep you together, rather than tearing you apart playing the blame game."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: We meet with our friends.

choices: At school, Darla Darling confronts Pat.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"Do you have a plan, Mr. Pennant?" Wincing, Kyrl asked. "We sort of flapped it as we went along during our mission."

"Here we use the expression 'wing it'." With a half grin, Pop said. "Also, all those who know me call me Pop, please remember that."

Kyrl nodded. "As you wish,... Pop."

Pop nodded, then began to gather all of the evidence we had accumulated in our own little investigation, and placed it into the family safe, behind a portrait of the family. "First things first, we save everything." Serious, he said. "Destroying any or all evidence only weakens our hand if we are forced to come to the table."

"Weakens our hands?" Confused, Kyrl asked.

"We would have less chance of defending ourselves if we must face our justice system." Serious, I explained. Turning to Pop, I asked, "How do we defend ourselves against the speculation and theories of others in school and around town? Also, the reporters don't give up that easily, how do we deal with them?"

Pop scoffed. "Don't shoot down anything they come up with, unless it turns into insults or harmful rhetoric." Serious, he said. "Let them speculate all they like, the truth is oftentimes stranger than fiction anyway." He raised a finger in warning. "Just don't acknowledge anyone who happens to guess the truth, either."

"And these reporters?" Wincing, Kyrl asked.

"It is their job to report what they see as news that affects their community and beyond." Calmly, Pop explained. "Most of them are respectable, but there is a small percentage who are just after some award or fame for breaking a huge story."

"As Mr. Dorie said, secrecy is essential." Somewhat sadly, Pat said. "The very thought of aliens living among us would spark an unnecessary panic."

"Exactly." With a firm nod, Pop said. "It would also attract every crackpot alien hunter and conspiracy theorist from miles around to all of our doors."

"Not to mention the federal government." Frowning, Mom said.

"You fear your own government?" Wincing, Kyrl asked.

Pop sighed. "There is a reason why this planet was dubbed a place to hide." Softly, he said. "We are an extremely hostile species..."

"Much like we Gaians were, before the great peace accord." Sadly, Kyrl said. "Only by then, it was already too late to save ourselves from extinction."
