"You are not extinct yet!" Startling Kyrl, Pop firmly said. "You are what we humans call an endangered species, one that must be protected, and we will protect you!" He sighed. "We need to stay on the subject at hand. The bottom line is that this entire town, and the lives of the people within it, would be turned upside down if this gets out all at once."

"Wait... you said all at once." Surprised, Mom said. "What are you planning?"

Pop frowned. "I am planning to get the whole story out..." He then smiled. "In the form of the Sisterhood's first little musical."

Mom stared at Pop in confusion and disbelief, until Trish began to giggle. "I get it!" Bemused, she said. "The reporters sneaking around will only see us preparing for a musical to sell to the school, and eventually lose interest in any bigger story between the lines."

"That's the basic idea." Patiently, Pop said. "It also would explain how you are all suddenly best of friends, and how Sarah's father is a bit reluctant to allow Sarah to participate."

"What of Dr. Foster's, um,... glowing personality?" Wincing, I asked.

Pop turned to Kyrl. "I would seriously consider replacing all of the lights in your home to blue bulbs, I can get them for you, if needed." Calmly, he said. "If anyone asks, simply tell them that the blue lights calm you after a rough day."

"That way, if she does change at home, no one will blink an eye at it." Catching on, Mom said.

Again, Pop nodded. "The only issue now is to actually put together a musical."

Kyrl smiled at that. "The youngest Gaians, the last generation of our world, put together a play to honor us and our mission." Tears falling, she said. "I helped put it together, as I was a member of that generation, and it did include the Song of Gaia."

"Then let us put our plan into motion." Serious, Pop said. "For Earth and Gaia, we must, and we will, succeed." He held his hand out. "To preservation."

Kyrl shed tears, knowing the significance of that statement better than any of us, and placed her hand onto Pop's. "To preservation."

One by one, we all placed our hands in and said, "To preservation..."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The Plan

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"The first thing you'll need," Pop said, plopping a laptop in front of me, "is a script."

I thought the word script, and my fingers danced on the keyboard. When I was done, two hours had passed, and I had Act I all written out. "Like this, Kyrl?"

She came over and read what I'd written. "Astonishing! You really are a repository for our world's culture. You almost don't need me."

"You're very necessary, Kyrl," Pop said. "There will be things that teenage girls can't accomplish on their own, but that an obstetrician who is generous with her free time can help with." He turned to the others. "Okay, Cassie's taking care of the words. Who else?"

Lauren raised her hand. "I've got a background in music, so I could fill the role of composer."

"I can choreograph," Sarah said. "The Gaians incorporated dance into their worship. I can recreate their movements."

"Splendid," Pop said.

"What about us?" Trish asked. "What can we do?"

"Flats must be painted," Mom said, "props must be built. And, of course, assuming we get this thing on stage, somebody has to recite the lines and sing the songs."

I whipped out my phone. "I'm going to start posting poems on Facebook. It'll help me build a profile as a lyricist."

"That's the spirit, Cassie!" Mom said, kissing my forehead. "Even if you can't get it in front of your fellow students, you'll still get the message out."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The making of a musical.

choices: Brooklynne challenges me to run for prom queen.
Skip to the student council meeting.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
At school the next day, Pat found found herself bombarded by students from all classes, and even some teachers, all asking her if she was really running against Darla Darling for freshmen prom queen. It was quickly becoming obvious that Darla was monster both at school and, likely, at home as well.

I had heard her reply more than once, "I'm not sure, I sort of have a lot on my plate."

"Why did I have to be roped into this?" Irritated, she whispered to me later. "Now I'm the most popular girl in school, and I will be the most hated if I don't at least try to run for prom queen." She gave a silent moan then added, "Everyone is bound to do everything they can to get Darla and I together to confirm the rumors."

Throughout the early part of the day, I caught pieces of whispered conversations between girls in my classes as they spoke of getting Pat and Darla together during lunch.

"No way!" whispered one girl in homeroom. "Pat, that shy boy turned girl, is running against that bitch Darla Darling?!"

"The rumor has been spreading like wildfire, ever since someone heard Darla grumbling about how she might actually have a chance." replied another girl. "We have to get these two together, so we can confirm this rumor."

"Darla actually has some competition this year?!" Surprised, a girl in her second class asked. "Who is it?!"

"That shy boy turned girl, Pat Pennant." replied yet another girl. "You know that tiny, frail little boy with the rare condition that killed all his Y Chromosomes..." The girl smiled. "There's talk of getting them to meet again during lunch."

In the halls, I overheard some of the freshmen girls talking as well, and could only imagine that Pat overheard conversations of her own. "Darla has a competitor for freshman prom queen?!" Whispering, one girl asked. "I'm surprised she hasn't been scared off yet. Who is it?!"

"That shy boy with the rare condition, Pat Pennant." Whispering another girl replied. "He's a girl now, and quite the looker." She smiled. "Not bad for being born a boy."

The first girl giggled then whispered, "It would be a hoot if her sister, Cassie, ran against Brooklynne for junior prom queen!"

I even heard a number of teachers whispering about Pat and even me running for prom queen against Darla and Brooklynne, making me worry more and more for us both.

At lunch, Pat and I took our turn at the lunch line and purchased what we wanted, before turning around to find Darla walking up to her with a cross look on her face. I winced, having a feeling what was going to happen, and stayed close, in case she needed saving. For a moment, the two looked at each other while the students around them, especially the girls, stopped what they were doing to watch. The silence was maddening to everyone, including Pat and Darla, it seemed. Finally, Pat broke the silence, but not in a way she had intended.

"Um... May the best girl win." Extending her hand, she said.

Low gasps and whispers were heard and she immediately regretted her words, as it only confirmed the rumors that Pat was entering the prom queen competition. Only it had already been said, and it was too late to rephrase.

Only, to mine and everyone's surprise, Darla slowly accepted, shaking Pat's hand. This brought on even more gasps and whispers from the crowd. One teacher, I noticed, nearly dropped her tray in surprise, seeing this, a girl with the courage to run against the most feared and hated bully of the freshmen class. The irony of it was too great for her to miss. She quietly placed her tray down and picked up her cellphone camera to take a picture, knowing that the other teachers might not believe her. Finally, Darla responded and everyone strained listen.

"I don't like competition, Pat." Frowning, she told her. "Looking at you, it's easy to see you have a fair chance, and that drives me crazy. Worse, you are cute for being born a boy." She blushed, bringing more gasps, as she then added. "Still, the student council made me promise to invite you over to their next meeting, so we can all talk about this."

"Me and my sister?" Hopefully, you asked.

Darla shook her head, not moving her eyes from Pat's. "Just you." Firmly, she said. "With you being pregnant, and rumors of you working on a musical, it is a lot of stress to deal with. The council wants to be certain you are up to the task of running for prom queen."

Pat blushed at that, uncertainty on her face. She discretely turned to me, but I could only shrug, as it was her decision to make. The other students around me, I could see, were all anxiously waiting for Pat's response. One girl from the freshman class mouthed, 'say yes!' A number of other students and even some teachers also quietly urged Pat to accept. i could only imagine the amount of peer pressure Pat was feeling. Finally, Pat turned to Darla, still holding her hand and managed a polite smile. "I'll have to check my schedule." Politely, she said. "If I can squeeze in the time, then yes, I will talk with the student council, but not alone."

Darla also managed a tiny smile as she then released Pat's hand. "They are not going to bite you, Pat." Ice returning to her voice, she said. "The meeting is right after school, today, in the student council's office. I hope you... and your sister are able to come and meet with us." With that, she walked away, not saying a word to anyone else...

As I watched her leave, I had a much better idea what Darla was up to. She had plans to convince the council that Pat could not enter the prom queen competition, due to everything else she is dealing with. It was a bit underhanded, but it was unfortunately within school rules.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Pat and Darla Face Off

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The girls were halfway finished with lunch by the time I sat down. "Is it on?" Fae asked. "Is Pat in the running for prom queen?"

"She's thinking it over," I replied. "But the stress of knowing almost the entire school wants her to do it can't be helping."

My first clue about what was about to happen was how quiet it suddenly got. The cafeteria is noisy almost by necessity, and that many people don't all shut up at once for no reason.

My second clue was the scent of expensive perfume that hit my nose. Not many girls could afford more than the knockoff fragrance.

"Don't you think you have enough on your plate, Pennant?" asked the unmistakable voice of Brooklynne Dietrich.

I'm eating for two, I thought, but didn't say.

"You're knocked up, and you're trying to keep your grades up. That would be enough for most people. And I've heard rumors that you're writing a play?"

I nodded. No sense wasting a perfectly good lie on that.

"And a little bird told me you were actually considering the possibility of running for prom queen? Tell me I was misinformed, that you have some grasp of your place on the totem pole."

I sighed, put my fork down, and turned to face her. "What's in it for me?"

"Well, the student council would like to have a talk with you. Wouldn't want you working yourself into a miscarriage, now, would we?"

"Fine. I'm going there with Pat anyway."

Satisfied, she turned and walked away, wearing a smirk that begged for someone to slap it.

I let her take three steps before I said, "Brooklynne."

She turned as I got up.

"I'll tell you what I'll tell them: Out of all the things I'm doing,... kicking your ass in a popularity contest is, by far, the least challenging."

I'm sure she said something after that, but too many people were cheering for me to hear her.

"You enjoyed that," Trish said, as I sat down.

"Damn right," I replied.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Brooklynne challenges me to run for prom queen.

choices: No but we feel we have no choice.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Pat and I had a few things in our favor while seeing the student council. First, the president of the council was a longtime acquaintance of mine, Sarah Stone. She was a senior, standing at six foot even at the age of fifteen, with shoulder length black hair and green eyes. She knew about my pregnancy and the cover story, but not the entire truth. It was not that I could not trust her, Pop simply wanted as few to know the whole truth as possible. Second, Principal Lily Switch always oversaw the council meetings, and had a strong sense of right and wrong.

Upon entering the student council office, I was greeted by Principal Switch. She was short, almost exactly my height, with silver hair tied up into a neat bun on the top of her head, and blue eyes peering through half-moon glasses. Many students and even teachers had called her "the fearless Ms. Switch," as she feared no one and she knew how to hold her own. "How are you and Pat coping so far?" Kindly, she asked. "Being pregnant is one thing, but slowly turning into a girl and then getting pregnant is quite the experience, I would say."

"That's an understatement." Blushing, Pat said.

"Tell me then, why put so much on your plate?" Softly, Ms. Switch asked. "Are the rumors on the news about a musical in the making true?"

"That much is true, but I don't care much for the speculation." Sighing, I replied. "Pop was forced to file a restraining order."

"A misunderstanding led everyone to hope then believe that I was running for freshman prom queen against Darla Darling." Wincing, Pat said. "As the rumors spread, my sister got roped up into it as well, through the hopes of the students."

"Now we have the entire student body literally cheering us on." Shrugging, I added. "No pressure there, right?"

Sarah giggled. "We all heard those rumors being spread like wildfire." Bemused, she said. "You and your sister are in quite a pickle."

"Which is why we are holding this meeting." Turning serious, Ms. Switch said. "However, you both need to decide now if you are running or not."

With that said, Ms. Switch and Sarah took their seats as the rest of the council entered. There were eight students in all, each representing the freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors. Sarah was the student council president. She and her twin sister, Emily represented the senior class. The Rafferty twins, Mike and Bill represented the junior class. Two girls named Ina Watt and Tia Zoe represented the sophomore class. Finally, a boy and a girl named Dawn Moore and Tex Scott represented the freshmen class. I really did not know most of them, but that did not matter at the time. What mattered was getting this foolishness behind us.

"This meeting is called to order." Serious, Sarah said. "We are gathered at this meeting to determine if Pat and Cassie Pennant are or are not entering the running for freshmen and junior prom queen this school year." She turned to us. "As you have noticed, neither Darla Darling or Brooklynne Dietrich are attending this meeting. You are both free to speak your minds, without interruption or intimidation."

"Hopes are high among the students, as these two... individuals have proven to be rather troublesome and difficult." Serious, Tia Zoe said. "The choice is, of course, yours to make."

"No pressure..." Frowning, Pat muttered.

"I will make this simple." Firmly but kindly, Ms. Switch said. "Do you or do you not intend to run for freshmen and junior prom queen, with everything else on your plate?"

Pat and I turned to each other and slowly nodded. We both seemed to have the same answer in mind, as we turned back to Ms Switch and replied....
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The Student Council

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"I guess we have to."

"Are you sure about this?" Principal Switch asked.

"We didn't want this fight, ma'am," I said, "but it looks like we've been drafted."

"Very well," Sarah said. "Meeting adjourned."

When we opened the door to the student council office, it seemed like most of the student body was waiting for us. "They'll do it," Tia said , to thunderous applause.

"This is all such a new experience for me," I confided to Principal Switch. "Before I got pregnant, I don't think half the school even knew I go here."

"Perhaps your poem had something to do with it," she said. "It's gone... bacterial?"

"Viral." I decided to check for myself. "Holy crap!"

"More than you thought?"

I showed her. "Lin-Manuel Miranda is following me."

"Does he go here?"

"He's a famous singer and songwriter."

"Impressive. I'll have to have a look at this play you're working on."

"I'll have a copy of the script on your desk by Friday."

When we got to our friends, I don't know if they were happier about the prom or my new fan. I was just glad that Kevin was there.

At home, we told the folks about everything that had happened. "Don't worry, girls," Mom said, "we shouldn't have any trouble renting you Empire gowns."

"Huh?" Pat asked.

"They're tightest just below the breasts, loose and flowing under that. Just what you'll be looking for when it's time for the prom."

"Later," Pat said, as she trudged up the stairs. "Too tired."

"Two too tired," I said, following her.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: No but we feel we have no choice.

choices: Stewart and Jimmy ask Pat and I out at school.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Pat and I still had our own bedrooms, but at least there was less fighting over the upstairs bathroom, now that I had a stepsister rather than a stepbrother. The first night Pat became a girl, she did not want to sleep alone. Not that I could blame her, she had gone through more than any of us. She had been violated as a boy, and turned into a girl to ensure her and her unborn child's survival. The Gaians had given her a certain calming factor to help her adapt. In a way, I was envious.

"What a day!" Plopping onto my bed, I muttered. "At least I don't have any homework to deal with on top of it all."

I was considering whether to change for bed or just go to sleep until dinner, when the sound of the doorbell reached my ears. Pat came out of her room, hearing the chimes as well, and threw me a curious look as we both asked, "Now what...?"

Curious, I came a quarter down the stairs, so I could hear what was happening but not be seen by our unknown visitor. I was surprised when I heard Stewart's voice at the door. "Good afternoon, err, Pop is it?" nervous, he said. "I'm Stewart Tucker, and I believe you know Jimmy."

"How can I help you gentlemen?" politely, Pop asked.

"We were hoping we could talk to you about Cassie and Patrica, sir." Sounding even more nervous, Jimmy said. "We would like to ask if we could, um..."

"If you have something to ask, spit it out." Firmly but kindly, Pop said. "I am strict, but I carry the grace of God with me."

"We are asking for your blessings to ask your girls out on a date." Rather quickly, Stewart blurted out. "We thought it only right if we discussed it with you first."

I blushed at that, and turned to Pat, who was at the top of the stairs, blushing as well. Only a few days ago, both Pat and I were nobody, and now we were practically a household name around school, with two suitors at our door! We paused to listen as Pop chuckled, something we were not expecting at all.

"I admire your courage and honesty, gentlemen." Calmly, dad said. "I have nothing against you asking the girls out on a date, as you have proven yourselves loyal in your friendships with them. However, as you must know, they have already had a trying day, so you will have to ask them tomorrow. Good day, gentleman."

With that, I heard the door close before I saw Mom looking up at Pat and me from the bottom of the stairs. There was an amused smile on her face. "Well, there you have it, girls." Bemused, she said. "Your crushes have confessed their feelings towards you."

Pop came into view, also with an amused smile. "Your lives are changing quickly, but that does not mean you have to move quickly to keep up." Kindly, he said. "if you are not ready for your first date with your crushes, let them know..."

"Dinner will be here in ten minutes." Smiling, Mom said. "We ordered pizza."

Mom and Pop then walked away, leaving Pat and me with a big decision to make. I did not know if I was ready for my first date, and, from the look on Pat's face, I doubted she knew herself...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: First Dates?

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"Mom tells me you two had quite the day today," Pop said as we ate.

We nodded. "Pat and I both got roped into going out for the prom queen of our grades."

"Mainly because the favorites are a couple of bitches," Pat added.

"Language!" Mom said.

"That is the censored version, Mom," I said.

"How's the play coming along?"

"Ms. Switch is interested. And Lin-Manuel Miranda is following me on Facebook."

Pop almost choked on his pizza. "The Lin-Manuel Miranda? Hamilton? Moana?"

I nodded. "It's one thing to hear your poem's gone viral, but to have an A-list celebrity say you've got his attention?"

"And then your crushes come and let you know they're just as interested in you as you are in them?" Pop said. "That would wear you out, even if you weren't pregnant." He sighed. "Maybe you've got enough to worry about without prom."

"Prom's months away," I said, "and I'm almost done writing the play. I don't know if we're ready for our first dates yet, though. But that's a matter of emotional readiness, that's all."

Pop put his hand on mine. "Never let it be said that I wanted you to date before you wanted to. Just let them down easy, don't let them dangle."

"We won't, Pop. Besides, when we are ready, we wouldn't want them to think of us as using them."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Dinner conversation.

choices: I offered her to join us.
I pulled her into a warm hug.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The following day at school, Pat was in her school uniform of a dark blue pleated skirt and light blue blouse with a dark blue blazer. We approached our lockers to find Stewart and Jimmy nervously waiting for us. Here we go, Sighing, I thought.

Stewart was the first to talk, but I raised my hand, stopping his question. "We heard you talking to Pop yesterday afternoon." Politely, I said. "I have a crush on you, too, but..." I bit my lip. "I'm not ready for my first date quite yet."

"You two will be the first we ask when that day comes." Softly, Pat added. She smiled, blushing. "I've got feelings for you too, Jimmy, so... rain check?"

Both Stewart and Jimmy seemed disappointed but smiled, taking it well. "When you are ready, Cassie, call me." He handed me a piece of paper that I assumed held his phone number.

Blushing, I replied, "Count on it."

"That goes for you too, Pat." Smiling, Jimmy said. "You know my number."

Blushing as well, Pat nodded. "When I am ready, I'll call."

With that out of the way, we began to gather what we needed for our first class. I opened my locker to find a note on a torn piece of paper someone had slipped through the door. It read: I need your help. With my newly acquired knowledge of arts, I recognized the handwriting to be Nicole Terry, one of the Queen Bees who hang around with Brooklynne. She was rather tall, with long forest brown hair and emerald green eyes. Out of the entire bunch, she was likely the most tolerable. However, the note did not reveal much, other than she needed help from me for some mysterious reason.

"What did you find?" Curious, Pat asked.

"A note from Nicole Terry, asking for help." Honestly, I replied. "Only it didn't reveal much."

Pat handed me a torn note of her own. "I found this in my locker." Frowning, she said. "it looks to be the same handwriting."

I looked at the note. It read: Meet me at lunch, I'm scared.

Pat and I exchanged worried looks, and decided to try to figure out what was going on and why she needed our help. Only Nicole Terry did not show up for school, and it was clear from the death glares I got from Brooklynne that she somehow thought I was involved. The majority of the morning was uneventful, and soon we were at lunch, where I was sitting with my friends, including Pat and Jimmy. I had to admit, I was a bit anxious to find out why Nicole Terry needed help from my sister and me. The answer came when Nicole entered the cafeteria, looking rather ill.

"There you are, Nicole!" Irritated, Brooklynne snapped. "Where have you been all day?!"

Nicole winced, not answering her, and walked straight up to our table, where she looked down at Pat and me, nervously rubbing one arm. "Um... Do you mind if I join you?" Tearfully, she whispered. She touched her lower abdomen, tears falling. "I think I meet the requirements to join your little sisterhood..."

She began to softly sob where she stood. It did not take a genius to catch on that she was pregnant, and I stood from my seat...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The Next Day, at School

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
I figured that what she needed, right then, was warm human contact, so I hugged her. She hugged me back, tightly, so I guess I was right.

Meanwhile, Trish stood up and moved down the table, so Nicole could sit between me and Sarah. Fae offered her her milk, which she took with a "Thanks."

I wanted to hear whatever it was she had to say, and I only got as far as "Would you like - " before she spoke.

"I was at a party," she said. "I think there was something in the punch. I don't remember much of it."

She took a drink. "When I woke up the next morning, my blouse was buttoned wrong, my bra was inside out, and my panties were half off. I knew something had happened. I called the hostess, and she told me she'd kept the hounds off me until my brother came and got me." A shake of her head told us that, whoever that guy was, he wasn't her brother. "N-now I'm p-p-pregnant, and I don't know whose it is. I don't know what to do."

She broke down and cried. I rubbed her back, letting her get it out. "Why did I go?" she asked. "Why did I drink so - "

"This wasn't you," Amy said. "Girls get raped at parties and at home. Girls get raped when they're drunk and when they're sober. Girls get raped when they run around naked and when they wear burqas. It's the rapist's fault, not yours."

"We decided we wanted to have our babies," Sarah said. "Maybe you don't want to. That's okay. It's up to you."

By this time, apparently, Brooklynne got tired of wondering what Nicole was up to, so she and the Queen Bees came to us. "Nicole," she said, "where were you all morning? Why did you give me the brush-off? And what in the name of God are you doing at the losers' table?"

"She came to us," I said, "not to you. Maybe you should ask yourself why that is."

"We'll be meeting tonight at our house," Pat said to Nicole, "working on our play. You're welcome to join us. Maybe we can dig up some information on your attacker."

"I'll think about it," Nicole said, but the slight smile told me she was grateful for the offer, and that she'd probably made up her mind already.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: I pulled her into a warm hug.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"You didn't answer my question, Nicole!" Forcefully, Brooklynne said.

"Leave her alone." Standing up, Pat demanded. "She does not answer to you."

Brooklynne turned red. "You little freak of nature!" Irritated, she yelled. "Nicole is one of us! I have half a mind to..."

"Half a mind to do what, Miss Dietrich?" Startling her, Ms Switch demanded. "Also, who are you calling a freak of nature? Your grades hardly mark you as an expert in any given field."

Ouch... Wincing, I thought.

Brooklynne turned around with a cross look on her face, only to cover it quickly to avoid the stone cold glare from the principal. At that moment, there was no doubt in my mind why many had dubbed her the fearless Ms Switch. "It's just a little misunderstanding, ma'am." Glaring at Nicole and my friends, she said.

"You look me in the eye when you talk to me, young lady." Sternly, Ms Switch said. "I have lived through and survived horrors that would give you maddening nightmares." She motioned to Brooklynne's favorite table. "Finish your lunch and leave your classmates in peace, or you will be answering to me."

As Brooklynne reluctantly returned to her table, Ms. Switch leaned in close to me and whispered, "I am watching over you, Miss Pennant. Do have a care."

I looked her in the eye and gasped as I saw them turn all blue with a dull shine before returning to their original color of brown. As she then walked away without a word, I realized how the substitute teachers were able to infiltrate the school. Our principal was a Gaian.

The rest of the school day was uneventful, with the exception of Nicole sticking pretty close to my friends and I. Brooklynne and her remaining Queen Bees gave her and us death glares when we caught their eyes, but they did not make a move, likely due to Ms Switch's warning. Finally, the day ended, and we all met up at my house with Nicole nervously showing up with Dr Kyrl Foster. "I picked her up, as you had asked." Calmly, Kyrl said. "I told her parents that she was volunteering to help with a school play."

"They- they don't know yet." Tearfully, Nicole said. "I'm trying to find a way to break it to them."

"The sooner you tell them, the better." Honestly, I said. "We'll be there for you, if you want."

Nicole teared up, a grateful smile on her face. "Thank you, all of you." Timidly, she said. "I have to admit, I was afraid you would reject me because of all I had said as a Queen Bee..."

"That's in the past." Serious, Pop said. "You need to focus on the present, it is the only time you have in which to act."

Nicole nodded, then turned to the Spindle Harp. "What is this musical you are putting together?"

"It is a musical about a dying world." With an air of sadness, Kyrl said. "It reflects upon the rising pollution, hate, and inequality we are seeing here on Earth."

"Basically, the musical speaks of a desperate people with a desperate plan to preserve what is left of them." Sadly, I said. "Their art, culture, technology, religion, philosophy..."

"A warning that if we are not careful, we will face the same fate." Serious, Mom added.

"It sounds intense." Looking impressed, Nicole said. "How can I help?"

"We have the beginnings of a poem you can help with turning into a song." Kindly, Pat said. "Tell me what you think."

Nicole listened and was surprised by the words of the poem...

The realization came too late, no children will be born, we sealed our own fate.
To a primitive world dubbed a place to hide, it is our last hope to survive.
Young women with great hearts we must find, grant them the gift of what we leave behind.

"So... people from this alien world will be looking for young women to pass on everything their world was." Curious, Nicole said. "Why...?"

"In their religion, it was three virgin born daughters who spread the word of right and wrong, with the help of a single wise man, instead of three wise men spreading the word through a single virgin born son." Serious, Pat said. "As you can see, we put a lot of thought into this play."

Nicole was silent for a moment. "I'd leave the poem out." Kindly, she said. "We don't want to step too much on religion, as some people are sensitive about that."

"I know that from experience." Sadly, Sarah said.

Nicole nodded. "You have Bible-thumping parents, too, huh?" Softly, she asked. "What did they do when they found out about your pregnancy?"

"They kicked her out." Softly, Mom said. "Only my husband set them straight."

Pop cleared his throat, trying to hide a blush. "I did nothing more than remind her father of the grace of God." Calmly, he said. "We have a lot of props and landscape scenes to make and paint, before our audition performance before the student council next month."

"You already made an appointment to audition the play?" surprised, Pat asked.

Pop chuckled. "No, Ms. Switch did." Smiling, he said. "She seemed quite interested in it."

"I think I know the reason why." Wincing, I said. I turned to Kyrl, which Pop noticed and sighed.

"I take it you knew about Ms. Switch, Dr Foster." Softly, he said.

Kyrl nodded. "I knew... She was my teacher back at home."

Nicole turned between Pop and I. "What about Principal Switch?" Confused, she asked.

Pop shook his head then smiled. "It's hard to hide anything from Ms. Switch." Bemused, he said. "She knew about the play long before we revealed it was in the making."

Nicole smiled, shaking her head. "I might have known." Softly, she said. "Where do we start?"

Pop smiled and replied, "We start with..."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Welcome to the Sisterhood.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Lauren took out some sketches. "We've got some plans for our costumes," she said. "Unfortunately, none of us are seamstresses."

Nicole smiled. "My folks are tailors. I was learning how to run a sewing machine while I was learning how to read and write."

"We don't need theater-quality work at this point," Pop said. "Just something to give the student council an idea of what to expect."

Nicole took the sketches. "Just good enough? I can do that by Friday."

As she looked over the sketches, I pulled Pop aside. "We almost blabbed the big secret."

"I know," Pop said. "I got so used to everyone being on the same page, I forgot that Nicole only just picked up the book."

"Good thing we've got the plan."

"What's she like?"

I knew what he was asking. "She gets good grades."

"So she might figure things out."

"I'd say it's all but certain."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: costumes.

choices: Pat and I go on our first date.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
It was Thursday afternoon, crunch time for piecing everything together before we were expected to show Principal Switch the highlights of the musical we had put together. We were all working hard on what we had to do, talking almost excitedly among ourselves but stopped as Nicole walked in with a tear-stained face, and Mom doing her best to comfort her.

"What happened?" Worried, I asked.

Nicole began to sob again, as Mom led her to the downstairs bathroom before returning to speak to us. "Nicole has figured out the truth." To our surprise, she said. "She saw Dr. Foster in her light form when she visited her office, and sought out the advice of Principal Lila Switch."

Pop sighed. "I take it she knows the entire truth now?"

Mom nodded, a smile forming onto her face. "Only she felt great empathy towards the Gaians' plight, and could not stop crying for them." Tearing up herself, she said. "She went to her parents in that state, and told them about her pregnancy, fearing she would be kicked out or worse."

"What happened?" Wincing, Pat asked.

Mom's smile grew. "Principal Lila Switch went with her for support, and now her parents are fully on Nicole's side." Calmly, she said. "She told them about the musical, and her father found it an ironic parody to their beliefs and what we are doing to our own planet."

"I thought Nicole said she had Bible-thumping parents." Confused, Trish said.

"That is what Nicole thought." Softly, Mom said. "It turns out that there are several religions within her family." She sighed, smiling. "Her parents are modern Wicca, an Earth-based religion, similar to the Gaians, which is why her father thought it ironic."

"Do her parents know the whole truth?" Worried, I asked.

"No, they just know about the musical, and of our similar plights with pregnancy." Entering the room, Nicole said. "I want to be a part of this more than ever." She dabbed at her tears. "To think that you carry the final, flickering hope of an entire world inside of you..."

I nodded, knowing all too well how overwhelming it was. "Welcome to the Sisterhood, Nicole." Smiling, I said. "You can help us finish up the costumes."

Nicole smiled. "Thanks, guys... for- for being there for me when I needed help the most."

"That's what sisters do." smiling, Pat said. "We be there for each other."

We all shared a group hug then got back to work, again talking almost excitedly among ourselves, while Mom and Pop watched, smiling. "Their circle of friends is getting bigger." Softly, Pop said. "Our girls are growing up."

Mom nodded. "It is indeed."

Time seemed to fly after that before...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Days Later

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
At last, the time had arrived for our performance. When we got up on stage, however, I was surprised to see unfamiliar faces in the audience. "Does anybody know who they are?" I whispered.

Nicole took a look. "That's Mrs. Norris," she said. "She's the Drama teacher. The kids are the Drama Club. I guess they want a say on the play."

I should have anticipated their presence. After all, putting on plays was their territory. Of course they'd be interested. "Alright, everybody," I said, "break a leg."

"Why did you tell them to hurt themselves?" Kyrl asked.I

"It's a showbiz superstition," I explained. "It's bad luck to wish a performer good luck before they get on stage."

The show went well, I thought. Certainly, Ms. Switch seemed to be moved. Of course, from where she was sitting, only we on stage could see that her eyes were blue and glowing.

I had an amazing experience as I sang the last song for my character. I held the baby doll prop as I sang:

Little baby, please understand
I won't be there for you
When you become a man
This generation may be the last, we fear
Unless we reach another world so near
We need them so... hear our woe...
Take these broken dreams
And lift our hopes up again
Of a life lived so free
When we hear the angels sing
We'll know Earth has opened up their arms
And let us in

Little baby, a kiss goodbye
I must leave to right the wrongs
To give you a better life
Little baby, it's all we have to hold
A desperate plan to save our race
So pray for the brave and bold
We rely on them so...
Take these broken dreams
And lift our hopes up again
From extinction, we'll be free
And when we hear the angels sing
We'll know Earth has opened up their arms
And let us in...

As I sang, I felt somehow outside of myself. I wasn't just Cassie Pennant, performing a play: I was also this grieving mother, sending her baby to be born of another woman. Suddenly, I was sure of it: This woman's child was the one growing inside me.

My son.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: We performed for Principal Switch.

choices: Video of our play makes it to the news.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
When the play was finished, there was not a dry eye in the audience, not even Brooklynne or Darla, though they tried to hide it, as we were all rewarded with a standing ovation. I smiled, then scanned the audience and almost fainted! There, standing by the rear door, was a tall man with short black hair, beard, mustache and brown eyes, in a suit. It was Lin-Manuel Miranda! He had come to see our play, and he was applauding!

Oh my goodness! Breathless, I thought. Oh my goodness!

I wanted to scream in delight, but, just as quickly as I had noticed him, he handed an usher a note and casually walked out. I wanted to chase after him, but I was cut off by Mrs Norris as she quickly approached me on the stage with an air of excitement in her eye, as principal Switch did the same from where she had been sitting.

"That was incredible!" Tearfully smiling, Mrs Norris said. "The Drama Club will bring the house down with this magnificent script and music!"

"Excuse me?" Taken back, I demanded.

"The play does not belong to you or the Drama club, Mrs Norris." Firmly, Mrs Switch said. "Do not assume that every play auditioned is school property." She motioned to my friends and I. "The play belongs exclusively to the girls who created it."

Mrs Norris huffed as if insulted. "I was not suggesting ownership." Frankly, she said. "It is just that all plays are usually performed by the Drama Club."

"And this play will be." Smiling, Mrs Switch said. "There are many key parts that will require the expertise of your students."

Catching on, I said, "Of course... none of us really have any real performing experience, so we will need tutoring before the big opening."

"As our tutors, you will have a huge bragging point on your future resumes." Smiling, Pat said. "Especially if the play turns out to be widely successful."

Mrs Norris smiled kindly, something I was not expecting. "Now that is the right attitude of true prom queens and leaders." Serious, she said. "Sorry, but I had to test you. Most people who come up with a hit performance immediately fall into a power trip and refuse to share the spotlight with anyone." She motioned to her students who were all smiling. "That does not fly in my Drama Club."

"Does that mean we are in the Drama club, too?" Whispering, Pat asked.

Mrs Switch giggled before whispering into My ear, "Gaians have twice the strength and endurance as average humans."

"But we're not..." Whispering back, I began.

Mrs Switch smiled and whispered, "No, you are not, but carrying a Gaian child, you inherit some of those traits." She giggled and added, "By the time your children are born, even Pat will be able to run circles around a triathlete."

I smiled at that, then turned to Mrs Norris. "Where do we sign up for tutoring?"

The members of the drama club cheered, but paused as Brooklynne blurted out, "Sign us up for the drama club! We'll perform that play far better than all those pretenders!"

Mrs Norris shook her head. "Don't you think you have enough on your plate, Dietrich?" Quoting Brooklynne's own words to me days before, she asked. "You're stuck up, and you're trying to keep your grades up." Her smile turned into a grin. "That would be enough for most people. And now you want a part in a play, just because someone else thought it up?"

Brooklynne gasped as if slapped in the face, then turned red before storming out of the auditorium with her Queen Bees reluctantly following. After they were gone, Mrs Switch turned to Mrs Norris with a grin. "You enjoyed that, didn't you?"

"Every bit of it." Grinning back, Mrs Norris replied. She turned to me. "Confidentially, you are not the only one who thinks she's an asshole."

I smiled at that, as the usher handed me Lin-Manuel Miranda's note.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Queen bees and drama queens

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Ms. Pennant,

I saw your show, and I was impressed. I think you and your friends have bright futures ahead of you. If you need help in any way, please don't hesitate to call my private number.

Lin-Manuel Miranda

After that was a phone number.

My scream drew the Sisterhood, Ms. Switch, Mrs. Norris, and the Drama Club. "Are you okay, Cassie? What's wrong?"

"Nothing's wrong," I said, handing Mrs. Norris the note. "Read it."

When she finished, she handed the note back to me and said, "Congratulations, Cassie. Your sister's prediction appears to be well founded."

I showed everyone else the note. It was the most excited I'd seen the Sisterhood since we learned where our babies came from.

Walking out of the theater, Pat and I were met by Kevin and Jimmy. "How'd it go?"

"It went well. We'll be putting on a full production. We've even got our first fan."

Kevin read the note. "Awesome!" He picked me up and spun in a circle.

When he put me down, I said, "Isn't there something you wanted to ask me?"

"Huh? Oh, yeah: Would you like to go out?"

I wrapped my arms around him. "I'd like nothing better."

Then Jimmy asked Pat, and got a similar response.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Lin-Manuel Miranda's note.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
That night, Mom smiled as she got out one of the nice dresses I had picked out and passed it to me, which I put on. "I must admit, I'm a little surprised you are going on a date so soon after all this had started." smiling, Mom said. "Where are you two going?"

"I'm not sure." Honestly, I replied. "Only, Pop told me to take some cash, just in case Kevin and/or Jimmy get in over their heads trying to impress us."

Mom giggled. "A wise decision." Smiling, she said. "Trish came over to help Pat get ready."

I began to apply a light amount of makeup to my face before painting my nails. "That's good, because I don't think Pat has makeup and dresses down just yet."

After spraying a modest amount of perfume on myself, I slipped into a pair of three inch pumps and looked in the mirror. The silk blue dress accented my curves very well, and had a dipping V-neck collar that showed just a hint of cleavage, with a slit along my left leg that revealed just enough to be a bit of a tease to the boys. Mom stood behind me with a bemused smile. "You and Pat have come a long way in a very short while." Softly, she said. "I'm proud of you both."

"Thanks, Mom. Let's see how Pat looks."

I stepped out of my bedroom and froze, as I caught my first glimpse of Pat blushing in an elegant gown of her own. It was much like my own dress, but ivory, with white silk lace and a moderate V collar that showed off a little cleavage. There was a slit on the left side of the dress that stopped just below the thigh. The sash was white with an ivory trim which Trish had neatly tied into a cute bow in the back. "You look incredible in that dress, Pat." Smiling, I complimented.

Trish stood behind Pat smiling. "More than any mortal man deserves."

I giggled at that with Trish following while Pat only blushed more. "Nervous, Pat?" Bemused, Mom asked. "It's normal."

Pat managed a smile. "It just seems like a little much for a first date." Nervous, she said. "I feel like I'm going to the prom."

"If you think the dress you are wearing is over the top, trust me, you haven't seen anything yet." Smiling, Trish said. "This is modest by comparison to prom dresses today."

Just then, the doorbell rang. "It's showtime, girls." Smiling, Mom said.

"Go get 'em, tigress." Lightly pushing Pat forward, Trish said. "Show Jimmy your feminine side."


We both walked down the stairs to greet Jimmy and Kevin, who were both wearing handsome black suits. Their jaws dropped as they saw us. "Wow... " Stunned, Jimmy said. "You look breathtaking, Pat."

"The stars in the night sky pale by comparison." looking at me, Kevin said. "I am humbled you chose me, out of an ocean of men..."

"Okay, Romeo." Firmly but kindly, Pop said. "I think Cassie gets the idea."

Pat and I giggled. "You look rather handsome yourself, Jimmy." Blushing, Pat said.

"You look dashing this evening, Kevin." Calmly, I said. "To where are you whisking us fair maidens, on our first adventure together?"

"To the movies, and then dinner." simply, Kevin replied. "They are playing the new hit movie, The Reluctant Princess." He chuckled at Jimmy, suddenly blushing.

"It's about a common boy who was transformed by magic into a royal princess, as the queen needed an heir." Blushing, Jimmy said. "Kevin thought that it might give Pat and Cassie some perspective in her new lives, as, in a way, they are royal princesses now."

Pat and I blushed at that, we never thought of it that way. We were the last hope of a dying race so, in a way, Kevin was right, we were royalty in a way. "Flattery will get you boys nowhere." Teasing, I countered.

Unknown to us until after the date, Pop had spotted Darla Darling and Brooklynne Dietrich peering into one of our windows and nodded at Mom, who then nodded at Trish, out of sight on the stairs. She pulled out a cellphone and dialed a number. "The Queen Bee and the Drama Queen are on the scene." Serious, she said. "Tell the Sisterhood to be ready, in case they decide to try to start trouble."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The Sisterhood is watching.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"Oh, my," Pat said.

We were looking at the poster for The Reluctant Princess. It was a lenticular poster, so the picture changed depending on the angle. One way, it showed a boy wearing the same sort of clothes Pat had worn as a boy. The other, it showed a beautiful young woman in a sparkling blue gown. "I feel like I showed up in my bathrobe," I said.

"Come on, Jimmy," Kevin said, "let's show our dates how special they are."

The boys escorted us away from the poster. "FYI," I whispered to Pat, "that is a prom dress."

Kevin asked me what I wanted from the concession stand, and Jimmy did the same with Pat. Then, the sent us to wait in the lobby while they got everything. It seemed unnecessary to me, but, hey, I didn't buy the ticket.

"Oh! Excuse me, I'm awfully sorry, miss."

I turned to see what had happened. Apparently, the janitor had accidentally hit a young girl in the face with the business end of his mop. Apologizing profusely, he took her to one of the restrooms to wash up. Oddly, however, he pulled her to the opposite side of the building, even though there was a restroom just past us.

Whatever. The staff know their business. And, anyway, Kevin and Jimmy were here with the food and drinks.

****************************************


We had a great time. The movie showed how the young man in question was picked up in his sleep, and changed for reasons he didn't know. This movie is closer to our story than Kevin knows, I thought. Or, at least, closer than he ought to know.

Now, I wasn't averse to Kevin knowing our secrets. I felt he ought to know what he was in for, after all. But I certainly hadn't told him anything. So was it a coincidence? And, if it wasn't, how did he find out?

As the movie let out, another peculiar incident happened. We walked out to find Darcy Darling standing in the lobby, soaking wet from two huge sodas. I wondered how that could have happened.

After we left, the janitor removed his baseball cap and mask, revealing it was Nicole. "The eagles have left the perch," she said into a walkie-talkie, "and are in search of a meal. Drama Queen has been sidelined. Be ready."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: At the movies.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Kevin and Jimmy took Pat and I to Momma Mia's, a popular Italian restaurant near the theater, where we were greeted by Momma Mia herself. She was tall and pleasantly plump, with long salt and pepper hair and blue eyes. "Young love is always a blessing to see." Gushing, she said in a heavy Italian accent. "It's even more of a romantic blessing when your dates buy out the entire restaurant just for their first date."

Pat and I blushed at the first part of Mia's statement, but gasped at the second part and turned to Kevin and Jimmy, shocked. Kevin blushed just as much as I. "Pop helped out a little."

"A little...?" surprised, Pat asked.

"Okay, he helped out a lot." Blushing as well, Jimmy said. "We wanted to make sure we show you two a really great time."

"The restaurant is yours, little love birds." Smiling, Mia said. "I will bring you some menus."

Kevin led me to one booth while Jimmy led Pat to another. shortly after, a young waitress approached, handing Kevin and me menus. As we were looking them over, I noticed more young workers pulling the shades down over all of the windows. I spotted someone standing outside but I did not catch who it was. Just as I was tempted to investigate, the lights were dimmed and a single candle lantern was placed on Pat's and my tables.

"Nothing like a little atmosphere to make this dinner perfect." Smiling, Kevin said.

"Wow..." Blushing profusely, I said. "You and Jimmy really gave this date a lot of thought."

"We wanted it to be perfect." Smiling, Jimmy said. "Order whatever you want."

I was completely blown away. I had the urge to giggle like a little girl on Christmas day. I held the menu in front of my face to hide my gaiety until I could compose myself. Only I broke into giggles when a young worker began to play a romantic tune on the violin between Pat's table and mine.

"If this is the first date, I'm going to need to prepare myself for the second." giggling, Pat said.

I giggled at that, not knowing until later that the violin music was to drown out Brooklynne pounding on the glass window, due to not being able to get in. Pat and I ordered our meals and engaged in friendly conversation with our dates. It was a wonderful experience, though I was curious about the young workers. When we were done and ready to leave, Kevin produced his wallet, only Mia stopped him with a wave of her hand. "I've already been paid far more than I normally make on a day like this." Kindly, she said. "It's on the house."

At this point, I felt it would not be appropriate to ask about the young looking workers, and we left with our dates, who took us back home. Inside the restaurant, one of the violinists took off her work cap and mask to reveal Trish, who turned to the others. "Great job, sisters." Smiling, she said. "The Queen Bee has been snubbed."

Outside, Momma Mia confronted Brooklynne, who was trying to intercept us. "I do not appreciate anyone banging on my windows!" Sternly, she barked. "If you come here again, I will slap you so silly, you will forget your own name!"

Brooklynne looked past Mia to see that Kevin's car was well out of reach and stormed off, ignoring Mia's threat. After she was gone, Mia smiled and pulled out a cellphone. "Okay, little brother, your stepdaughter and daughter had a great time with no Queen Bee to ruin either of their evening."

"Thanks, sis." Calmly, Pop replied. "I owe you one."

"Family is always there for each other." Smiling, Mia said. "Adopted or not."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: At the Restaurant

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
As we walked toward the front door, Kevin said, "Cassie, can I ask you something?"

"Anything."

"Where did that play come from?"

I had to think quickly. "After I got pregnant, I started thinking about the world we're leaving for our children. I know I can't change the world, but I figured I could reach out to the people who could change things."

"I hope it works."

We stood on the front porch. "I had a great time," I said.

"So did I," Kevin replied. "I'll call you."

"I'm looking forward to it." That wasn't all I was looking forward to.

It was happening. Kevin brushed my hair away from my face.

I nodded.

We kissed.

"Hi, kids."

Pop had come out to meet us.

Kevin cleared his throat. "I'll call you," he said again.

As Kevin and Jimmy left, Pop brought us inside.

"Hi," I said.

"Hi," Pop replied. "How did it go?"

"Hi."

"That well, huh?"

"How about you, Pat?" Mom asked.

"Hi."

"Why don't you girls go up to bed?"

"Hi," we both said.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: After the date.

choices: We were called to the principal's office.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Both Pat and I were practically floating on air the following morning. Our date the night before was an experience I doubted either of us would soon forget. Everything was perfect, and it ended with our very first kiss. "I feel so weird, but I feel so good." Entering the dining room, Pat said.

Mom giggled. "You still haven't come down from the high of that kiss, I see." Smiling, she said.

"I don't think I have either." Dreamily, I said. "What a first date."

Pop smiled. "Your circle of friends made certain of that."

I turned to Pop, surprised, then smiled, remembering the young bumbling janitor and the young workers at Momma Mia's. "I should have guessed."

"We saw both Darla and Brooklynne looking into one of our windows before you two left on your dates with Kevin and Jimmy." Calmly, Mom said. "Trish had a feeling they would try to pull something, and rallied the sisterhood."

"True friends..." Tearing up, Pat said. "We should do something like that on their first dates."

"I agree." Smiling, I replied.

Upon walking into school, we were in for a surprise. There were posters on almost every locker stating: Cassie and Pat for prom queen. We turned to each other, not knowing how to react, as Darla approached my sister with a certain fury in her eyes, with Brooklynne right behind her. I found it interesting that her Queen Bees were not with her.

"Try all you want, freak!" Angry, Darla fumed. "You will always be a loser!"

Darla curled her fingers into a fist and tried to punch Pat in the lower abdomen. Knowing what her intention was, Pat dodged her first swing, and then the second, and third... "Hold still, damn you!" Raging, Darla yelled.

I had prepared myself to intervene, not knowing that a number of students, witnessing it, ran for the principal's office. What happened next seemed to occur in slow motion. Pat's expression turned to rage and caught Darla's hand before it came even close for another try, and squeezed it with such untapped strength, Darla was forced to cry out in pain and fall to her knees.

"Don't you dare touch my baby!" Literally screaming, Pat warned. "Try that again, I'll..."

"That is enough, Patrica!" Firmly, principal Switch said. "Let her go!"

I turned to find Ms Switch approaching from the crowd. Reluctantly, Pat released Darla, who quickly began to nurse her hand as Ms Switch confronted her. "This is a new low for you, Darling." Softly, angrily, she said. "You were warned... clean out your locker, young lady, you are expelled as of today."

With that said, Ms Switch escorted Darla off to her office while I turned to Brooklynne. "Don't tell me you're going to be the sensible one." Sarcastically, I said.

I had never before seen fear in Brooklynne's eyes, until that day. She slowly backed away, and I swore I saw her gulp. "You're both freaks..." Whispering, she said. "Everyone has something to hide, I'll have you and your play ruined!"

As she walked away, I knew that we no longer had rivals, we had enemies. Darla tried to harm Pat's unborn child and she reacted as any mother would. Only she stopped the attack with a strength I never would have guessed she had. "We're going to need to warn the Sisterhood and the Drama Club." Softly, I said.

The rest of the day was mostly uneventful, with the exception of gossip about Pat's rage and unheard of strength. "It's always the quiet ones..." I heard one girl whisper.

"Darla had it coming to her." Another girl replied. "I just never thought it would be the shy boy turned girl who would give it to her..."

"Patrica is almost guaranteed to win prom queen this year, now that Darla has been expelled." Yet another girl said. "Her retaliation was out of self defense, so that won't disqualify her..."

As the school day ended...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The rivalry escalates.

choices: Pat says it's too late to back out.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Both Pat and I sighed upon hearing the secretary calling us to the principal's office over the PA system. Brooklynne gave us a wicked grin as she passed us upon reaching Ms Switch's office. Only, as we walked in, we were surprised to see her smiling. "So, are we in trouble or not in trouble?" Nervous, I asked.

Ms Switch giggled. "Normally, when I call someone to my office, they are in trouble." With a grin, she said. "However, I called you two here to educate you on Gaian pregnancy."

"You... lost me." Confused, Pat said.

"Like humans, expecting Gaian mothers become very protective of their unborn child." Calmly, Ms Switch said. "However, it is their emotional reaction to what they see as a threat that gives away the gender of their child. We call it a mother's rage, where you call it a mother's instinct."

"So you know the gender of our unborn children already?" Surprised, I asked.

Ms Switch nodded and turned to Pat. "Congratulations, Patricia." Smiling, she said. "You are going to give birth to a girl."

Pat blushed profusely before smiling as she touched her lower abdomen. "Well, at least that narrows down the names to give her." Softly, she said.

"Spoiler alert." Grinning, I said.

"How is an alert spoiled?" Confused, Ms Switch asked.

I giggled with Pat following. "Giving away something before it is discovered by others is called a spoiler alert." smiling, I said. "It spoils, or ruins, the surprise."

Ms Switch raised a hand to her mouth, blushing. "Oh my..." Softly, she said. "I did not realize you wanted the gender of your child to be a surprise. What an interesting tradition..."

I shrugged then said, "What is done is done, so, if you know the gender of my child..."

"You are going to have a boy." Smiling, Ms Switch said. "I know this because the way you handled Brooklynne during the incident today."

"I don't understand." Wincing, I said. "I hesitated..."

"Did you now...?" Grinning, Ms Switch countered. "From where I stood, your eyes were squarely set on Brooklynne." She turned serious. "I would wager to say that had she moved a single finger against you or Pat, you would have torn her apart."

I blushed at that. "Honestly, I was hoping she would..."

Ms Switch nodded. "You knew that Pat could handle herself one on one, but not against two." Calmly, she said. "It is that hair trigger aggressive nature that told me you were going to give birth to a son."

Pat and I turned to each other smiling. "I'm going to have a son." Dreamily, I said.

"And me a daughter." Sighing happily, Pat added.

Ms Switch smiled. "Now then, Patricia." Lightly scolding, she said. "You are not off the hook for the incident earlier today."

Pat sighed, all of the celebration draining from her. "What's my punishment?"

Ms Switch giggled. "Relax, child, it's not as bad as you think." Lightly, she said. "Emotional outbursts like yours will make people see you in a different light. You have some PR damage control to do if you want to win prom queen."

"That or drop out, right?" Sighing, Pat asked.

Ms Switch nodded. "This is your one chance to either back out or press on." Serious, she said. "The choice is yours alone to make."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: A mother's instinctual rage.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Pat shrugged. "Like Pop says, 'In for a penny, in for a pound.' I'll make a formal apology tomorrow."

Ms. Switch smiled. "I expected nothing less of you, Patricia. No wonder that errant offspring chose you for her mother. You're dismissed."

******************************


We had a meeting of the Sisterhood that night. "To begin with," I said, "Pat and I want to extend our sincere thanks to you all for helping to make our first dates so magical. You can all expect to be repaid in kind.

"Second, this sort of announcement isn't usually made before the mother is out of her pre-pregnancy wardrobe, but Pat and I heard it from Ms. Switch this afternoon, and we're too thrilled to hold it back from you: Pat's having a girl, and I'm having a boy."

The surprise was quickly followed by congratulations from the Sisterhood.

Nicole raised her hand. "Yes, Nicole?"

"I thought I should let you know," she said, "that a few of the Queen Bees have contacted me since date night. You guys may have noticed that they weren't with Brooklynne today. The point is, they described Brooklynne's behavior since then as 'off the rails.' She's shown no interest in any topic that isn't Cassie, Pat, or both."

"So you're saying that the battle's just getting started?" Mom asked.

Nicole shook her head. "I'm saying today was a battle. What's just getting started is the war. And it's a war she'll do anything to win."

That gave me pause. Brooklynne had said she would dig up Pat's and my secrets. And secrets don't come much bigger than being the mothers of an alien race. "On a related note," I said, "Kevin's behavior leads me to wonder if he knows about me, and how much he knows. I don't expect any of you to trust my judgment. I'm asking you to find out what you can, and, if you think it's necessary, take action to protect and defend the Sisterhood."

******************************


That night, as I lay in bed, I talked to my unborn baby. "I wonder what development is like for Gaian babies? Do you have ears yet? Can you hear me when I'm talking?" I rubbed my flat belly. "Jonathan Donald Pennant. That'll be your name when you come out. Jonathan for my father, Donald for Pop. We can call you JD for short. Do you like it? How does it sound, JD?"
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Pat says it's too late to back out.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The next morning, at school, Mrs Norris approached me, looking annoyed. "Thank you for the heads up on Brooklynne's threat." Serious, she said. "We were able to get enough facts together after school yesterday to stop the first of her assaults."

"What did she do?" Wincing, Pat asked.

"She left flyers in the freshmen football locker room, saying that Pat broke all of Darla's fingers when she grabbed her hand, and Darla dropped out in fear." Frowning, Mrs Norris replied. "However, Kevin and Jimmy were kind enough to talk to Darla's mother after the incident."

"Is she okay?" Worried, I asked.

"She's just fine." smiling, Mrs Norris said. "Her mother had transferred her to an all girls boarding school with strict rules for conduct, to straighten her out. All of the teachers in school have been informed of this, and will correct anyone who asks or speaks out."

"Only this is just the beginning." Frowning, Pat said.

"Don't worry, girls." Smiling, Mrs Norris said. "You are not fighting this war of words alone."

"What can we do?" Wincing, I asked. "I won't stoop to her level."

"Brooklynne uses blackmail and intimidation to get her way." Approaching us, Trish said. "She is very good at it, but we are better."

"You found something?" Curious, I asked.

Mrs Norris nodded. "The party Nicole went to was at Brooklynne's house." Serious, she said. "They have a security system..."

"How do you know this?' Startled, I asked. "Did you break in..."

"My husband is a police officer." Firmly but kindly, Mrs Norris said. "Brooklynne's father turned over the video disks to the authorities after Nicole reported she had been raped at the party." She sighed. "It was Brooklynne's older brother, Bronx Dietrich."

"Has he been arrested?" Worried, Pat asked.

"He is in the hands of the police." Serious, Trish replied. "Only Brooklynne doesn't know."

"What are you getting at?" Confused, I asked.

"I'm thinking we allow Brooklynne to defeat herself." Smiling, Mrs Norris said.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The War Continues

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Lunch started out normally enough, with the usual hubbub. The Sisterhood was talking about baby matters (how big they were right then, why so many books compared the size to foodstuffs), when a fight broke out.

Teachers separated the combatants, with help from Kevin, Mike, and Bill. "You know fighting is not allowed on school grounds," one teacher said.

"He started it!" one of the fighters replied. "He said Pop Pennant got all those girls pregnant! Even his daughter and stepdaughter!" He began to calm down. "My folks knew Pop from when he was a preacher. It tore him up that Cassie and Pat were hurt. He'd die before he even thought about... that."

A few people came by our table. "I don't believe that story," one said. "Like Hank says, that ain't Pop."

"No, Pop didn't do it," Nicole said. "But I can tell you about Bronx Dietrich, and the police can back me up."

"Brooklynne's brother? What'd he do?"

"He roofied me, raped me, and got me pregnant. Ask Brooklynne. If she tries to deny it, ask her where he is now."

As the other kids left, Sarah said, "Pulling out the big guns already?"

"I wouldn't have done it," Nicole said, "if Brooklynne had come after us. But she went after Pop, and for that, she must pay."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Brooklynne tries another lie.

choices: Days later, we perform the play for the school.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
We explained what had happened to Mom and Pop after school, only, to our surprise, both seemed rather calm. "She finally made that one mistake." Softly, Mom said.

Pop nodded. "I'll make the call."

We were then sent to our rooms to do homework, and did not hear who Pop had called or what was said. I tried to ask, but Pop would not say. He just smiled and said, "Trust me. When the time is right, you will know everything."

It was not until lunch the next day when I saw Brooklynne again, only she was staring down her former Queen Bees, who had all decided to confront her on her latest lie. "You went too far, Dietrich!" a tall blond huffed. "It's one thing to dig up dirt on people, making up lies is another!"

"Easy, Gretchen." Stress in her voice, Brooklynne said. "I can explain..."

"Pop has literally saved dozens of lives as a preacher, including my own!" Angrily, a well built brunette scolded. "Trying to drag a man like that through the mud is a new low for you!"

"Darci, I only did that to get back at..." Brooklynne began.

"What are you going to do next, girl?!" Scoffing, a brown haired girl demanded. "Start spreading dirt on us?! Don't forget, we have plenty of dirt on you to spread in kind!"

"Are you threatening me now?!" turning red, Brooklynne asked. "Have you forgotten who I am?!"

"Brooklynne Marybeth Dietrich!" Angrily, a male voice thundered.

Everyone in the cafeteria turned to find a towering man with crew cut black hair and green eyes. It was Brooklynne's father, Maximus Dietrich, the owner of the local bank.

"Daddy...!" With a nervous grin, Brooklynne said. "I thought you were still on a business trip..."

"I just got in this morning, to hear that my son is a rapist, and that you are knowingly spreading misinformation at school about one of my most decorated clients and his family!" Furious, Maximus roared. "If I lose a single penny because of your antics, young lady, your inheritance will be cut in half!" He then cleared his throat and straightened his tie and softly added, "I do hope I have made myself crystal clear."

With that, he walked out of the cafeteria to talk to someone. From where I was sitting I was able to see Maximus was talking to Pop! It was then that it all made sense. Pop had placed all of the treasure left for us into Max's bank! I could not help smile. "Well played, Pop."

I then turned back to Brooklynne, to find her almost literally dead in the eyes. She turned to me with a heavy sulk on her face. Fortunately, I had dropped my smile before then, as she merely shook her head and slowly walked away with her former Queen Bees walking toward me.

"So, I hear you have a little sisterhood going on." Slightly nervous, Gretchen said. "Are you accepting new members?"

I turned to the others, who could only shrug, it was left up to me. "Sit with us, we'll talk." Politely, I said. "It's at least a start."

"I'm Gwendolyn, my friends call me Gwen." Softly, the brown haired girl said. "We hung around Brooklynne for various reasons..."

"That is in the past, Gwen." Quoting Pop, I said. "Focus on the present, it's the only time you have to act."

Gwen smiled, I knew she was grateful not to have to explain her past actions. "You play is really amazing, guys." Honestly, she said. "What inspired it?"

"Well, what we are doing to our own planet was part of it." Softly, I replied. "That, and getting raped at the Stardust hotel." I gulped. "Those substitute teachers chose their targets carefully."

"What do you mean?" Worried, Darci asked. "Why did they target you four?"

"Think about it,..." Firmly, Pat said. "Three shy girls with very few friends, and an inwardly drawn boy slowly turning into a girl..."

Gretchen's eyes went wide as she fit the pieces into her mind. "There would be little chance of an investigation, because almost literally no one would have your backs."

I nodded and added, "Can you imagine how many other girls they may have attacked before they were caught in the act because of a perverted hotel manager?" I then shuddered. More in disgust of having to lie about three brave aliens trying to save their world from extinction.

"Why are you keeping the babies, then?" Wincing, Gretchen asked.

"They did not ask to be born." Softly, Pat replied. "I will not take a life because someone could not keep it in their pants."

"We will be punishing those rapists every day by raising our children to be better than them." Firmly, I said. "It's the best form of justice we could ever ask for."

In a way, it was the truth. The Gaians had ruined their own planet, and, by raising their next generation right, it would be an ironic form of justice.

My thoughts were interrupted by Gretchen suddenly hugging Nicole. "When that creep, Bronx, gets out of jail, we are not going to let him anywhere near the Sisterhood."

"Thanks, guys."

The Sisterhood was growing.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: A queen without a kingdom.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The time came for us to perform Gaia in front of the entire student body. By this point, we were pretty polished: Nicole had brought Lauren's sketches to life, and everyone on stage knew their part by heart.

Looking out into the audience, I saw almost everyone was eagerly awaiting our show. The sole exception: Brooklynne Dietrich.

As the show went on, the students responded better than we'd hoped. But that wasn't what struck me.

During a scene that Pat and I shared, I snuck several peeks into the audience, and Brooklynne's attitude was definitely noteworthy: she was staring at Pat.

Okay, so you may be thinking, what was so special about Brooklynne staring at Pat? Well, she wasn't looking daggers at my stepsister. It wasn't hatred, or even jealousy.

Then, it hit me: the look in Brooklynne's eyes was lust.

Brooklynne Dietrich, gossip queen of the whole school, wanted to get into Pat's pants.

********************************


The show ended, and the student body erupted in a standing ovation. I was touched when Mrs. Norris came up to thank me and Lauren for our work.

Now, the play had brought me a lot of surprises, but it wasn't done yet. As we celebrated, a woman approached us. "Excuse me," she said, "which of you are Cassie Pennant and Lauren Tucker?"

"That would be us. And you are?"

"Sharon Allen. Drama critic. You wouldn't believe how highly recommended you two are."

"How highly?"

"Lin-Manuel Miranda sent me." She produced a telegram from the star, instructing her to come to our show. "And now that I'm here, I'd like to interview you, if I may."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Days later, we perform the play for the school.

choices: Brooklyne forcing a kiss on Pat.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
After warning Pat of what I had observed during the play, Lauren and I agreed to the interview. Sharon took us to an empty classroom nearby, where cameras were set up. Once we were all comfortable, she began. "Thank you for agreeing to talk to us." Politely, she said. "I know you all have a lot on your plate right now."

"We manage." Smiling, I replied.

Sharon smiled. "What inspired this play you and your friends put together?"

"Mostly real life events." Serious, Lauren said. "What we as a species are doing to our planet, to each other, is just terrible, and it has to change."

"I know this must be a sensitive subject, but did you incorporate your pregnancies into the play?" Curious, Sharon asked. "I noticed certain lines in the songs that suggested impregnating young women to save the Gaian world."

I turned to Lauren and we shared a nervous laugh. "Guilty..." Blushing, I said. "There was a ridiculous rumor that we were raped by 'aliens'." I made air quotes, then added, "And it, well..."

"It gave us the idea of a desperate plan to save an entire race by becoming one with mankind." Smiling, Lauren said. "You see, as you might have seen in the news, many of us were at the Stardust hotel the night we were all raped."

"There was an unusual ball lightning event that night, which had entered all of the rooms of the hotel before the storm was over." Serious, I added. "That is what gave us the idea of aliens of gentle blue light."

"Intriguing..." Fascinated, Sharon said. "You girls put a lot of thought into this."

"We all had a part." Smiling, Lauren said. "We all went outside of our comfort zones to help put this together, and it turned out great."

I nodded. "Pat gave ideas for the landscapes, though his fascination is in world religions, I came up with the songs, when I'm more of a tinker, Lauren made up the unusual musical instruments, when she is really more into music and art than building anything..."

"I am impressed." Smiling, Sharon said. "This play is going to get five stars in my review in Rolling Stone, and I have more good news..."

Lauren and I were stunned. We never thought when this started that we would find ourselves in a magazine like Rolling Stone. We wanted to scream in delight, but Sharron said she had more good news. "What news do you have for us?" curious, I asked.

"Lin-Manuel Miranda has asked me to invite you and your friends to perform your outstanding play at Playhouse Square in New York City."

That was when Lauren and I screamed in delight. Not only was our message, Gaia's message, being spread through the most popular music and art magazine in the world, but we were going to perform in the most watched theater in the US, and possibly the world. Sharon giggled as she watched us celebrate. It was the best news we had received since this had all started.

"We will have to get permission from our parents, of course." Excited, I said. "But I don't see any problems, I'm too excited!'

"Congratulations, girls." Smiling, Sharon said. "My people will contact your parents to iron out all of the details."

After the interview, I walked out of the classroom and gave my friends the good news. As I had expected, everyone cheered in excitement. I then told Principal Switch what was said during the interview, which caused her to giggle. "Well, the secret is out, sort of." Smiling, she said. "Well played, by the way, stopping such speculation before it started."

"I learned from from the best." Shrugging, I replied. I then looked around. "Where is Pat?"

"She went to the bathroom about five minutes ago." Calmly, Stan said.

I looked around again, and did not find Brooklynne either. Worried, I rushed for the nearest ladies room to find...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The Interview

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Brooklynne had Pat pinned against the wall, her hands held over her head. Pat tried to squirm away, but Brooklynne was paying no attention to that. She was too busy alternating between forcing her tongue into Pat's mouth and licking her face.

I had seen enough. I pulled her off of my stepsister and whipped her across the restroom. "Like brother, like sister, huh?" I asked.

She said nothing, just staring at me, as if I was the one who had crossed a line.

Pat clung to me, weeping into my shoulder. "Go find a member of your family who can keep it in their pants," I told Brooklynne.

A few of the Sisterhood came in, including a couple former Queen Bees. Brooklynne took the opportunity to get the hell out of Dodge. "What happened?" Nicole asked.

"Brooklynne tried to force herself on Pat."

"Wow," Nicole said, "I wouldn't have called that. Especially after this past summer."

"What happened last summer?"

The Used to Bees were quiet for several seconds. "It's... not the sort of thing you like to talk about, Cassie. In more ways than one."

"It's enough to make you not sure of what she would do. I want to hear it."

Gwen sighed. "Bronx and Brooklynne... they're close. Not close like you and Pat, close like your mom and Pop."

I wanted to throw up.
