"Last summer," Nicole said, "Bronx drove her two towns over, to a clinic where nobody who saw her would know her, and ask why she was there."

"I... guess her father would have asked some questions," I said.

"Want to know the odd part?" Nicole asked.

"Odder than what I've just heard?"

"While she was at home, taking pain meds, two families and a tour group needed a place to spend the night."

I had to admit, that was quite a coincidence.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Brooklyne forcing a kiss on Pat.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Upon returning, home, Pat rushed upstairs to take a shower, still weeping over the incident at school with Brooklynne. Seeing her crying, Mom and Pop turned to me. "It turns out that Bronx Dietrich is not the only one who can't keep it in his pants." Wincing, I said.

Mom turned pale and ran up the stairs after Pat, while Pop put on a kettle of water. "Coffee for me, and tea for you." Serious, he said. "I have a feeling this is going to be a long talk."

Over the next hour, I told Pop all the good, bad, and ugly events that had happened at school, up to Brooklynne forcing herself upon Pat. Pop merely nodded and gave an occasional grunt as he listened, then sighed as I had finished. "I'm proud of you and Pat, the play you and your friends had put together is obviously a huge success." Calmly, he said. "However, this new development with Brooklynne has me worried."

"You think she may try to go after her again?" Wincing, I asked.

Pop shook his head. "it's just a gut feeling." Softly, he said. "It comes from years of working with people of all walks of life. I think Brooklynne may be very sick."

"You mean other than in the head?" Trying to be light, I asked. Only Pop was not smiling.

"I mean she may be very physically sick, as well as mentally." Serious, Pop replied. "Suddenly switching from trying to destroy you both to loving one is a dead giveaway."

"What do you suppose is wrong with her?" now worried, I asked.

Pop drummed his fingers on the table in a nervous manner. "Again, its just a gut feeling." Softly, he said. "I'll need to make a call to confirm my suspicions."

I watched, curious and anxious, as Pop made a phone call. "Principal Switch, Pop Pennant here." Firmly, he said. "Are you aware of Brooklynne Dietrich's unusual personality changes lately?"

Pop listened as Ms Switch told her what she knew of it. His expression told me that it was not good news. "I understand." Softly, Pop said. "We will do what we can on this end..."

Once Pop was done on the phone, he turned to me, looking worried. "Brooklynne was targeted, just as your friends were, with a seed." Serious, he explained. "Only there was a marginal risk we were not informed of until now."

"A risk?" gulping, I asked.

Pop sighed. "Inbreeding brings the risk of genetic disorders." Darkly, he said. "I have seen this first hand, and it is not pretty." he sighed. "Ms Switch fears that, by making love to her brother, Brooklynne developed a Gaian genetic disorder from her unborn child."

"Why was she targeted?!" Surprised, I demanded. "I thought they were looking for those who were isolated due to shyness or..."

"There is more than one form of isolation." Calmly, Pop said. "A rich girl who gets all she wants but her father's love can be very isolated, indeed. No time to listen to either of them, and allowing his wealth to take care of them for him."

I was now seeing Brooklynne in a new light. "What did she develop?" Whispering, I asked.

"Ms Switch called it Endless Lust Disorder." Almost sadly, Pop replied. "Unfortunately, her brother is just a privileged horny brat who is all too happy to fuel Brooklynne's illness."

"Is there a cure for this?" Wincing, I asked.

"Ms Switch told me she can help her, but we need to first find her." Firmly, Pop said. "If we don't find her soon, she may harm herself in order to satisfy that never ending 'itch'."

After a thought, I took up my phone and called Nicole. "I just got word that Brooklynne is very sick and needs medical attention." Serious, I said. "She's confused and frightened, we need to find her, fast."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Unexpected issue.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"The last time Brooklynne got scared," Nicole said, "she went to her family's houseboat on the lake. She said the waves helped her to think."

"Boat house on the lake, got it," I said. "We'll get help and go there."

"Should I go ahead of you, try to reason with her?"

"According to Ms. Switch, she's not in a reasoning frame of mind. No, if you go, it's as part of our group, or not at all. I'll talk to you later. 'Bye."

As I hung up, Pop was hanging up his phone. "I just spoke to Ms. Switch," he said. "She said she'd meet you there. And don't go in without her, unless you absolutely have to."

I called up the former Queen Bees and let them know what was happening, then I borrowed the car and rounded them all up. "What's going on?" Gwen asked. "How did Brooklynne get so sick? And how is Ms. Switch going to help?"

"It's a long story," I said. "The short version is, there are things I and the rest of the Sisterhood haven't told you, for your own protection, and it looks like I need to tell you now." One as-brief-as-possible recap later, I said, "So now Brooklynne's sick from her relationship with Bronx, and Ms. Switch needs to help her and her fetus. Still in?"

The girls were wide-eyed after everything I'd told them, but they still cared enough about Brooklynne to agree to help her.

Once we got to the lake, it wasn't hard to spot the houseboat, as the lights were on. As we got closer, we could hear two voices coming from inside. "Looks like we'll need to go in," I said, "ahead of Ms. Switch."

As we entered the boat house, we saw Brooklynne, naked, tying her father to a post. "Brooklynne," he yelled, "I demand an explanation!"

"I need you, Daddy," she said. "But you never have time for me. So now, we're going to make the time, and do all the things I want to do with you."

"Except you don't want to do this, Brooklynne," I said, "not really. You're sick, and we've come to help you get well."

She charged at me, but I was ready, knocking her into the water. When she climbed back out, Nicole and the others held her down, while I untied Mr. Dietrich.

"Would someone tell me," he said, "precisely what in the blazes is going on here?"

"A battle for your daughter's mind, body, and soul is going on here, Mr. Dietrich," Ms. Switch said. "And, if you ever cared about her as more than an extension of yourself, you will do exactly as I say."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Nicole knows where Brooklynne is.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Although shaken and confused, Mr Dietrich nodded. "What must I do?"

"We need privacy, if you don't want this to get out to every news agency in the county." Sternly, Ms Switch said. "Take us all on a little cruise around the dock while we work."

Mr Dietrich hurried out of the living area of the houseboat to the pilot box, and began to move the boat out of the dock. With him distracted, Ms Switch turned to a small radio. "We are ready."

A blue light entered the living area, before becoming a man I recognized as the new school janitor, Mr. Barns. He was of average height and build, but had a very handsome face with sandy blond hair and gentle blue eyes. "I need everyone to think of a person who wants a child." Calmly, he said. "Do not speak of this person, just think. I am what you would call a clairvoyant."

We were surprised, and somewhat startled, but we all thought of who wanted a child but could not, and Mr Barns smiled. "It is unanimous." Calmly, he said. "Let us begin."

"Who are you people?" Frightened, Brooklynne demanded. "What is going on?!"

"You have what is called Endless Lust Disorder." Startling her, Pop explained. "It is a rare genetic disorder triggered by interbreeding pregnancy."

Brooklynne turned white. "Is that what I have?" Shaking, she demanded. "i thought i was going mad, after so long of letting Bronx violate me..."

"You let your brother rape you?!" disturbed, Nicole asked.

"First cousin." Softly, Brooklynne replied. "Daddy adopted him after his parents had died in an avalanche while skiing overseas." She began to cry. "I figured, as long as he was focused on me, he would not tarnish the family name by..." She fell apart, crying uncontrollably.

"Easy, child." placing a hand onto Brooklynne's forehead. Ms Switch said. "All will be well in a matter of moments."

Her eyes turned blue and began to glow as Mr Barns transformed back into his blue light form and entered Brooklynne. Just as quickly as it had happened, he flew out of her and vanished through the wall. Ms Switch looked at her watch then turned to us. "In less than a minute, Brooklynne will have a new child growing within her." Serious, she said. "This will stabilize her condition, but the trauma of what she has gone through will remain."

I turned to Brooklynne, seeing her in a new light. The stress and heartache she had suffered was enough to make all of us cry. Before we could react, a blue light passed through her before Mr barns returned. "It is done." Politely, he said. "Her madness will subside and eventually vanish, and the odds in favor of our survival will increase."

"We took her unborn child and gave it to Mrs Norris." To our shock, Ms. Switch said. "She has always wanted a child, but feared she was sterile." She smiled. "This way, her pregnancy will not be questioned, but welcomed with open arms."

"Here I thought they just targeted us." Ruefully, I muttered.

"They are trying to save an entire species, Cassie." Serious, Pop said. "Do you seriously believe that they would risk everything on seven lone young women?"

Stunned, I turned to Ms Switch. "How many of you are there?" Wincing, I asked.

Ms Switch sadly smiled. "Far fewer than you might think."

"Who... Who are you people?" Trembling, Brooklynne demanded. "Please... I'm scared."

"You are a victim too, Brooklynne." Softly, I said. "That does not mean you have to be a victim all on your own." I held my hand out to her as the others relaxed their grip. "We are stronger together, we can make a difference."

Slowly, hesitantly, Brooklynne took my hand and I pulled her into a warm hug. It was then that she completely fell into hysterical tears. She gripped my blouse as if she feared she would lose me if she were to let go. The rest of the sisterhood soon joined in the hug, all realizing that, like the Gaians, we were slowly making peace with our foes.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The Treatment

choices: Details About the New York Performance
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The Brooklynne Dietrich who paid a call on us that Saturday afternoon was markedly different from the one who had attacked Pat. She still had dark circles around her eyes, but there was a spark in those eyes that wasn't there before. "Good afternoon, Brooklynne," Pop said. "How are you feeling?"

"It all feels like a dream," she replied. "Did the janitor turn into a big blue ball of light and impregnate me?"

"As strange as it sounds," I said, "that actually happened. How do you feel about it?"

"Different. I mean, I was pregnant before, but this time,... it feels different."

"How so?" Lauren asked.

"I think... I want this one."

"You're not the first to have that reaction," I said.

"Yeah, but I can't shake this voice in my head saying 'no career, no future,' over and over again." She smiled ruefully.

"I heard a voice like that once," Sarah said. "Wanna know how I beat it?"

"How?"

"I just reminded myself, 'She doesn't know what I know, why should I listen to her?'"

"She didn't know a lot, did she?"

"The good news," I said, "is that every day brings more possibilities to learn. So, if you learned something, the day wasn't wasted."

"Well, I certainly learned a lot last night."

"How are things at home, Brooklynne?" Mom asked.

"I guess Daddy learned something, too. He apologized for being gone so much, and he promised to help me. And the baby." She rested a hand on her womb. "It's so weird. Why me? Why did they pick me?"

"We had the same questions," I said. "The Gaians who impregnated us said that they wanted girls with great capacity for love, because we would give that love to our children."

It was the first time Brooklynne had ever heard herself described that way. Her face brightened... and then sank again, as Pat came down the stairs.

As Pat came closer, Brooklynne stood, her head lowered. "I know sorry can never be enough," she said, "but it's all that I have. I threw up when I got home, from disgust with myself."

Pat said, "I've never been so afraid as I am now. But Pop told me what happened, and why. I can't forget what you did. But I can offer forgiveness." Pat lifted Brooklynne's chin. "Pop says, peace doesn't mean we all agree on everything. It means we all agree to talk things out. So, let's talk."

Brooklynne was near tears. "Think I'll fit in at the losers' table?"

"We're not winners," Pat said, "and we're not losers." She put her arm around Brooklynne. "We're the Sisterhood."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Brooklynne joins the Sisterhood.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"What we are about to tell you is to be considered the greatest secret you can ever be entrusted to keep." Serious, Pop said. "It is also to be considered the greatest privilege and responsibility any mortal could ever be asked to carry."

Brooklynne gulped. "Is it that serious?" Stunned, she asked.

Mom nodded. "Literally an entire world rests upon the shoulders of you and your new friends." Also serious, she said. "It took a while for it to sink in with my daughters."

"As well as us." Honestly, Trish said. "This is as serious and wondrous as it gets."

Brooklynne turned from one girl to the next, each of them solemnly nodding, confirming Mom and Pop's words. "Okay..." softly, she said. "You have the word of a Dietrich that this goes no further than this room. Fill me in."

Everyone took turns telling Brooklynne of the Gaians, and their desperate plan to save their entire species from extinction by merging into the human race. "We each got a piece of the Gaian world which was out of our comfort zone." Serious, I said. "I got their art and music, Lauren got their technology, Sarah got their religion, and Pat got their geography."

To say Brooklynne was shocked would have been an understatement. She gently touched her lower abdomen. "I'm one of the few carrying the last hope of a dying world...." Whispering, she said. "What did the rest of you get...?"

"They were seeded, just as you were." Serious, Pop said. "They will get their gifts once they are ready to bear a child." he sighed. "Principal Switch and I had a long talk soon after I learned she was a Gaian. They had seeded a lot of people throughout this region."

"For good reason." As if enlightened, Brooklynne said. "The Gaians wanted it all controlled, contained to ensure success. If word were to get out too soon, it would spark widespread fear and confusion, like the New Moon Era."

"The what...?" confused, I asked.

Ms Switch, who had also paid a visit, let out a sigh. "The New Moon Era happened a long time ago on Gaia." Calmly, she said. "It was similar to what your people called the Dark Ages." She motioned to Brooklynne. "Your new friend has apparently been gifted with our history."

We all turned to Brooklynne, who blushed slightly. "History is not my strong suit." Softly, she admitted, "I prefer to live in the here and now." she smiled slightly. "I'm more interested in animals, I want to be a veterinarian some day."

"Mrs Norris is a huge history nut." Smiling, Lauren said. "Maybe her gift was Gaian wildlife."

"Maybe..." Smiling, Ms Switch said.

"So this play really is wrapped around everything that had happened to you, to us?" Curious, Brooklynne asked. "Why?"

"Two reasons." simply, I said. "First, to spread the word that this world in need of saving, and second, to hide the real truth. If any rumor or theory does spread, it would be shrugged off as them hearing about the play."

Brooklynne giggled. "That's deviously clever, Cassie." With a rueful grin, she said. "We'll make a bee out of you yet."

We all giggled, catching on to the irony of her statement. "Welcome to the Sisterhood."

Unknown to us, miles away, a dark figure watched a segment of the news, talking about our play to soon hit Playhouse Theater. He hit the power button on a remote then threw it at the television, cracking the screen. "A play like that could be harmful to business." Gravely, he said. His voice was deep and dark.

"They're just children, Mr Creed." Calmly, another man remarked.

"You speak as if I intend to harm them, Mr. Thorne." Insulted, Mr. Creed said. "There are many less violent ways of neutralizing a potential threat to business."

Days later...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Details About the New York Performance

choices: I meet Ms Switch half way.
Someone pulls me into an empty classroom.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
When we returned to school the next day, we were surprised to find a number of the teachers were out sick, with substitutes taking their place. In homeroom, I was greeted by a handsome man in an expensive looking suit. If that wasn't strange enough, he seemed to ignore everyone else in the room and came straight to me. "You must be Cassie Pennant." Smiling, he said. "I'm Mr Smith, taking the place of Mrs Dorrie for a few days, while she is on vacation. I saw your interview with the drama critic, Sharon Allen, on the news."

"Word gets around fast, I guess." Shrugging, I said. "Sorry that I can't give away too many details, as they are still being ironed out."

"I'm merely curious of the message your play is trying to give its audience." Softly, Mr Smith said. "It seems a bit apocalyptic..."

"That's the point." Serious, I replied. "We are literally killing our own planet with war and waste."

Mr Smith was about ask something else but the bell rang and I walked to my seat. He seemed irritated by the interruption but walked to his desk and addressed the class. "I am Mr Smith, taking the place of Mrs Dorrie while she is out on vacation." Serious, he said. "Let's make these few days we have together run smoothly, shall we?"

The students in my homeroom exchanged curious glances. Mr Smith's attitude changed from kind and patient to strict and unbending in a heartbeat. What concerned me more was that his face seemed to soften upon catching my eye. This teacher is creeping me out. With a shudder, I thought. I better talk to Principal Switch.

I talked to my circle of friends, and learned that there were substitute teachers in at least one of their classes, with the same story regarding their regular teacher and the same direct curiosity about the play. I was elected to talk to Ms Switch and see what was going on.

As I walked to Ms Switch's office after classes...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Creepy substitutes.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
I let out a short yelp of surprise as someone pulled me into an empty classroom. It was not until I turned around when I saw that it was Darla Darling wearing a black pleated skirt with a white short sleeve shirt and a black sleeveless jacket. On the jacket was a small image of a thorny rose with the words, Rose Thorn School underneath. At first, I was surprised then angry but all of that vanished when I saw tears running from Darla's eyes. "It wasn't bad enough that you and your sister got me expelled?" Tearfully, she asked. "You had to send some muscle after me?"

"What are you talking about?" Confused, I demanded. "First, you got yourself expelled by attacking Pat and second, we did not send anyone anywhere."

"You didn't send them?" Surprised, Darla asked.

"For the last time, what are you talking about?!" irritated, I asked. "We have enough problems."

"A number of substitute teachers came to my new school out of the blue." Frustrated, Darla explained. "They all claimed that the regular teachers got a vacation." She scoffed. "I may not be an A-plus student but I know BS when I hear it."

It was too much of a parallel for it to be a coincidence. "Let me guess, they were all fixated on you, asking strange questions about our play." Frowning, I said.

"You do know something about this!" Accusing, Darla yelled.

"Because we got the same problem here!" Yelling back, I countered. "The same BS excuse of a lot of teachers suddenly taking a vacation and the substitutes only having an interest in us, those who had anything to do with the play."

Darla paused. "It sounds like your play has made someone very nervous." Softly, she said. "My guess is that this someone sent these phony teachers to get more information."

"Who would be nervous about our play?" confused, I asked.

"Anyone who profits off of ignoring clean air legislation or waste management laws." Serious, Darla replied. "Your play gives a powerful message that we need to take better care of our environment and each other before there is nothing left but regrets."

I sighed, still angry with Darla for her stunt that got her expelled. "What was with you trying to punch Pat anyway?" irritated, I demanded. "You now she's pregnant!"

"I wasn't going to actually hit your sister... hard." Frowning, Darla said. "I just wanted to get my message across loud and clear that she should not be running against me." She sighed, seeing my face harden. "The point is, we both have a problem on our hands. Maybe, if we call a truce and share what we know, we can get that problem out of our hair."

I hesitated but eventually sighed and shook Darla's hand. "Okay... truce."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The return of Darla Darling.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
When we walked into the principal's office, Ms. Switch fixed her eyes squarely on Darla. "I know you've had difficulty obeying my orders in the past, Miss Darling," she said, "but I thought you understood the concept of expulsion."

"Something's going on, ma'am," Darla said. "All of a sudden, there's substitute teachers all over the school, and they're fixated on anyone having anything to do with that play. And Cassie says it's the same way here."

Ms. Switch was stunned, either from the news, or Darla addressing her with respect, or both. "I thought they might be up to something," she said. "But going to two different schools indicates that they are taking no chances."

"Can you do something? You're the principal."

"I went to the school board about it," she said with a sigh. "But they reminded me that I had placed three people who were accused of sexual impropriety into this school, so I ought to adopt more of a wait-and-see attitude."

"So what can we do?" I asked.

"Don't tell them anything you wouldn't want a stranger to know about this matter. Warn the Sisterhood at the next meeting. Perhaps this will blow over by Christmas."

I don't think anybody believed that was going to happen.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Talking to Ms Switch.

choices: Darla returns to school on probation.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
I rallied the Sisterhood immediately after talking to Ms Switch, and dragged Darla along to the meeting, where she was surprised to see Brooklynne and her bees there. The two looked at each other for a moment then demanded, in unison, "What is she doing here?!"

"Brooklynne and her friends are a part of the Sisterhood." Calmly, Lauren said. "It turns out they were trying to protect us, and others, in their own ways."

"You joined them?!" Surprised, Darla asked. "When we met at their house by chance, I was under the impression that you hated them."

"That was the old me." Somewhat sadly, Brooklynne said. "I'm pregnant too."

Darla took a step back. "You're what?!" a look of fear formed upon her face. "What is this, an epidemic of mysterious pregnancies?!"

Brooklynne stepped up to Darla with a cross look on her face. I had a suspicion that she was going to show her the intimidation she had used on so many others in the past. Only she instead sniffed the air near her. This made Darla visually disturbed and concerned. Finally, Brooklynne's face softened as she softly said, "You've been seeded."

"Are you certain?" Surprised, Mom asked. "Why her?"

"What are you guys talking about?" Becoming worried, Darla demanded. "I'm in enough trouble for jumping school..."

Ignoring Darla for the moment, Brooklynne turned to us. "I first noticed it on myself." Calmly, she explained. "Our body odor typically has an almost almond smell to it. Only when seeded or impregnated, that body odor changes to a scent closer to coconut."

Curious, Darla gave her armpit a quick sniff then turned to us, shocked. "What..."

Pop sighed and turned to Darla, with a look that caused her to step backwards in fear. "I didn't touch your daughter!" Near tears, she whimpered. "Sure, I tried to scare her, but..."

Pop placed a firm hand onto Darla's shoulder, causing her to freeze, tears rolling down her face. I became concerned at this point, but was surprised as Pop knelled down to Darla's level and removed a layer of makeup under her eye, revealing a very bad shiner. Everyone gasped as Darla then began to freely cry. "Don't tell mom..."

Brooklynne stepped forward and began to examine Darla, becoming more and more distressed as she did. "She has two broken ribs, a badly healed broken arm, and I can feel a number of cuts under her clothing." Sadly, she said. "Someone has been physically abusing her."

Everyone began to shed tears, now having a better understanding of the roots of Darla's physical attacks on others. Pop looked Darla in the eye. "Who... did... this?" Firmly, he asked.

"My- My stepfather." Whimpering, Darla said. "Since I was around four... he- he gets drunk a lot, and can't control himself..."

"Don't make excuses for a sinner." Serious, Pop said. "He's been hurting you, hence you know no other way." He gave Darla a kind smile. "That ends today."

Darla began to cry more. "My stepdad is impossible to live with!" Wailing, she said. "He went crazy when Mom told him I was being transferred to an all girls boarding school!" She began to gasp for breath. "He sneaked in the other night... He... He... I had to run..."

She completely broke down in Pop's arms. "It took a lot of courage to come to us from a boarding school for help." Gently, Pop said. "t took even more courage to tell us of your stepfather's crimes against you." He began to rub her back in a soothing manner. "I promise you that your stepfather is going to be in very serious trouble."

"What should we do?" Worried, I asked.

"First, I'm going to call Darla's mother." Serious, Mom said. "If her second husband is willing to sneak into an all girls boarding school, there is no telling what he will do to her, now that his favorite punching bag is out of the picture."

"I'll call the boarding school." Standing up, Pop said. "Their security needs serious updates."

"I'll call my father." Retrieving her cell phone, Brooklynne said. "He can have his attorneys on this case within the hour."

"I'll call my mother." Firmly, Nicole said. "She is a lieutenant in the local police force. A report will need to be made."

"I'll call Ms Switch and tell her Darla's story." Firmly, Pat said. "Once she understands the reasons behind her behavior, maybe she will let her come back."

Darla was now freely crying, seeing every member of the Sisterhood rallying behind her with what they had to offer, to help her. I could sense that a huge weight had been lifted off her shoulders, and pulled her into a warm hug. "It's going to be okay, Darla." Firmly but kindly, I said. "Your nightmare is over."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: We discover Darla's nightmare.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"What does 'seeded' mean?" Darla asked. "I don't want to have a baby, I'm just a kid."

"Pat, Lauren, Sarah, and I were impregnated," I explained. "But others, yourself included, were seeded. You aren't pregnant now, but, when you're ready, you will have a Gaian child."

"Those are the aliens from your play... You mean... ?"

I nodded. "It's real. Gaia was a real place, with real people. Their greed and hatred destroyed their world, and brought them to the brink of extinction. We're their last chance,... if we can avoid destroying our world ourselves."

"Hence the play."

I nodded. "The words and music are Gaian. Along with their children, the Gaians gave us mothers-to-be pieces of their rich knowledge. I got their arts, Lauren got their tech, Pat got their geography, Sarah got their religion, and Brooklynne got their history. When your time comes, you'll find out what your gift is."

Brooklynne rubbed Darla's back. "You're not the only broken person here. My cousin used me for his pleasure, and it threatened to destroy me, heart and soul. The Sisterhood, and my baby, are helping me to heal. We can do the same for you."

Darla lifted her head. "Do I need to be pregnant?"

"No. You just need to want a better place for these babies."

She smiled slightly. "I can do that."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Darla joins the Sisterhood.

choices: More questions from the new teachers.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
In the hours that had followed, Darla's stepfather was arrested for child and spouse abuse, and taken to jail to await his day in court. Darla was then pulled from the all girls boarding school, and returned to our school. Only Ms Switch had a few conditions for her return. "Understand that you are under strict probation, young lady." Sternly, she said. "While I understand the abuse you had suffered led to your aggressive behavior, you cannot run for prom queen... school rules."

"Yes, ma'am." Timidly, Darla said. "Thank you for giving me one last chance."

Ms Switch's face softened. "Now that the official business is out of the way, we can begin your rehabilitation..." Her eyes glowed a bright blue before returning to their original color of brown. "Know that you have an ally you can turn to if you need help."

Darla's jaw dropped in surprise, only she smiled as I whispered, "Welcome to the Sisterhood."

Ms Switch smiled. "The official story is that you pushed to get transferred into the all girls boarding school to escape your abusive stepfather." Calmly, she said. "Only he broke in to attack again, and you were forced to run."

"You came back here, to us, for help, and we reported your stepfather for his crimes." Calmly, I added. "Now that he is out of the picture, you felt safe to return to school, where you were welcomed back under probation."

"My move has placed me back on the good side of the school board." Smiling, Ms Switch said. "Especially when I reminded them that they, not I, were the ones who cleared all the substitutes who had committed the crimes against the students under my watchful eye."

"The school board is thusly reviewing the new substitutes." Serious, I said. "Only, I would not hold my breath of them rushing it."

Ms Switch sighed as well, shaking her head. "Typical bureaucracy..."

We all got more than our share of curious looks from students, and the new substitute teachers, now that we were all friends. The rumors again began to spread throughout the school, only I did not pay any attention to them this time. I was more worried about the new teachers. Still, with our circle of friends growing, these teachers were no longer facing us one on one. We were now using the buddy system, to ensure none of us would be alone.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Probation and rehabilitation.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
We began full rehearsals for Gaia, what with a performance in New York approaching. Last I heard, we were to be in Manhattan over winter break. Our producer, Lin-Manuel Miranda (!), would be footing the bill for our transportation and hotel accommodations, and Pop was negotiating between Netflix and Hulu for streaming rights.

Mrs. Norris had taken the unusual position of directing us from the rear of the theater, a decision which was explained by how frequently she ran out through the doors. About the fifth or sixth time, Darla caught the knowing looks we were exchanging, and asked, "What's going on?"

"It's a bit of a story," Brooklynne said, and gave a concise recitation of her relationship with Bronx, the resulting near mental breakdown, and how the first Gaian baby she was to have was purified and implanted in Mrs. Norris.

When Mrs. Norris returned, Darla asked, "Are you alright, ma'am?"

"Probably just a 24-hour bug," she said, "I'll be fine."

"It might not hurt to get checked out tomorrow. You know, just in case."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Play rehearsal.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Before rehearsals could continue, a tall, average built man entered the auditorium with a number of papers in a folder. He moved a lock of his brown hair away from his flashing brown eyes as he confronted us. "Cease and desist!" Firmly, he ordered. "This production is under copyright! My client demands that you halt this production, as you are all guilty of plagiarism!"

We all turned to the man, rather surprised and annoyed, as there was no way the play had ever been made on Earth. Only to argue with this person would risk spilling the beans on its true origin. We were again surprised when Ms Switch winked at us before walked straight up to the man who had entered, demanding that we stop, "Absolutely, this play is under copyright." Calmly, she said. "Young Miss Pennant and her sister, along with their friends, wrote the play several years ago."

The man scoffed, though I sensed he was suddenly nervous. "Do you have proof of this claim?"

Ms Switch walked to a briefcase she had brought with her and pulled out a large sealed manuscript envelope. "This is called, in legal terms, a poor man's copyright." Calmly, Ms Switch explained. "A complete version of the play mailed to oneself as legal proof of the date of its completion." She smiled. "May I see the date of your client's copyright?"

Reluctantly, the man handed Ms Switch the papers, to which she shook her head. "Tsk Tsk... this copyright was requested yesterday." Disappointment in her voice, she said. "Also, it seems your client was denied copyrights, as there is already one for the play in pending, set by one Lin-Manuel Miranda, in our names." She handed the paperwork back to the man. "I believe the term, 'better luck next time' fits here better than any other."

"As well as take a hike." Firmly, Darla added.

"Perhaps we should press charges of our own." Folding her arms, Brooklynne suggested.

"Now, Now..." Smiling, Ms Switch scolded. "I'm certain this was just a misunderstanding." She turned to the man, her face turning dark. "Let us hope no further misunderstandings occur."

The man huffed and turned on his heel before storming out, without another word. After he was gone, Ms Switch turned to Darla and Brooklynne. "Well played, you two." Smiling, she said. "Now we must return to rehearsals..."

"How were you able to handle that guy so calmly?" Curious, I asked.

Ms Switch giggled. "Because i was once very much like Darla and Brooklynne were, before their reform, when I was their age." Calmly, she explained. "I was violent and manipulative, doing whatever it took to get my way in life." She let out a sad sigh. "Then the horrible realization that our world was dying hit us all. It was a wake up call I hope none of you ever have to face."

The mood in the room became quite depressing until Ms Switch added, "Only, thanks to all of you, my world, my people have a chance to survive."

That brought smiles to our faces once more, and the rehearsals continued. "What do you think that guy will try next?" After rehearsals, I asked.

Ms Switch shook her head. "Likely, he will go back to his boss and ask what to do." Serious, she replied. "My guess would be bribery." she smiled. "Remember, those who do not know you and your circle of friends assume you are just regular high school girls... easily frightened and easily bought off..."

"One more question, Ms Switch." Wincing, Pat asked. "How does one run for prom queen?"

Brooklynne, hearing her, giggled. "It's basically a popularity contest." Calmly, she explained. "Darla only won because she chased away anyone who would compete with her."

Darla blushed, looking ashamed. "You will have to show the school you are worthy through activities, helping others, inspiring students to do better,..."

"We'll help you two, as I have dropped out of the running for this year." Serious, Brooklynne said.

"You dropped out of the race?" Surprised, I asked.

Brooklynne nodded. "I needed more time to spend with Dad." Smiling, she said.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Rehearsal Is Disrupted

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Brooklynne and Darla began their instruction at our house.

"Let's start with activities," Brooklynne said. "The play is a start, but you'll need to do more."

"Try the decorating committee," Darla said. "They can always use extra hands. When people see you pitching in around the school, they'll get the feeling that you care about it, and us."

"I had one idea," Pat said. "How about if we hand out candy canes between classes? You know, just give kids a candy cane with a smile and a 'Happy Holidays.'"

"That's the spirit, girlfriend," Darla said.

Pat giggled. "Did you ever think you'd call me that?"

"Can't say I did," Darla said, giggling in return.

We spitballed ideas back and forth, until Darla said, "I think you're ready for this."

"You've come a long way," Brooklynne said, "from the girl who wouldn't say 'Boo' to a goose."

"I didn't think it was possible for me," I replied. "Of course," I added, one hand on my belly, "I've learned a lot of things are possible."

"This deserves a reward," Brooklynne said, "and I know just the thing. This is your first trip to New York, right?"

"You know it."

"Well, there's nothing wrong with going from Minnesota to New York, but there's no reason for you to look like it. Get the Sisterhood together."

After we made the calls, Brooklynne said to Mom, "I'm taking your girls shopping, Mrs. Pennant."

"No maxing out my card."

"We're using mine, and I have no idea what the upper limit is."

"Just remember," I said, "we'll be three months along. Mom says our clothes will be getting snug."

"Good point. Room to grow. Got it."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Learning to win prom queen.

choices: Later, on to the next store.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
One limousine ride later, we all walked into the local mega mall. All fifteen of us, including Mom and Pop, who seemed a bit lost. "So this is the mall..." Awestruck, Mom said.

"I'm used to buying everything at the thrift shop." Softly, Pop added.

Brooklynne giggled. "Well, prepare yourselves, Pop and Mrs Pennant." Smiling, she said. "We are all about to get pampered and primped for our trip to the New York big stage."

"This should be quite an experience for you, Pat." Smiling, Darla said. She nudged her arm. "Being born a boy and all."

Pat smiled. "I am reborn." Softly, she said. Turning to Sarah, she added, "In more ways than one."

Sarah smiled at that, but said nothing. I decided to get the ball rolling by asking, "Where to first?"

"First, we get you all up to date in fashions." Kindly, Brooklynne said. "We want our looks to literally shout out..."

"Rich...?" Raising an eyebrow, Pop asked.

Brooklynne shook her head. "New Yorker..."

I smiled at that, as we were then led into a clothing store called Rose Bud Fashions where we were greeted by a young saleslady with a patient smile. "Good morning, Miss Dietrich." Kindly, she said. "I see you have brought some friends."

"Guys, I would like you to meet Viva Rose." Kindly, Brooklynne said. "At the age of twenty, she is the owner and operator of Rose Bud Fashions. She is very interested in the costumes in our play, and has an offer for us."

"I see the costumes in your play becoming an instant hit new fashion sensation." Serious, Viva said. "If whoever came up with those fashions gave me exclusive rights to them, I'll give her or them a partnership in the business, and dress you all up to the nines for free."

We all turned to each other, surprised and flattered. "Ms Switch, the principal of our school, came up with the original idea." Smiling, I said. "I drew up the designs with a few ideas of my own, and Nicole made them for the play."

In a way, it was the truth, as Ms Switch came from the world the fashions came from, and I did alter the designs a bit to make them more 'Earth friendly,' and Nicole made them with Mom's sewing machine with impressive speed. Viva seemed surprised, but she still smiled. "Do you think we can hammer out a deal?" Hopeful, she asked.

I turned to Nicole, who smiled, her eyes pointing towards inside the store. I turned and smiled myself upon seeing Ms Switch, who was smiling as well. "I believe that can be arranged."

Viva squealed, clapping her hands like an excited teenager. When she was able to compose herself, she motioned to the many clothing racks "Let's get started then! New York awaits you!"

Ms Switch giggled, a joyful tear rolling down her cheek. "My world is coming back to life..." Whispering, she said.

I gave her a one armed hug. "Our world, Ms Switch." whispering back, I said. "Welcome home."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Two worlds becoming one.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"So, Cassie," Brooklynne asked, as we left Rose Bud, "how does it feel to be a fashion designer?"

"I can't get over it," I replied. "The last time I got news this surprising, I was in a hospital gown, being told I was one of three girls who didn't know how they got pregnant."

"Alright, ladies," Brooklynne said, "time for a real-life makeup tutorial."

She took us to a high-end cosmetics shop, Face the World. "My friends are going to New York," she told the staff. "Teach them how to turn, not just the men's heads, but the women's as well."

Ho. Ly. Cow.

I never thought I could look the way they showed me. When I got a look at my reflection, I thought, No wonder Mom got, not one, but two men to propose.

"If you two ever went to school looking like this," Darla said, "you'd have your pick of the school."

As we were leaving, a display caught my eye. "Excuse me," I said, pointing. "What's that?"

"Oh, the hairstyles? People saw hair like that in a play, and they came in looking for it. It really seems to have caught on."

Another beautician came and whispered to her. Turning to us, she said, "That was you? Wow. No charge. Enjoy your day."

I couldn't believe it. People saw the wigs we'd made, and wanted their hair to look like that. The Gaian influence is spreading...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Later, on to the next store.

choices: Next day, the regular teachers return.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Upon returning to school, we felt rather overwhelmed. Our play was affecting everything, from fashion, to hairstyles, to even music. There were students wearing Rose Line replicas of our costumes, others were sporting the hairstyles... Pat and I even heard the song 'Gaia' being played on the radio to promote the play being held at Playhouse Square next month! It was a high that was hard to explain. Only we were not the only ones to notice this movement, The substitute teachers who had come as mysteriously as the aliens seemed to carry looks of concern.

"What is your secret, Miss Pennant?" Curious, one of the teachers asked.

"I'm not sure what you mean." Taken aback, I replied.

"You practically have the entire school, no, the entire town, in the palm of your hands." Softly, the teacher said. "All from a play you and your friends had written."

I shrugged. "Our ideas just caught on, I guess." Honestly, I said. "We're all very proud of the work that has gone into it to bring it this far."

"I'm sure you are." With a slight frown, the teacher said. "I just hope you aren't too disappointed if this movement of yours does not last too long."

"I get the feeling you don't like the play." Slightly louder, I said. This caught the attention of the students around us, a tactic I had learned from Brooklynne. "May I ask why?"

The teacher looked around, noticing he now had an audience to his hushed conversation to me. "Clever, kid..." Whispering, he said. Then, out loud, he said, "I'm just saying that this could be just a flash in the pan. Popular now, and yesterday's news tomorrow."

"Square!" Grinning, one boy said. "No sense of the in and now." I noticed he was wearing a Rose Line Gaia shirt and pants.

"Most adults don't get it." Giggling, a girl added. I noticed she was wearing a Gaian-inspired hairstyle as she added, "Every generation has its movement, and this is ours."

"The Gaian movement." Smiling, I said. "This generation is going to do something to save our world, where the old did nothing."

Cheers erupted from the class as the substitute teacher frowned, before returning to the front of the class to begin his lecture. At lunch, we all shared similar stories of the substitute teachers trying to downplay the excitement over our play, and failing in an epic way. "What have we started?" Bemused, Pat asked. "It feels as if we are transforming the entire town into a Gaian settlement."

"It's the power of the prophets." Startling us, Ms Switch said. "The Gods have smiled upon you all, and are giving us the second chance we had prayed for."

"I don't think it's all that." Blushing, I said. "I think it's just so new and fresh that everyone wants to be a part of it."

"Perhaps..." smiling, Ms Switch said. "We all have our own beliefs."

We all shared a nervous giggle after Ms Switch had walked on, before I noticed that Lauren was drawing something in a notebook with her hands shaking. "What do you have there?" Curious, I asked. "A design keeping you awake?"

"Actually, yes." Wincing, Lauren replied. She sighed. "I have this uncomfortable feeling that, if I don't draw this, it will hurt us all down the road."

That caught my attention. "I had that same feeling about the Gaian music."

"I had the same feeling about the Gaian world." Gulping, Pat said. "Sarah and I are working together to make a globe of the world."

"Is this the same with the rest of you?" Worried, I asked.

The others nodded. Apparently, the movement was affecting us, as well...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The Gaian movement.

choices: We needed time to think about it.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"Exactly what is it?" Curious, I asked. "It looks complicated."

"I don't really understand it all myself." Wincing, Lauren admitted. "Technology is not my thing."

I looked over the drawings Lauren was working on. They looked like blueprints to a complex machine that, to my surprise, I understood perfectly. "Accelerated Artificial Photosynthesis." Calmly, I said. "It's basically a large mechanical plant that takes in carbon dioxide, light, and water then quickly turns it into energy and oxygen." I smiled, staring at the blueprints. "It can literally power itself once it gets started."

"You understand all of this?" Shocked, Lauren asked.

"I understand it better than the songs and art work flooding my mind at night." Shaking my head, I replied. "Technology is more my thing."

Lauren smiled. "Art and music is mine."

"Hold on..." Curious, Pat said. "Do you think the Gaians invented that to try to save their world?"

"They did." Sadly, Brooklynne said. "Only it was too little, too late..."

"Only it's not too late for us." Softly, Sarah said. "Do you think we can get that gizmo built and running, with everything else going on?"

I shook my head. "We would need hundreds of these units to do any good." Serious, I replied. "Besides, I doubt any of us are qualified to build anything this advanced."

"Incoming..." Frowning, Pat said.

I turned to see one of the substitute teachers, Mr Smith, approaching the table. He saw Lauren drawing something on paper and curiously looked over her shoulder. "I didn't know you were into technology, Lauren." Surprised, he said. "I have a degree in mechanical engineering, do you mind if I have a look?"

Lauren and I both shrugged and moved to give Mr Smith a better view. Only we both held on to the paper, to ensure he didn't take it. "It's just something that had been floating around in my head for a while." Honestly, Lauren said. "Technology is more Cassie's comfort zone, so she had been helping me."

"This is incredible." Showing genuine interest, Mr Smith said. "Are you planning to use this in your little production?"

"We were considering it." Serious, I replied. "Why?"

"This might actually work in real life." Serious, Mr Smith said. "I am impressed."

Lauren blushed at that. "Um... thank you."

"You're not really a teacher, are you?" Wincing, Darla asked.

Mr Smith sighed. "I do have the degrees to be a teacher, but that is not my true profession, no," softly, he admitted. "May I sit down?"

Although we were all slightly annoyed and disturbed that Mr Smith wasn't a real teacher, we made room for him to join us. "Who are you really, then?" Frowning, Brooklynne demanded. "Also, why shouldn't we report you to the school board?"

"First, it would be your word against ours, so good luck with that." Calmly, Mr. Smith replied. "Second, my colleagues and I are scientists under the hire of the Grimm Oil Company." He raised his hand. "Before you even ask, we had nothing to do with the so-called attorney who disrupted your rehearsals. This was Maximilian Grimm's ploy to slow down the production."

"He's the CEO of Grimm Oil." Serious, Nicole said. "A multibillionaire and advocate for the rich and powerful."

"But why come after us?" Curious, Pat asked.

"If anyone were really after you, less subtle means would have been applied." Serious, Mr Smith said. "The save Earth movement was picking up steam long before you kids came up with this play, but your production has given that movement vast momentum in a very short time."

"Let me guess." Frowning, Brooklynne said. "Saving the Earth is bad for business."

"Grimm Oil, and other companies around the world, are struggling to come up with alternative fuel supplies that meet the existing demands." Serious, Mr Smith explained. "However, new technology takes time and a lot of money... scientists do not come cheap." He then smiled. "However, this device promises to buy that time and money."

"What are you suggesting?" Curious, I asked.

"Agree to a private meeting with us." Serious, Mr Smith said. "Perhaps we can get a working prototype of this device built." He shrugged. "What do you have to lose?"

I turned to the others, who seemed just as surprised and skeptical as I was,...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The substitutes are fake teachers.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"What sort of conditions?" In a guarded tone, Mr Smith asked.

"First, we have proof of your confession." Serious, Darla said. She and the others held up their cellphones as she played back part of her recording. "So no more strange questions about us or our play, understood?"

Mr Smith sighed. "Understood."

"Second, we want our fathers in on this meeting." Serious, Brooklynne said. "Because of your confession, we do not feel comfortable alone with you and your associates." She motioned to her friends. "You know what the last substitutes did to some of us."

"Again, Mr. Smith sighed. "Very well. Anything else?"

"Bring your boss, Mr Grimm." Firmly, I said. "He's the one pulling the strings, so it will save time if we just to talk to him directly."

Mr Smith seemed surprised. "You kids don't beat around the bush, do you?"

"Pop always told me that, if you want to solve a problem, go directly to its source." Serious, I said. "Your employer seems concerned by our production, so, to solve that, we will talk with him, along with our parents."

Mr Strange stood up. "I'll see what I can arrange." Calmly, he said.

Just as he turned around, he found himself facing Ms Switch. "Sit... down." Her voice was cold and firm. "Call your boss here, with us listening."

Mr. Smith, although taken aback and a bit frightened, nodded and slowly sat down as he made the call. "Mr Grimm, we have been discovered." Calmly, he said. "The children want a meeting with you directly... they have something to offer."

He handed his phone to me. "Hello... ?"

"First, I apologize for my overzealous assistant, who sent an attorney to slow down the progress of your production." The deep voice of Mr Grimm said. "He has been penalized."

"A misunderstanding, I'm sure." Calmly, I said. "We would like to discuss this with you in person, this weekend, if you are free."

"Mr. Smith said you had something to offer." Calmly, Mr. Grim said.

"We will discuss this in length at the meeting." Serious, I said. "I am a minor, and will not discuss such things without my father, who acts as my counsel."

"Where do you propose we meet?" Curious, Mr. Grimm asked.

After a pause, I replied...
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: We agreed with conditions.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"The school auditorium." simply, I replied. "We are holding rehearsals then. You can see the entire production for yourself before the meeting." After a pause, I added, "We are not a threat to your business, we just want to help the planet."

Grimm let out a short chuckle. "If I saw you as a threat, young lady, I would have simply bought out all of the shows, and no one would have seen them." Calmly, he said. "No, my concern lies within the impact your production is having upon the world around you."

"What do you mean?" Taken aback, I asked.

"Your play has not yet hit the big stage, and it is already starting a revolution." Serious, Grimm said. "It took me years to become a multi-billionaire with influential contacts, and here you are, set to surpass my achievements in a fraction of the time." He chuckled. "I am a bit envious..."

I giggled slightly at that. "I'm not sure how to take that."

"Take it as a compliment, Miss Pennant." Calmly, Grimm said. "At what time should you expect my arrival at your school?"

"Ten in the morning." Serious, I replied. "We start rehearsals then. The play hits the big stage in less than a month."

"I will be there." Calmly, Grimm said. "Until then... goodbye."

Upon ending the call, I relayed what was said to the others. "I don't know about you, but I get the feeling he's not telling us everything."

"That's usually how it goes with agreements over the telephone." Serious, Ms Switch said. "Neither party knows who is listening in."

"She's right." Serious, Mr Smith said. "It was wise of you not to put all of your cards onto the table over the phone."

"What is your position in all of this, Mr Smith?" Firmly, Ms Switch demanded. "Why were you and your associates sent here?"

Mr Smith turned to her, surprised, to which Brooklynne said, "No one cane keep a secret from Ms Switch for long, she always figures it out."

Mr Smith shrugged. "To learn more about the production, and how it is influencing everything in this town so quickly." Calmly, he replied. "Based upon its success in this school, it could easily become a worldwide phenomenon soon after hitting the big stage."

My friends and I turned to each other, shocked and surprised. We had not even considered that, but, with how our play is affecting our small town, it seemed very possible. Mr Smith smiled at our expressions. "I take it you had not thought that far ahead yet." Calmly, he said. "You kids really have something special here, and a lot of people will soon want to be a part of it."

"Or want it not to move forward." Frowning, Lauren said.

Mr Smith nodded. "It's possible." Serious, he replied. "There are a lot of big companies who would lose billions if clean air and water restrictions become tighter."

"But they are hurting our planet with the way they are doing things now." Wincing, Pat said.

Mr Smith nodded. "I agree, but there is a quote: 'When a pickpocket enters a church, he does not see the worshipers or the priest, he only sees their pockets.'"

"So when these big companies pollute our planet, they do not see the damage, they only see the money they are making." Frowning, Ms Switch said. "History repeats..."

The rest of us nodded, leaving Mr Smith confused, until we all softly sang the villain song of the play, 'Don't Abandon Us'...

Don’t abandon us!
We’ve been through enough
We all must leave paradise!
This is all that’s left
This is all we’ve got
We all must leave paradise

When we were done, Mr Smith was wiping at tears under his glasses. "That was beautiful and tragic." softly, he said. "Not to mention so true, when it comes to our world."

"That's the message we are trying to send out." serious, I said. "If we do not act now, this play could become a reality."

Mr. Smith nodded. "What do you need us to do?"
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: A meeting is arranged.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
At home, I told Pop about what had happened. "How much did you tell him?" Pop asked.

"Only that he's invited to watch the show, for free," I said. "We've got more to offer, but he didn't tell me everything, and I didn't tell him, either."

"Good plan. Our sole advantage is that he doesn't know what you're capable of. Now, what can you tell me about these substitute teachers?"

"Grimm sent them to find out more about the play, and why it's gone viral in so short a time. That seems to be all."

"Cassie, you, of all people, should know better than to take people as they seem to be. There's more to this, and Mr. Smith and his cronies are wild cards. I'd bet that they have their suspicions about you."

"What's to be suspicious about?"

"Sweetie," he said, pointing to the plans Lauren had drawn, "I have an engineering degree, and I couldn't tell you what this does or how it works. Look, tell me that some high school students wrote a play that went viral, and I could believe it. Tell me that someone with no education on the subject could kluge her way to cleaning the air and powering the world, and I have my doubts. Those substitute teachers know more than they've told you."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Later, I tell Pop of the meeting.

choices: We speak to the new Gaians.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
As promised, Mr Grimm showed at ten in the morning to watch our play rehearsals. We gave it our all to put on a good show, hoping to get the oil tycoon in a good mood for the meeting. The four scientists were there as well, with a tall, thin man in a suit, with short brown hair and green eyes behind gold-rimmed glasses. I could only guess he was Grimm's attorney. Among them were all of our parents, including Sarah's mother. After the play, there was not a single dry eye among the scientists, parents, or the presumed attorney, but Mr Grimm remained neutral as stone, his expression revealing nothing.

"You play is a bit apocalyptic, almost biblical in its message." Calmly, Grimm said. "Although I must admit it is very well put together, I cannot endorse this."

"We are not looking for your endorsement, nor do we need any permission from you to perform our play on Playhouse Square." serious, Pop said. "We are here to discuss your apparent opposition to the play going on stage."

"As I said over the telephone, I am not interested in the children themselves, or their play." Calmly, Grimm said. "I am more interested in the play's impact upon the population."

His attorney sighed. "Jay Higgins, company attorney," he said. "Imagine if this play moves the population to demand stricter regulations on air and water purity. The powers that make our laws will be moved to comply."

"That will cost all oil and manufacturing companies billions." Frowning, Grimm said. "Now, I know you see us as billionaires, more interested in making money than the health of our planet, but understand the demands of our customers."

"Without oil or manufacturing , the world will almost literally slow to a halt." Serious, Jay said. "The demand for both is too great to just stop."

"We have a solution for that, actually." Calmly, I said. "Lauren came up with the idea, and I helped her with the design."

Grimm raised a single eyebrow. "I assume this is what you had to offer me." Calmly, he said.

"These kids are quite brilliant, Mr. Grimm." Calmly, Mr Smith said.

Grimm grunted as Lauren and I showed him the blueprints we had drawn together over the course of the night. It took less time that we had feared, and we were able to sleep well before the play. "Accelerated Artificial Photosynthesis." Reading the title, Grim said. "Interesting..."

He looked over the blueprints with Jay, who seemed impressed. "This is very complex, well beyond any normal teenage girl." Softly, Grimm said. "It would seem we are dealing with a group of prodigies, Mr Higgins."

"We try to be humble." Serious, Brooklynne said.

"They could make a fine addition to our company, Mr. Grimm." Calmly, Jay said.

"My partner, Mr Creed, might agree with that." Calmly, Grimm said. "However, I do not share that optimistic enthusiasm." he sighed. "This device, as brilliant as it is, will completely replace any need for oil for generations, it will ruin me..."

"The patents alone are worth billions, Mr Grimm." Serious, Mr Smith argued.

"I do not own the patents!" Angrily, Grimm yelled. "This play, this invention, will completely destroy everything I have built!" He stood up, fuming. "One day, in the far future, oil and gas will be replaced with alternative fuels, but I will not allow it to happen while I am at the height of my wealth!"

"Pickpockets in a church..." Whispering carefully, Pop said.

"We are very sorry you feel that way, Mr. Grimm." Standing up, Mr Smith said. "We cannot, in good conscience, continue working for your company... we resign, effective immediately."

"There are things worth more than money, Mr. Grimm." Calmly, Pat said. "You stand to make trillions with this device we are offering."

"That, and, with this device, you could become a world-renowned hero." Serious, Sarah replied. "Money comes and goes, but legends never die."

Mr Grimm paused, only for a second. "You are telling me that history will judge me for this day." Coldly, he said. "That might be true, but I live in the here and now." He shook his head. "I will buy out every last seat in every last performance, no one will see this play."

"You are a bit too late for that." Smiling, Nicole said. "My parents made certain to advertise the dates of the performances, and they sold out within hours."

"You stand to make more working with us than against us, Mr. Grimm." Serious, Brooklynne said. "Please reconsider this..."

"Enough..." Through gritted teeth, Grimm said. "I will do whatever it takes to bring this production down, and as for that device..."

"It's already patented." Frowning, Ms Switch said. "You were given the chance to cash in on this with us, and it's still open, as long as you stay and listen to reason."

Mr Grimm huffed and stormed out of the auditorium, with his attorney hesitantly following. "Why can't he see that this helps everyone, including him?" Wincing, Sarah asked.

"He's blinded by his wealth and pride, dear." Gently, her mom said. "The love of money is the root of all evils, and the more money one has, the deeper the roots of evil can get."

"Still, he can't stop the play... can he?" Worried, Pat asked.

"You will have an extra set of eyes on your side." Serious, Mr. Smith said. We were all shocked to see his eyes turn a bright blue before returning to their normal hazel color. "We are, sadly, the villains your play spoke of. Only, unlike Grimm, we have learned our lesson..."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: The Meeting

choices: The Next Attempt at Stopping the Play
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"How long have you been on this planet?" Ms. Switch asked.

Mr. Smith cocked an eyebrow. "Almost as long as you, I suspect." Turning to us, he said, "We were disheartened to see that your world was well on its way to sharing Gaia's fate. We infiltrated Grimm Oil, hoping we could steer the company onto a better course from within. Sadly, as you've seen, the CEO is quite resolute that the status quo remain unaltered."

"He's not the first," Ms. Switch said.

"I know. Perhaps, if we had the capabilities of your Charles Dickens, we might have been able to sway him. However, the play has attracted a great deal of attention, and it seems possible that it may effect the change required to save your world. Tell me, how did you really come by this story? Did your Ms. Switch give it to you?"

"Not as directly as you imply," I replied. I gave him an abbreviated version of the events that had brought us all to this point. "We wanted to do what we could to make this a better world for our children. Even so, we never dreamed it would take off like it has."

"I'm glad it has," Mr. Smith said. "It's as if the gods followed us to your world, and are working through you."

"Usually, pregnant Earth women don't like to be put under so much pressure," I told him.

"Don't forget," Ms. Switch said, "your Gaian children are making you stronger as they grow within you."
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: We speak to the new Gaians.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The next day, the regular teachers had returned from their vacations, looking happy and refreshed. The new Gaians were still there, but in the form of hall monitors, due to the open threats by the oil tycoon, Mr Grimm. I had told Pop of the meeting the night before. His words stuck with me as I sat down to lunch...

"Powerful men like Max Grimm will stop at nothing to remove whatever lies within his path to further riches and power." Serious, Pop told me. "However, Grimm is currently under the microscope of the federal government, he will not do anything that would directly tie him to any serious crime."

"What can we do?" worried, I asked. "We are no threat to him..."

"The powerful message your play delivers is a threat to his status quo." Calmly, Pop said. "He is blind to the damage he is causing, due to the money he is making." He surprised me with a gentle smile. "As for what you can do, just press on... I and the other parents will be holding a meeting to discuss our options for fighting back."

Returning my mind to the present, I turned to Sarah. "Did your father say anything to you when you told him about the meeting?"

Sarah shrugged. "Just that all the riches of the world are nothing compared to the Grace of God, and that he would be talking to the other parents about preparing for a storm."

"My dad said something similar." Serious, Nicole said. "He told us that we have the power of youth and change on our side."

"My dad was furious when I told him about the meeting." Serious, Brooklynne said. "He told me that Grimm is not the only tycoon at the table, and that he would look into his threats against us."

One by one, all of my friends informed me that their parents reacted in a similar way to Pop, and that they were going to discuss their options to fight back. "It's incredible." Smiling, I said. "Our parents have untied behind us and our message."

The rest of the day went smoothly, and I was feeling good about our chances, until we entered the auditorium for rehearsals. Every last prop was destroyed, every costume was torn to shreds, every scenery panel was destroyed with splashed paint... everything we worked so hard to build for the play was ruined. For a moment, we just stood there with our mouths open in shock, before both Brooklynne and Darla knotted their jaws with anger in their eyes.

"So they want to play, do they?" Angry, Darla asked. "Okay..."

"They're not stopping us that easily!" Furious, Brooklynne added.

"What do you have in mind?" Wincing, Sarah asked.

"We used to do this all the time to others who stood in our way." Serious, Brooklynne said. "That said, we always prepared ourselves for retaliation."

I watched in amazement as Darla turned to her cellphone. "Mom, they did just as we had suspected." Calmly, she said. "Does Uncle Frank have the backup scenery ready?" She smiled. "Great, we will need them delivered ASAP."

Brooklynne turned to her own cellphone. "Rose, someone just destroyed all of our props and costumes, do you have the backups ready?" She smiled. "Great... yes, you have exclusive rights to sell them to the public as promised. Call High End and tell them to have the wigs we need ready within the hour."

Taking a cue from the others, Lauren called her father. "Dad, they destroyed all of the musical instruments, as you suspected." Tearfully, she said. "Did you have the time to make new ones?" she smiled. "You are amazing, Dad! We need them at the school as soon as you can."

"I didn't know your father made musical instruments." Surprised, I said.

Lauren giggled. "Neither did I." Bemused, she said. "It's apparently a hobby of his to make strange and unusual musical instruments." She smiled. "He told me that there just might be a market for the instruments once the production hits the big stage."

After hanging up with her mother, Darla turned to me, smiling. "My Uncle Frank has become like a second father to me, like Pop is to you." Tears forming, she said. "He is a masterful artist who makes scenery for Broadway."

"Rose was more than happy to make professional costumes for our production, in exchange for exclusive rights to sell them to the public." Grinning, Brooklynne said. "Likewise with High End for the rights to the hairstyles and wigs."

"Clear away the old and get ready for the new." Startling us, Pop said. "Your next rehearsals will be better than ever. The new props, costumes and scenery are on their way as we speak."

We all cheered while, in the back of the auditorium, Grimm's attorney, Jay, watched with a frown on his face. He turned to a cellphone. "Vandalism will not slow them down, sir." Disappointed, he said. "The children have the means to replace everything in quick order."

Grimm's dark voice echoed over the phone. "Then we will have to rely on less subtle methods..."

Before Jay could react, Mr Smith took the phone from him. "We know you are behind the vandalism, Grimm." Coldly, he said. "Do not interfere any further, you are not the only player with wealth and power at the table." He then returned the cellphone to Jay. "We have video proof you vandalized the school, and the police are here to question you."

Jay sighed. "Taking me out of the picture will not stop Mr. Grimm." Coldly, he said.

Mr Smith shook his head. "No, it won't." Darkly, he agreed. "However, he now knows we are on to him, and that strengthens our hand."

With that, Jay was taken into the custody of the police. "History repeats, karma strikes." softly, he muttered. "No lessons to learn, we paid the price... We must all leave paradise." he shook his head. "To think I was once like that monster, Max Grimm..."

He began to quietly sob as he watched us rebuild everything for our production.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Parents united.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
The next rehearsal began with everyone in high spirits, especially Mrs. Norris, who had finally gotten her test results back. "I know it's customary to keep this sort of thing quiet for a while longer," she told us at the start, "but I'm too excited. I'm going to have a baby!"

As we all congratulated her, she added, "I know it may sound silly, but part of me feels that I owe this to you. Before this play came along, my husband and I struggled for a baby. In fact, we had given up this past spring. Then you all came to me, and, all of a sudden, I'm pregnant."

None of us laughed, due in no small part to the fact that we really did play a part in her becoming a mother-to-be.

Our good spirits took a tumble, however, when things began to happen.

I was the first. Halfway through my first song, a trapdoor opened up, almost directly beneath my feet.

Sarah came to me first. "Another inch," she said, "and you would be down there."

"I was trying not to think about that," I replied.

"Think it's just a coincidence?"

I shook my head. "Max Grimm's attempts to stop us have failed bitterly, and he's getting desperate."

The trapdoors opened a few more times, nearly taking out five of us. "I knew Grimm was desperate," Pat said, "but I never thought he'd sign off on nearly causing a miscarriage."

"He sees us as a threat to his profits," I replied. "He loves his money more than we love our babies."

Even so, we were all horrified by what came next.

Sarah was in the middle of her song and dance number when a spotlight began to sway. Mr. White pushed her away, but none of us could do anything when the spotlight fell right on top of him.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Accidents begin to happen.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
"Daddy!" Sarah ran to her father, and literally threw the heavy spotlight off of him as if it were tinfoil. She was not concerned by her newfound strength, but for her dad's safety. Mr Smith and the other three scientists had them surrounded in the next breath.

"His injuries are not serious." Calmly, Mr. Smith said. "We can heal him."

Ms Switch, who had been in the audience, scanned the catwalks and saw a dark figure running towards one of the service doors. "Meh ave I!" running, she yelled.

I did not understand what Ms Switch said, but I was shocked to see her leap onto the back of one of the seats before jumping high up to the lowest catwalk. She swung from its rail to the next catwalk up, where the mysterious figure was, and blocked his path! The man swung what looked like a knife, only Ms Switch blocked it, before delivering a crushing blow to the man's jaw. The punch sent the man reeling, but Ms Switch was not done. She kicked him in the knee, then threw him over the catwalk railing, where one of the scientists caught him and threw him over the seats onto the stage.

We all had the beaten man surrounded in the next breath. He was not someone we had seen before, a blurry man in all black with brown hair and eyes. "Who are you, and who are you working for?" Returning to the stage, Ms Switch demanded.

"What are you people?!" Shaken, the man demanded. "No one can move like that!"

"We are veterans of a horrible war most people don't know about." Serious, Ms Switch replied. "Consider yourself grateful you are among those numbers."

"I was just paid to scare you." Trembling, the man replied. "I had no intention of hurting anyone. Had the guy not jumped in, the spotlight would have landed right next to the kid..."

Ms Switch easily lifted the man with one hand, anger in her eyes. "I will ask you one last time." Darkly, coldly, she said. "Who paid you to attack us?"

"I don't know..." Tears forming, the man said. "I was mailed a package with payment in advance and the description of the job."

Ms Switch sighed then turned to Mr Smith. "Torque peek ta meh yap." Softly, she said.

Mr Smith nodded, then dragged the now frightened man out of the auditorium. Once they were gone, I asked, "What did you say to him?"

"I told him in our language to pay him to keep quiet." Serious, Ms Switch said. "The man told us that he performs a task for money, so logic suggests that, if we pay him more, he will ignore the orders of the one who originally hired him."

"I hope you're right." Wincing, I said. I looked around, only to find Pat was no where in sight. "Where is Pat?!"

I called Pat's name and heard her scream. We all turned just in time to see another dark figure, running off with her over his shoulder.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Continue

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
Unfortunately for the kidnapper, Pat Pennant was a less than ideal person to throw over your shoulder and try to hold on to. Grabbing her assailant, she did a backflip that put her feet on the ground right behind him. Still hanging on, she pulled him over her head and threw him to the ground, knocking him unconscious.

"I think Max Grimm has finally lost it," I said.

"You're not kidding," Lauren replied. "Take a look at this note."

I looked. In words and letters cut from a magazine, it read:

YOU CAN HAVE YOUR PLAY
OR YOU CAN HAVE YOUR SISTER ALIVE
CHOOSE WISELY


"Definitely lost it."

Ms. Switch placed a hand on the kidnapper's head, and her eyes and hand glowed blue. Within moments, the man opened his eyes. "What happened?"

"You failed," Ms. Switch said. "Would you care to tell us who put you up to this?"

"Why should I tell you anything?"

"Doesn't it seem unfair to you that, if this had gone even more wrong, you would be facing a murder charge, and your employer would be living the good life?"

"Murder? You got the wrong idea, lady. I wouldn't kill anybody."

She held the note in front of his face. "Maybe you wouldn't, but whoever wanted you to put this note together definitely would. And they were planning to leave you for the authorities."

"And that's not all," Mr. Smith added. "Under the law, if this girl had escaped your custody and been hit by a car, you would be tried for her murder. Again, why should you be loyal to someone who would have left you hanging?"

It was like the air was let out of the man. "I still can't help you," he said. "Everything was done anonymously. I honestly don't know his name."

I clung to Pat, not sure which of us was more scared. Legal maneuvers had failed. Bribery had failed. Vandalism had failed. Accidents had failed. Kidnapping had failed.

I didn't know what was left (or maybe I just didn't want to think that much about it), but I knew it was coming.
1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.title: Pat holds her own.

1111211111111121112121211121211111122111.content:
After we all picked up our luggage at JFK Airport, I don't know which surprised me more: the flotilla of limousines waiting to take us all to the hotel, or who was waiting with them. It seemed like everyone else there was taking pictures of Lin-Manuel Miranda.

I went up and shook his hand. "It's an honor to meet you, Mr. Miranda," I said.

"Please," he replied, "call me Lin."

"I don't know if I can, Mr. Miranda. But I promise to try."

He laughed. I just want to repeat that: I made Lin-Manuel Miranda laugh!!! "How was your flight? Air sickness get too bad?"

"We couldn't say," Nicole replied. "Half of us can't tell the difference between air sickness and morning sickness."

"And the other half can't tell between air sickness and nerves," Trish added.

"Well, make me a promise," he said. "None of you even mention the play until Friday. It'll help your nerves if you think about something else."

"Like what?"

"An excellent question. If only you were in the greatest city in the world, at the most wonderful time of the year. Oh, wait, you are." He began handing out tickets and passes. "There's nothing like Christmas in New York, and you girls are going to get your fill of it. Skating at Rockefeller Center, the Radio City Christmas show. You think about it, we've got it. Relax and unwind."
